Ironically, AoE I DE is now more akin to an awkward stopgap game not unlike how AoE II HD is now, effectively arguably lacking purpose because the Return of Rome DLC for AoE II's own Definitive Edition effectively supersedes this one in regards to "Age 1 but modernized".

I would suggest either:
[list]
[*] Getting a copy of the original and installing UPatch for running it on modern Windows. That also formed the basis of DE's balance adjustments, should you want those.
[*] Playing Return of Rome. It only has some of the original campaigns (that may be ironed out overtime), but also has three new ones, enjoys many modern QoL and amenities from being ported to AoE II DE's more modern engine, and is otherwise the current version maintained.
[/list]

'Full coverage of all the campaigns but in fresh paint' is otherwise the only thing going for AoE I DE in the meantime, and even then it has heavily altered or even replaced many of the scenarios; your mileage may vary. It is intentionally also more conservative than Return of Rome, but that version ended up adding things that people actually wanted in DE. Neither release really has active online in English-speaking communities.

Ultimately, your decision between either version should depend on what it is you're after, but DE's offerings are perhaps the weakest of the three.

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is like a fine wine that's been fermenting for decades in the digital cellar. It may not be the flashiest game on the market, but it's got heart, soul, and enough strategic depth to keep you hooked until your kingdom rises from the ashes or crumbles into oblivion.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1017900/]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/url][/b] is a solid Real-Time Strategy game that offers a variety of campaigns to keep players engaged.

There's plenty of content to enjoy throughout the ten campaigns, starting from the [i]Ascent of Egypt[/i] and [i]Voices of Babylon[/i], and ending with [i]Enemies of Rome[/i] and the [i]First Punic War[/i]. Each campaign consists of between four to twelve scenarios, providing a satisfying amount of gameplay.

The gameplay itself is enjoyable, despite a few flaws. There are instances where units may experience pathfinding issues, leading them to become confused or go in the wrong direction. This can be frustrating, especially when it results in the loss of valuable units. There's also situations where it's difficult to find a unit standing behind a tree.  Additionally, the game mechanics can sometimes be unclear, leading to ambiguous victory conditions, or victories while there's still conditions to be met.

Despite these issues, [b]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/b] still offers hours of strategic fun and satisfaction in building civilizations, managing resources, and engaging in epic battles or journeys. If you enjoy Real-Time Strategy games, and can overlook its flaws, this game is definitely one worth trying out.

[quote] [b]TL;DR:[/b] [i]"Age of Empires: Definitive Edition"[/i] is a declaration of love for old-fashioned real-time strategy and a beautiful journey back to childhood.[/quote]

[b]üïó Total time played (approx.):[/b] 82h
[b]üèÜ Completion:[/b] 100% (44/44 Steam Achievements)

[b]REVIEW:[/b]

[i]"Age of Empires: Definitive Edition"[/i] is not just a remake of a classic but a lovingly crafted monument to the glorious era of real-time strategy. As a game that shaped my childhood, I was curious to see how this remake would blend nostalgia with modern enhancements. I'm delighted to say that it has succeeded in preserving the essence of the original while introducing fresh elements to captivate even new players.

One of the most remarkable features of [i]"Age of Empires: Definitive Edition"[/i] is the revamped graphics. The 4K resolution and improved textures make the game world appear more vibrant and detailed than ever before. Exploring the tiny details in the cities and experiencing epic battles in stunning graphics is great. But the beauty of this game lies not only in its visuals but also in its gameplay. The mechanics feel familiar yet have been refined to ensure a smooth gaming experience. The balance between resource management, construction, and combat remains engaging and challenging. It's amazing to see how well the fundamental principles of the game still work after all these years.

Another highlight of [i]"Age of Empires: Definitive Edition"[/i] is the soundtrack. The iconic music that once shaped the atmosphere of the game has been masterfully remastered, adding an epic touch to every match. It's nearly impossible not to hum along while guiding your civilization through the ages.

However, what truly sets this remake apart is its attention to detail. From small animations to historical background information, the game provides a wealth of knowledge and little surprises that will even astonish long-time fans. Especially for lovers of history and historical settings, [i]"Age of Empires: Definitive Edition"[/i] comes highly recommended. Through the game, players gain insight into many fascinating backgrounds of different epochs and civilizations, enriching the gaming experience even further.

Overall, the game is a triumphant remake that captures the magic of the original and brings it into the modern age. It's a game that transports me back to my childhood while also showing that timeless games retain their fascination and finesse even after all these years.

The game itself is [i]as fun[/i] as usual, keywords being as fun.  If you never played Age of Empires 1, get this on sale.  If you have, then it depends on the strength of your nostalgia. I used to own this version on Microsoft Store and it was awful, the Steam version is MUCH better. There is also no "HD Edition" or GoG version, so this is the main way to play "original" Age of Empires (except for emulating the original in VmWare of course).

It is very nostalgic, has 100% of the campaigns from both the original game and Rise of Rome expansion, the music aaaand... the clunkiness.

I think AoE DE was more of a trial run before making the excellent AoE 2 DE. In that regard this game is great since it paved the way for the sequel, just like it was all those years ago. Age of Empires 2 in 1999 was a massive leap forward from Age of Empires in 1997 making that game obsolete.

I still like the setting - the ancient bronze age era period, as well as Roman era. I always had a soft spot for the Egyptian stone age intro which felt very "cozy" for lack of better word. The original manual was awesome, thick, and had some minor history book texts about the civilizations, as well as some of these texts in game at the start of the campaigns (still have these in DE, yay!).

Right now the final nails in the coffin are being hammered in for this version since a reimagining is being made as a DLC for Age of Empires II Definitive Edition - Return of Rome - with currently 3 of 5 original campaigns having already been done and ready to play. As well as 3 brand new campaigns (AoE 2 DE truly got all the love).

Two quality of life improvements in Return of Rome makes this version obsolete: Pathfinding and formations. The ancient era (the Romans, come on!) had some seriously well made formations in their units, but due to technical difficulties this didn't exist in OG Age of Empires to everybody's detriment. When it was implemented in Age of Empires 2 this feature alone made AoE 1 a dinosaur after only 2 years.

Pathfinding is terrible in this version just like the original and is a huge source of frustration.

PROBLEMS

This version has some serious issues. 
- The scaling seems a bit off 
- Placing buildings kind of "glow in green" which seems strange and unimmersive
- The menu is very basic (just like the original of course, but it's way better made in AoE 2 DE - Return of Rome)
- The water splashing against the shore line is just really, really bad and unimmersive.
- The pathfinding is still horrible (of course 100% original)
- No formations

THE GOOD
- Has all campaigns
- Music is more nostalgic
- Voiced campaign intros (these also exist in Return of Rome)
- Good graphics in general.

Age of Empires was literally my first PC game some 25 years ago, and it brought me into the world of RTS. It's nice they are keeping a classic alive. The only things I remember from the game are the tutorial missions. I still remember being surprised that you can actually walk over (shallow) water to get to the berries on the other side. 
I think what made the OG AoE1 great are its music and graphics, which have now been updated, its time period with well known figures like Caesar and Hannibal, and intuitive units. A 7 year old can understand you use archers to take out melee, cavalry to charge at enemy archers, siege to destroy towers and buildings, etc. This makes it relatively easy to get into compared to sci-fi or fantasy settings. The only confusing thing is that weapon and armor upgrades are in the storage pit.
Also, the history notes in the campaign missions were quite interesting, which span all the way from hunting and foraging to the Roman Empire. 

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition improves on the original in 2 significant ways, beyond sounds and visuals.
1. The ability to zoom out. In AoE:DE you can zoom out to the point where it becomes hard to select individual units, which is actually refreshing to see.
2. The population limit has been increased to 250. Some may not like the higher pop cap, because it changes the gameplay, but it's better to have the option than not. When you make a custom scenario, you can even set the limit to an absurd 9000. If only the AI could handle it, it would make for some epic battles.

Other than that, the game plays exactly like the original including its notorious terrible path-finding. It also still has a limit of 36 units that you can select at any time, which is even more nonsensical now with the increased pop cap.

All in all, I'd recommend Age of Empires: Definitive Edition mostly for nostalgia or achievement hunting, or if you're particularly fond of the time period. I highly doubt anyone in the world plays this as their main strategy game.

Age of Empires was a fundamental part of my RTS education. Two years before it I was enjoying the futurist spin of Command & Conquer and the fantasy vibes of Warcraft II, but Age of Empires offered up something else entirely ‚Äî a middle-ground.

It was a monumental moment in the history of the genre, as the awe-inspiring sprite-work and the sheer scope of the game really spoke to me and spurred my interest in ancient civilizations. Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is still very much a game from the ‚Äô90s, lacking the panache of its sucessors, but those of you with an open mind and a strategic knack will enjoy it just as I did all those years ago.Even though I haven‚Äôt played in ages, all of my prior knowledge came flowing back through me as soon as I moused my cursor over my first worker. The Definitive Edition has a way about it that just feels right, to the point where I had to do a double-take and watch a video of the original just to see if I was going crazy. No, the 1997 edition never looked this good, and the remaster doesn‚Äôt douse its legacy in any way.

A tried and true skirmish-based RTS, the concept of a warring over a finite amount of resources that forces eventual confrontation isn‚Äôt unique to Age of Empires, but it‚Äôs handled a bit more organically in this series. With several forms of resource gathering (such as hunting and farming berries for food) you always feel like you have a strategic choice, rather than just setting and forgetting a bunch of drones to grab gold from a mine. Rising through the ages for upgrades at new tiers (an RTS staple) is gamey, sure, but it‚Äôs engaging and framed as moving through major moments in history. Multiple win conditions like building and defending a Wonder to win are still magical and unique.

Subtle enhancements that bring the original iteration into the modern era are welcome. Attack move (where units quite literally can attack while navigating if you press a qualifying button) is a no-brainer. So are all the included staples of old school RTS that are still relevant today ‚Äî multiple building orders, control groups, viewing idle villagers at a glance. Pathfinding (the process in which units locate areas you command them to go) is the only ‚Äúimproved‚Äù mechanic that still needs work. It‚Äôll all come naturally to folks who have moved on from Age of Empires and into more uncharted territory. The population limit increase is really the big draw here. While a lot of remasters fundamentally don‚Äôt touch the base, Microsoft took a chance here and shook up the game while keeping in some tongue in cheek references.Ratcheting up a unit cap that served as a technical limitation doesn‚Äôt sacrifice its strategic core, and it works particularly well with the expanded zoom feature ‚Äî whoever put in for that one deserves a raise. I was taking all this in with the tasteful animation alterations (mainly more stylish building destruction) and the orchestral soundtrack. The only aspect of the presentation that feels off is the UI ‚Äî which is so dated that it‚Äôs like the team ran out of money to fix it up.

What‚Äôs going to be the big holdup, not only for power users but for posterity, is online play. It‚Äôs very finicky even after its beta state, to the point where you really need to sort of go into this remaster knowing it‚Äôs a single-player game. Despite the boisterous claim of dedicated servers for all on Xbox One, some PC releases are left in the dust, this one included.

Remember all of those fun ‚Äô90s ping issues you had? Well they‚Äôre back, baby! Having tested out the multiplayer in the live version I ran into some of the same issues as the beta, where entire games would drop as a result of a connection error. Having to go through the Microsoft Store app, which significantly hinders my ability to play the game at times (I had to go through multiple processes to rid the app of boot errors), is also no fun.  It‚Äôs a good thing the campaign has basically been doubled in the Definitive Edition, and bots are still in.The Windows 10 restrictions simply do the development team a disservice. A lot of work went into Age of Empires: Definitive Edition and just enough tweaks were made to ensure that it‚Äôs still relevant in 2018. I have an incredible amount of respect for the folks who brought this classic back to life, and for their restraint to ensure that this remaster doesn‚Äôt abandon its roots. 8\10

[h1]Comentario Anal√≠tico: "Age of Empires: Definitive Edition"[/h1]

Para preparar el terreno para la llegada del tan anticipado Age of Empires IV el equipo de Microsoft encarg√≥ el desarrollo de 3 remasterizaciones de los cl√°sicos originales, partiendo por √©ste, el primero de todos.

Como juego es excelente, es el padre de los RTS, desafiante ya sea en Escaramuza (Solitario o con amigos) o en sus campa√±as, que esta vez incluye tanto a las originales como al contenido de The Rise of Rome. 

Como remasterizaci√≥n hace un trabajo brillante. Es visualmente bello, dota a los nuevos sprites de alta resoluci√≥n y animaciones fluidas, el escenario ahora est√° repleto de detallitos que aportan a la comodidad visual, los nuevos men√∫s contin√∫an siendo arcaicos pero relativamente c√≥modos, ahora es posible hacer zoom e incluso si no te gusta, pod√©s activar el modo Classic para jugar con el aspecto original.

Sin embargo hay algo que me molesta en lo que a visuales respecta, y es que esta remasterizaci√≥n pareciera haberse planteado para Age of Empires II. Luce muy similar a su secuela (Tanto a su versi√≥n cl√°sica como su remasterizaci√≥n), hace un excelente trabajo en adaptarse visualmente pero la mayor√≠a de sus decisiones est√©ticas no son muy fieles al aspecto original del primer Age of Empires.

Adem√°s hay algunos aspectos t√©cnicos y jugables que quedaron sin retocar, como la formaci√≥n de tropas (Seleccionar a un conjunto de tropas no las reune, cada unidad se mueve desde su respectivo lugar inicial, esto no ser√≠a para tanto si tan s√≥lo hubiera un modo de organizarlas en distintas formaciones como ocurre en Age of Empires II), campa√±as con un m√°ximo de poblaci√≥n en 50 sin importar la dificultad seleccionada, imposibilidad de seleccionar m√°s de un l√≠mite muy estricto de unidades al mismo tiempo y un p√©simo pathfinding para las unidades m√≥viles (No hay partida en que las unidades no tomen el camino incorrecto o no se queden atrapadas entre ellas).

En el Age of Empies original se pod√≠a perdonar, pero esta remasterizaci√≥n apenas mejora sus mayores carencias mec√°nicas.

[b]¬øEn conclusi√≥n?[/b] Vale la pena por la excelencia del material original, y en varios aspectos hace un decente trabajo como remasterizaci√≥n; sin embargo le queda mucho por retocar.

I like this game and I would perhaps recommend it to you, however it comes with it's fair share of caveats. It's not AOE2, it's an embryo that has many of the elements that would make it great, but I'll write below my biggest misgivings about it - you decide if you still want to get it based on that.

The unit path-finding is not the worst I've seen, but it's bad compared to AOE2. It can be very frustrating when you want to get units through a tight passage and half of them decide they'd rather take a journey around the map instead.

EDIT: The units also sometimes move on their own, returning to their previous position. This didn't happen often, but when it did it was very annoying.

Civilization tech trees seem to have a great amount of grey, that is: unavailable upgrades & units. To the point where it seems a poor civ choice could make your loss almost inevitable.

Speaking of the tech trees, it doesn't make it clear what units actually counter what. 

There's only one narrator for campaigns and I think no in-game voice acting (apart from unit voices). Not irredeemable, but it makes some campaign scenarios fall kinda flat for me, especially those where you start with a few military units and are supposed to make your way to some goal.

Campaign scenarios give you a pop limit of 50 (- this might be different in campaigns I haven't played yet), while the enemy often greatly outnumbers you. They also like their monks a bit too much and there is no Heresy tech. You are effectively forced into attrition fights where you slowly build your fortifications deeper and deeper into the enemy base until you win. The towers & walls are solid tho, unlike the Papier-m√¢ch√© shit that Empire Earth II has for example, so it's not too horrible but still it often seems unlikely to win some other way.

Takes me back in time to playing the original in the 1990s.  Game play is smooth, graphics are awesome.  Auto seeding farms is a cool plus.  Have not tried multiplayer, but campaigns and skirmishes against computer are great.

Oddly enough, this game is very strangely satisfying. I personally did not grow up with AOE but have been blessed with playing RTS that has been well-made from WC3. 

Although this game is aged, and the controls are a bit clunky it feels like I'm reading a short war novel upon completion of each campaign mission and the game itself is entertaining in its method of exploration. You are forced to scout and explore the map as opposed to many other RTS genre type of games of build base, army, and kill the opponent.  

The tutorial campaign was also very well made to allow any new player to learn how to play the game (arguably one of the best tutorials I've seen compared to most RTS games). 

It is a very simplified game without a bunch of stuff clouding your HUD and your screen. Easy to play and master.

This is a classic game. 

I spent many hours in my childhood building units and sending massive waves of troops to crush the AI. It's great to see that years later, it's just as fun as it was in my childhood. 

The different campaigns  are quite varied with some being quite hard and others being more relaxed. 
 
The game play is fun and easy to pick up. However you can learn the hotkeys or master the best unit types for your civilization to really raise the level of strategy in the game.  

The game also allows you to make your own scenarios and you can even string them together into your own custom campaign. A good bit of creativity in this game. 

I would be a monster if I also didn't mention the soundtrack. Something about it makes it an absolute ear worm.

I didn't enjoy Age of Empires 1 when I was a kid, maybe because I already had AoE2, but I wanted to give it another shot.
I thought I maybe judged it too harshly compared to AoE2, but trying it out again I felt as if I could see the flaws more clearly. There's simply a lot lacking in terms of strategy, civilizations and technology that makes the game a bit more of a slog. However, I think those are the same reasons why  a lot of people would like it, so it's a more subjective thing where for me it just lacks a certain polish and appeal.
As a remaster I think there is also a lot that could've been improved but wasn't. For example, the fact that so many civilizations still use the same voices seems strange and that would've generally been seen as an improvement if it had changed.

The original AOE is extremely nostalgic, so people that didn't grow up with it might not find it all that entertaining, but it is an absolute treasure from the golden age of RTS gaming. It is a different game from any of its successors, and it plays differently. If you're coming from AOE2 know this:

1. Maps will generally feel smaller
2. Resources will feel more scarce
3. Technologies will all seem more expensive
4. There will be a smaller variety of units
5. Civilization buffs are less elaborate

That being said, play the game with the time period in mind. The ages in the game go from the Stone Age, to the Tool Age, the Bronze Age, and finally the Iron Age. AOE1 takes place in the ancient world, where (1&2) the world was "smaller," (3&4) any technological advancements took a long time to develop, and (5) cultures and civilizations were just beginning to define themselves from each other and come into their own. If you play with all that in mind and you love RTS games, you will love AOE1. AOE1&2 are games that shaped a generation of RTS lovers.
This game is engaging and entertaining with plenty of replayability

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is a graphic overhaul, rather than a remake, of the 1997 classic RTS, featuring new graphics, modern animations and UI plus some quality of life improvements.

It features all the campaigns of the original plus the Rise of Rome expansion, and the Hittite campaign - although the scenarios of this one are different than the ones I used to play over and over as a kid on the demo from the Windows 98 CD-ROM!

However, if you have played the original game, you'll notice that it is essentially a new graphics engine put on top of the original code - so it also retains all the flaws of the original game like units constantly bumping into each other and bad path finding.

Still, I would definitely recommend it both for new and old players, especially on sale.

Age of Empires was an incredibly influential and important game, but it's also 22 years old. It really needs a remake, not a coat of paint. 

Balance is awful, with unique civilisation units being massively overpowered and spammed by the AI, often meaning entire armies are brought down by 2-3 War Elephants. Units aren't able to path around well, leading to frequent bottle necks and units going the long way around, usually into danger. The lack of stances means your units often just keep chasing and pushing until they are killed, so it's a lot of constant micro managing. 

The AI cheat, quite badly. They advance Age much faster than is humanly possible, and seem to build armies much faster than you can. They do very silly things like repeatedly try and build inside your space, next to your docks etc relentlessly, never stopping regardless of how many of their villagers you kill and builds you raze. They also just give up at a certain point, even if you're nowhere near beating them.

It was incredibly in its time, but in the modern age, the original Age of Empires just.. isn't very good.

First of all I want to clarify that I've had the original game since around 2001 when I first played it on my dad's then-dated Windows 95 *demo CD*. Yes, that version. I still love it, please don't get me wrong, it is the first game I ever played as a child and is responsible for my pursuit of a master's degree in history. However, some major criticisms HAVE to be lent to the DE version of this game, which I feel has not done well to clarify the concerns shared here also by other players elsewhere for the last 28 YEARS. 

So. The pathfinding in the DE of this game is absolutely pants on head. Many villagers will get caught up on each other and immediately stop their tracks so you have to move them manually. The auto-gather of villagers is particularly a pain in this game as well, since they'll sometimes traverse to the other side of the island (during Island map games) just to cut a tree down. The organization of AOE1 whether it's Classic or DE, was never much my style. Obviously after playing massive hours in AOE2 it can be hard to remember the less convenient methods to which research is conducted through which buildings. Why towers and walls are researchable at a Granary is beyond me, and the villager-centric aspects of the Town Center from AOE2 are sorely missed since you have to construct a market just to research how to gather resources faster, and can only build a Government Center in the Bronze Age. It's a clunkier, less enthusiastic Age of Empires than the one I remember playing as a child. AOE2 soars above this game in every single aspect. The AI is beyond a chore to trifle with-- even on easiest difficulty they will manage to build twice as fast as you and outmanouvre your navy to a point where it's useless to build Fishing Ships because they'll already have Triremes countering to destroy them, and will easily send transport ships to your island when you least expect it. Infantry seems very slow to react to cavalry. I think that overall the micro of this game versus what AOE2 created for the community is a joke by comparison. It's impossible not to put the two together for the review as they are both legendary games everyone with a computer knows about.  I think AOE2 serves as a reminder that AOE1 was just the start of something bigger. I'm sure many stans will disagree with me, but I'm just not a fan of this version of the game, and often resort to playing Classic 1997 in all matches, at best. It's hard to make this game work well on this engine, so I can't personally recommend it, even though it was the first video game I had ever played in my life, and holds a special place in my heart. A mixed, confused, but special place in my heart that is.

Age of Empires Definitive Edition does a nice job of updating the graphics of the original version, incorporating the expansion packs for the original game, and providing the means to link the game to your Xbox Live Account. I also like the addition of queuing up unit training and research that was missing from the original version.

However, the skirmish mode isn't really enjoyable, the game has random crashes when least expected, and having a loophole that lets cheat codes help easily unlock achievements. It's a decent remake, but it does have some faults.

I felt nostalgic going through all the the missions, and skirmish as well... sadly i didn't find almost anyone
to play this game in MP, but the solo experience was just fine to me...

Pros:[list]
[*] Game is basically same as the original, with better graphics, and remastered music to be 
as close to original as it can be.
[*] You can switch between remastered graphics and original graphics which is a big LIKE!
[*] AI is slightly improved,
[*] They've put a voice over the description before and after each mission,
[*] Skirmish![/list]

Cons:[list]
[*] Sometimes AI gets glitchy, it's rarely nowadays, but still happens,
[*] Too bad they didn't remade or remaster the intro video from original release
[*] The population in campaigns could've been raised above 50 units, but i guess it would
lose the original feeling of the game, might not be challenging as it was in original
[*] MP is basically dead if you're trying to play online with someone because i don't see that much people playing it online
[/list]
Apart from all the pros and cons i give this game a score of:
[h3]8/10[/h3]

I consider it's wrong to criticize a game that's 25 years old, even if it's a remaster. I'll just recommend it to hardcore strategy fans and ardent fans of the Age of Empires series, especially those for whom the first part was a part of their childhood, not the second one.

Pros:
- An interesting setting of ancient world civilizations. I think many people enjoyed the history of those times in school. Each mission in the campaigns has a detailed historical description. And then you actually participate in these events. Nice :)
- It's just interesting to see where the series began and what the second part adopted (or didn't).
- And, looking at screenshots from the 1997 game, you understand how well they have redrawn everything with respect to the original.
- The soundtrack. Orchestral music is always good.
- Well, the Priests seemed more effective to me than in the second part :D

Cons:
- Pathfinding and getting units stuck in each other. Of course, you get used to it.
- Many civilizations don't have their own campaigns. So, you can only play with them against AI or online, which might not be interesting. Perhaps consider buying the DLC The RoR for the second part and maybe, someday you'll get them.
- A unique economic system. After it, you better understand the economy of the second part :)

Overall, the game isn't bad. It's a good remaster. But it's best to start playing it strictly after you've played the second part of the series.

As much as I love AoE, this remaster suffers from the same problems as the original.

Cons:

‚Ä¢ No grouping/formation options.
‚Ä¢ When commanded to attack, units more often than not, will walk past the enemies.

Pros:

‚Ä¢ Cool unit and building models (Legion)
‚Ä¢ Cool art style and destruction effects.
‚Ä¢ Multiplayer, like any other AoE is fun.

I missed out on the original and had heard good things about it, so thought I would give the Definitive Edition a try.  It's a classic city builder/RTS, where you have to gather resources, build villages/towns/cities and create armies to defend them and overcome your foes.  Each scenario is introduced with some information that places it in its historical context, which is interesting if you're a history buff, like me.

The remaster is very well done, and makes this classic playable on modern hardware.  The only thing that's frustrating is that the pathfinding is off for units, and it's often difficult making them go where you want them to!  The AI can also be punishingly unfair, especially on the higher difficulty levels.

"During my high school years. I saw a trailer from Microsoft about a remastered version of the Age of Empires game. I ended up having to wait to try out the remaster due to not having a Windows 10 pc and the pc I had before which ran on Vista at the time couldn‚Äôt upgrade to Windows 10. The wait was well worth it and I got the game when it was released on Steam. While I wasn‚Äôt too familiar with what a remaster was. I looked at it and it blew me away. From playing the original Age of Empires for almost a decade. The graphical upgrades were quite insane. While I never cared much for graphical fidelity. It was cool how they upped the fidelity to 11 but kept it very faithful. Even more faithful to the point that the remaster uses the same Genie engine used for the original game. Another thing they did that made the game sound pretty interesting was that they changed the music from MIDI Sounds too real orchestral music using actual instruments. One thing that was added was a narrator for the campaigns.

          There were some things that were included in the remaster that are optional like turning on blood. Even though the original game doesn‚Äôt have blood. I did enable it and tried it for an hour. I Didn‚Äôt notice it and decided to disable it.

I never had the experience to play online multiplayer, let alone I never knew how to use MSN Gaming Zone around the time when it was still around when playing the original. I noticed the game would use the Xbox Live service for the multiplayer but good thing I realized I didn‚Äôt have to pay for it since I was on PC.

When I first entered a multiplayer Duel. I decided to message the enemy player by saying I was new to RTS Multiplayer. From years of experience playing by myself in the campaigns or random maps. I noticed the enemy player would use houses in place of walls. He did end up building a wonder, but I went on the other side of the map to send a bunch of Centurions to easily destroy the wonder. Only one was left remaining and I took out the wonder before the other player could cry out for victory. I decided to defend myself, I walled myself in but only left the other 2 sides open. Near the walls would have Babylonian towers and monks. While gaining more resources in the process. I was able to build a wonder. I successfully defended myself from incoming attacks and turned enemy catapults into my own using the monks. I angered the other player, and he sent out a message saying I lied and surrendered. I gained a victory, but it was a lucky one that lasted for two hours. I did end up replaying the campaigns I had finished all those years ago. Most of them were the same with some of the campaign titles different. I did like how they added the Age of Empires Demo campaign which wasn‚Äôt in the original release. While knowing everything and how to beat the game. I ended up having an Achievement completion in under four months of playing the game."

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is recommended if you are a big fan of the earlier games and want to relive them or if you are new to AoE then it is best to start with the definitive editions to get the best out of the experience .

Inside, this is still the same Age of Empires as you might remember it.
You walk across the screen with the same characters, look for the same raw materials and have the same missions in mind.
However, it all looks much better. The game has had a complete remake. This is not a polished version with a higher resolution, but the game has been completely redesigned and is playable in 4K.
With new graphics, textures, light effects, water effects and details, the game looks like a modern game.

The soundtrack also received a massive overhaul in the Definitive Edition.
Instead of the original MIDI, an orchestra is now responsible for the music in the game.
Many of the songs contain the same characteristics as in the original game, while I also got the impression that there are new melodies.

in its entirety, this is certainly a remaster of an outdated game. The original game is getting close to being 30 years old and yet it's still worth watching.
The game looks more beautiful than ever before and the new music gives the games its own identity while keeping its distinctive character.
If you loved the original Age of Empires, the Definitive Edition is definitely worth checking out. But in the end it remains the same good old Age of Empires, as we have known it for years.

Pros: Nostalgia and based on a different time period with unique civilizations and campaigns in addition to improved graphics. Some people might enjoy the skirmishes/custom scenarios.

Cons: Abandoned by Microsoft apparently with no dlc, complaints about issues with multiplayer not working properly, villagers (AI villagers I think should not be attacking priests when trying to convert them regardless of difficulty settings), and probably has less people on multiplayer than the other three games from this series, except for RoR (Return to Rome) dlc.

Neutral: Pathfinding, but this a problem for the entire Age of Empires series in general especially for I and II being the most noticeable. It could be argued that RoR dlc from AoE II: DE is better, but debatable and while it might be underrated it also has much lower Steam ratings currently than this game. Some people however might enjoy playing with both games.

Conclusion: Might be more practical for single player than multiplayer and maybe not as good as the other three games from this series especially with AoE IV now confirmed to have its first dlc come out, but I would recommend this game for at least casual gameplay. I would overall rate this game with a 6 out of 10.

‚ùå There has been little to no gameplay updates as compared to the original. While I understand why they wouldn't want to do a complete remaster and instead clung close to the original, the gameplay was already getting old when Age of Empires 2 released in 1999. I mean, there have been so many RTS games released since then that you are bound to feel how unwieldy this whole thing is.

I think that for any people who don't have a lot of nostalgia for the original game, trying to get into this one is a bit of a waste of time. The gameplay is clunky, the narration of the campaigns is conveyed in a bit of a boring way, and overall if you want a real time strategy game Age of Empires 2 just does everything better - even though it's not taking place in the same time period, sure.

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is rather fun for quite a while, however, like most Age of Empires games, it struggles to keep me interested more than 25 or 30 minutes each time I play. This does not mean it is a bad game, merely a game I wouldn't invest a lot of time or money on. If you are a fan of strategy and action games alone or with friends, then this is a good choice, or if you just like historical warfare games.

Age of Empires is a timeless masterpiece that has managed to capture the same exhilarating thrill it did back in the days. As I dove into the game once more, I was instantly transported back to a world of strategy and conquest, where empires rise and fall with every calculated move.

The upgrades in this latest iteration are nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail is astounding, making every unit and building a true work of art. Watching my civilizations evolve and grow under my guidance is a visual delight that never gets old. The sheer depth and complexity of the game's mechanics keep me engaged for hours on end, constantly strategizing and adapting to the changing tides of history.

One of the most brilliant features is the option to experience the game in its original pixelated glory from the 90s. This ingenious addition allows us to appreciate just how far the game has come visually, and it's a nostalgic journey that tugs at the heartstrings of long-time fans. It's like revisiting an old friend and being amazed at how they've transformed over the years.

Age of Empires is more than just a game; it's a pure recollection of gaming greatness. The blend of nostalgia and innovation is a testament to its enduring appeal. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game promises an unforgettable experience that will have you hooked from the very first moment. So gather your forces, shape your destiny, and prepare to conquer the ages once again. Enjoy the ride ‚Äì it's an epic adventure like no other.

Aaaall right. So, let me start off by saying that I have a lot of love for this game. It's what got me interested in history and I have it to thank for a lot of fond memories. As while other kids my age were playing your typical kiddie games, I was dominating the ancient world.

HOWEVER...

Those times were also filled with a bit of frustration that my poor 6 year old mind probably couldn't comprehend or really even retain in my wee memory... and now over 20 years later, I'm being reminded of these issues.

So lets get the good out of the way first. 
This is a trip down nostalgia lane through and through. The updated graphics and soundtrack is amazing, the new campaign presentation is in line with what you'd expect from Age of Empires 2. In terms of overall presentation, I couldn't have asked for better. 
In regards to ease of use, there are plenty of improvements. Units can have stances now (I forget if that was in the original or not, but I feel like it wasn't), there's hotkey support and the UI has been updated to convey much more information, once more, in line with Age of Empires 2, a few of these features probably being the beta forms of some of the features added in Age of Empires 2: Definitive Edition. 

However, this is where the positives stop, and I'd even say some of those positives are even countered by a few points I'm going to make here.

From what I've experienced, stances don't work over half the time. Heaven forbid that if I put my swordsmen on defensive formation so they don't go chasing some archer half way across the map that they begin to ignore my commands. (Btw, there's no formations in this version either). For some reason units will just outright forget their commands and return to their starting position, ignoring all other enemies in their paths. Which brings me to pathing...

It's improved a little bit but for the most part you will still experience villager congestion, most often when several are trying to drop off resources - though this doesn't happen with farms due to the way you've gotta place them. If they get congested to long they will just forget what they were doing and stand around. Or sometimes they'll just pull a Swordsman and stop working all together for no apparent reason.

The worst part of it all, I'm pretty sure this game's support was dead on arrival. These are bugs that have existed since launch, if not decades back when the original came out. And if wee 6 year old me didn't actually experience them back then, then these are -new- bugs. Which shouldn't happen to a remaster of a game more than two decades old...

UnlessyoureWarcraftIIIReforged *cough*

So all in all, if you are really a sucker for nostalgia, wait for a sale, otherwise, it's not exactly worth it. Just stick to Age of Empires 2: Definitive Edition which is by far the superior remaster from the original Age of Empires trilogy.

EDIT, 7/21/2023: And now with the release of Return of Rome for Age of Empires 2 Definitive Edition, there is  ZERO purpose to come back and play this.

[h1][i]-Overview-[/i][/h1]
 Age of Empires: Defenition Edition is the remastered version of the classic 1997 strategy. With improved visuals, new campaigns, and more civilizations (civs). Age of Empires is different from what many players remember Wololo!

[h3]‚úîPros:[/h3]
+ Campaigns:
 -> The game has a good amount of campaigns. The classics are all there and the game had some addictions. All of the stories are good and well adapted to the game.

 + Strangely Good Gameplay:
 -> It's possible to divide the Age Of Empires gameplay into two types. The complex, using a good amount of key binds to be faster building and play with the meta. Or the simple, that is more calm don't follow the meta that much.

 + Visuals Improvement:
 -> From the 1997 edition, it's possible to see great improvements in the visuals. As an old player, I couldn't ask much more

 [h3]‚ùåCons:[/h3]
- Military Control:
-> I could report a bunch of different problems into the military control. While controlling big armies, some units end up rushing into others, not letting any pass by them. Other times I could report that units from the army weren't going to the place designed.

- Constant FPS drops:
 -> I could find a very fun issue in the game. Every single time that I zoomed I would have an fps drop. Or if I moved my camera fast it would also happen a drop

[h1][i]-Going Deeper-[/i][/h1]
[h3]Rating: 73/100[/h3]

[h3]üìúStory[/h3]
  Age Of Empires is not a story-centric game. However, it still contains a series of campaigns that tell the great deeds of some civilizations of the past, such as Romans, Egyptians, and Greeks. There are no cinematic cutscenes or anything like that and is more as if we had to hear a chronicle of the events in which we play. 

 The stories are well told and adapted to the game. I don't see the campaigns as a thing that will make the players buy the game. They are good but don't something important to the gameplay. I was a bit sad for don't see the remastered version from the original Age of Empires: Defenition Edition cutscenes, or any new. I think that they were a master key to make the game more catchy. However, I don't dislike the chronicle idea.

[h3]üïπGameplay[/h3]
 At first glance, all civilizations will look a little the same, since the only things that seem to change from civ to civ are the special troops, the design of their buildings, and their buffs. However, the game has a whole meta of what to do. For example, on a map with lots of hills, a civ with archer buffs is the best choice. It's all about choosing the best strategy and adapting to your opponent's game. 

 I've played a lot of Age Of Empires II: Defenition Edition, and what I'm going to write here is more centralized for AoE II players, that want to go back to the beginning of the franchise. Age of Empires and Age of Empires II is not the same thing. The first game is more complex than AoE 2 at all levels. I'm not going to say it's a 7-headed monster impossible to play, but players who have already gotten used to the gameplay from AoE 2, can shake a little with the difference.

 At the level of control in combat, I must say that sometimes it becomes a bit complicated.  While controlling big armies, some units end up rushing into others, not letting any pass by them. Other times I could see that units from the army weren't going to the place designed.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2298193907
[h3]üìΩAudio & Visuals[/h3]
 Visually is impossible to don't see great improvements from the 1997 version. The game still gives the possibility to the player to use the 1997 graphics version. I enjoyed a lot have the opportunity to see and compare the two games.

 In terms of audio, the sound of the game is good. The song is more of the same, however, gets less annoying than that of the 1997 version without a doubt. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2298242811

[h1]Technical Details[/h1]

Intel Core i7-8750H; NVIDIA Geforce GTX 1660 Ti; 16,00 GB Ram

 - I played mostly at 60 fps, however, I got many fps drops while zooming or moving the camera fast.

Get the game while it's on sale, it isn't bad but after 15 hours it starts to get on your nerves and begins to feel frustrating. Even on Easy, some missions feel outright impossible (first mission of the Glory of Greece campaign, I'm looking at you!), the key here seems to be to take out your enemies quickly otherwise, if they progress too much in their technology, it becomes a long and booooring war of attrition. Especially when they start building stone throwers. Not to mention some scenarios should have a bigger population limit (most have a limit of 50 units), like 75 or 80 or something. The maps are pretty accurate and the game sometimes feels like an introductory history class, but it isn't 100% accurate. If you're having trouble, cheat codes are available (just Google them), but I do not see "God mode" among them. E R E C T U S!

Saying not recommended feels harsh,  it is important to provide an honest assessment of a game.
Age of Empires holds a special place in the hearts of many gamers, and for those who have a deep nostalgic connection to the franchise, the game can still provide a certain level of enjoyment despite its flaws.

For players who fondly remember the classic Age of Empires games, this installment offers a familiar experience that harkens back to the series' roots. The historical setting, strategic depth, and the satisfaction of building and commanding civilizations remain intact. Engaging in large-scale battles, constructing intricate cities, and witnessing the rise and fall of empires can evoke a sense of nostalgia and recapture some of the magic that made the series so beloved.

However, it is important to acknowledge that Age of Empires may not meet the expectations of players accustomed to the advancements seen in modern strategy games. The graphics and overall visual presentation may feel dated, lacking the level of detail and realism found in newer titles. Additionally, certain gameplay mechanics and features may show signs of aging, potentially feeling less refined or innovative when compared to contemporary strategy games.

Despite these shortcomings, the undeniable charm of Age of Empires can still draw players in. Its historical authenticity, engaging campaigns, and the joy of watching your civilization flourish can provide a satisfying and nostalgic experience. If you approach the game with an appreciation for its legacy and the knowledge that it may not match the technical prowess of newer titles, you can still find enjoyment in reliving the classic Age of Empires experience.

In summary, while Age of Empires may not be able to fully meet the expectations set by modern strategy games, it has its own unique appeal for those with a strong nostalgia for the franchise. If you can embrace the game's limitations and appreciate it for what it represents‚Äîa testament to the series' legacy‚Äîyou can still find enjoyment in revisiting the world of Age of Empires.

Oh, what am I saying, of course you don't. - Mesannepada's thoughts on Age of Empires.

The myth, the legend! The game that started it all. The world would be a much different place if AOE had never come around: For one, I would be able to find a job.

The Definitive Edition delivers the experience of playing a 90s RTS right to your doorstep, and it's everything you'd expect. Because, apart from upscaling and redrawing and adding sweet voiceover to the game's campaigns, they did nothing to actualize the game's shortcomings and bring it into the XXI century.

Now, I am not advocating for a complete rework of the game's mechanics. I understand this is entirely a different game from AOE2. But whereas some of these quirks had a place in the game and differentiated it from subsequent staples of the genre, some others were just hardware and software limitations in their own time, which even then made the game feel clumsy and slow. But instead of rounding out those sharp edges this time around, Microsoft chose to leave them the way they were.

The result is an upscaled game that plays extremely slow, requires a lot of patience, and might not work well most of the time. Pathing is still appalling, triggers will not, erm, trigger, and there are still tremendous balance issues. 

I would be more forgiving of Microsoft's treatment of this edition if it had been done for the sake of preserving the gaming experience of the original game for future players. But the fact that they've been quite willing to completely overhaul, modify and update everything in AOE2 (for which I am thankful) tells me that their decision to keep AOE's many quirks and shortcomings is less motivated by the preservation of gaming culture, and more by the need to make a quick and easy buck.

It's a shame, because the excitement and wonder of the original game are still there. I was very much looking forward to experiencing this in an updated setting and with improved mechanics and programming. But, as it is, the game is almost unplayable by modern standards.

Classic RTS with an interesting story line and quality graphics. This game combines building with resource management and real time battles. You can tell this came from the Golden Age of PC gaming because it does not have (or need) online co-play or loot box (pay to play) items to be fun, Occasionally a character gets a bit confused and need to be re-directed where you want them to go. The only thing I feel is missing is the ability to build gates and doorways into city walls. Also would be nice if you could set commands to your fighters to protect and follow a particular person. However, I found this game to be fun and highly replay-able.
Cheap low effort payday on an old good ip. Don't buy

After the Return of Rome DLC for AOE2 there is really no reason to buy this anymore. Providing all these old campaigns get ported over in future updates there isn't a single thing AOE1 dose better than the Return of Rome DLC.

I remember playing the original, which I really liked, and now this game is visually more appealing. The textures, models, and animations have been improved, creating a visually stunning experience that runs smoothly at 1440p and 144 fps. The remastered sound effects and soundtrack add immersion, making the game feel like a modern strategy gem.

In addition to the visual changes, the game has received technical improvements. Mod support is now included directly in the game, making it easier to install new mods. The multiplayer mode has been revamped and includes cross-network play and a built-in server browser. There have also been improvements in artificial intelligence and difficulty, with an extreme difficulty mode that will challenge experienced players.

The Definitive Edition also adds new content, such as new maps, game modes, and additional civilizations. These civilizations offer unique play styles that add variety and keep things interesting. The core of the game, combining combat and resource management, remains solid, and the campaigns offer an exciting variety of missions.

In summary, Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition is highly recommended. With its impressive visual improvements, enhanced user interface, improved artificial intelligence, and interesting content additions, this edition is the ultimate way to enjoy the classic strategy game.

I would give up fucking your mom every night if it meant i could play this!

This game is no longer supported, for AOE I DE you should buy AOE II DE and the AOE I DE DLC; but don't hold your breath, because this will probably change in a year when they ask for another 30 dollars for the AOE DE collection.

I'm going to tally up my AoE purchases here. AOE DE on from the MIcrosoft store (which didn't work at all), AOE DE on Steam (which kind of works), AOE II on steam, and AOE II DE. I purchased AOE III (non DE) but refunded it because it was too buggy to play.

If you purchased this game then you were misled and played by Microsoft, and you should be upset. This game is a buggy mess. Campaign maps that stall and prevent the player from finishing the campaign indefinitely. Miserably poor pathing that gets units stuck all over the place. Units will bug out and cease attacking until they die or the match ends. It's a pile of poo. 

With all of these frequent issues that can easily be replicated, this game has been abandoned. Alright, pretty frustrating, but not the end of the world, right? Well, this game is now being resold as a DLC for Age of Empires II DE with full support and planned content updates. 

In other words, this game should be completely removed from existence, but here it sits in a buggy mess for suckers to get conned into buying because Microshaft is objectively greedy. This was a deliberate maneuver to confuse consumers, or a massive blunder that should leave even die hard fans cursing this studio.

We should have seen AOE DE - pulled from the store. AOE II DE replaced by a title like "AOE collection", because in it's current state AOE II DE is two different games. AOE DE, as it exists independently of AOE II DE, should then be compensated to anyone who owns the currently abandoned AOE DE. Problem solved. If you ask me, they shot themselves in the foot with this one. There is no way I spend another dime on AOE. I know there are die hard fans that will continue to buy DLC for these games anyways, but this studio is milking their consumers by selling content they plan to abandon.

get the Rome DLC for Age II Definitive and enjoy Age 1 + more Content + More QOL Features in a superior Game. 

Literally 0 Reason to play this title.





[h1] I do recommend it on Sale[/h1]

If you are looking for Age of Empires I remastered, then by all means, by it fullprice. You won't be disappointed.

If you played Age of Empires II or Definitive and you are searching for "more" or "the roots" then by all means, try it on Sale for 5‚Ç¨ because everything besides the nations themselves is either a downgrade of Age 2, or a clearly tested IDEA for something that has not been refined properly.

In Essence this is game is considarebly slower whilst also being faster than Age II, with fighting and teching happening faster and more consistent whilst everything moves and acts on a snails pace. 
If you think that it can't be [b] [i] that [/i] [/b]slow, then look at a villager building a building with only 5 hammer strikes, because it takes him so long to lift his arm with that puny hammer in hand that you can feel yourself physically age.

It is a nice intermission to playing the second title and definitely has its place but Age 2 is the best sequel one can hope for and whilst pikemen, Hoplites and Chariots sound cool, they feel really weird and uncanny to use and while there are Rome, Carthage and Egypt, they are so similar in feel and tech tree, that they might as well be one faction.

This was a good remaster - the Definitive Edition for Age of Empires 1; however, I am not a fan of the first game and even though the modernization efforts are spectacular, I don't have much interest in AoE 1. I got this included with my purchase of Age of Empires 2 Definitive Edition. My POV is AoE 2 is superior. If I had the choice I would skip and not purchase this title unless I was getting it included in a combo pack like I did.

I will say that those that worked on the modernization and remastering of this game did an awesome job. I did not have any significant problems playing. Those improvements definitely make this really old game bearable on new systems.

So, for my own personal tastes' sake, I do not recommend this game -- but, this is the definitive edition for those that have an interest or passion for the first AoE game.

just get Aoe2 definitive with Return of Rome dlc that adds this game at basically half the cost. It is a better game with way more content and gets new updates all the time.

Originally, the main difference was that the aoe2 dlc wasn't going to have the old campaigns, but they are now planing to add them. The dlc already had exclusive content such as new campaigns and a whole new civ. I haven't tried the dlc yet cuz I can't bring myself to pay for this game twice, but i do own aoe2 and I know the game mechanics are so much better that its not even really comparable to this game. aoe2 is their baby, and it gets all the attention, so its defiantly the best long term investment.

They have added a new DLC of this whole game into AOE 2 DE under the name "Return of Rome" for 15 Euros, where they added even new campaigns, and other improvements such as gates and different QoL upgrades, thus all of us who spent money on AOE 1 DE did so in vain. I know someone will tell me how I got to play the game before this DLC was created, but I didn't, I just bought it to play it later, and now my money is wasted. Now it's pointless to buy AOE 1 DE with this new DLC for AOE 2. Forgotten empires has some very strange ideas where they incorporate an older title completely into the new one and they still keep it on sale for no apparent reason. All they needed to do was to upgrade this title AOE 1 and create a DLC for it instead of porting it completely into AOE 2, but they didn't...
Played it for pure nostalgia and was not disappointed. it's a bit of shame it's frozen in time in terms of historical accuracy but it's the AOE I loved and remember.
fun game

With Age of Empires 2 DE getting Return to Rome, and them opting to put campaigns from Age 1 into that, Microsoft should just port everything over and delist this. Its been a bajillion years and the pathing is still bad, they haven't done anything to it, and its a miracle Microsoft managed to greenlight AoE2DE with how terrible this game STILL is.

Nothing definitive here - nothing done to distinctly define this from the original. Just an overpriced graphics mod. With more bugs to add extra value for you.
Still same bugs and issues as original AOE.
Path finding still has the same issues but now even worse when moving through narrow streets, melee infantry blobbing and running around each other.
AI has not been improved. Sometimes likes to collect resources from across the map, making them weak.
They could've added gates and formations but did not.
They could've added some new content instead just the original AOE content.
The retro graphics option is bugged - the textures on the shoreline are incorrect and look terrible ruining this graphics mode.
If you have the original CD then there is nothing to buy this for unless you need the graphics mod.
It is misleading on the store page when it says modernized gameplay - there is no massive change (best and biggest change is farms not solid option and auto reseed). They are also lying when they say it brings together all the officially released content. There are some scenarios which were very enjoyable but are not included. Some campaign missions have been cut too.
They have also removed the opening cinematic.

Edit: Buy the Rise of Rome DLC for AoE2DE. Currently it lacks all the campaigns of AoE1 (it only has 3), but it is much, much more enjoyable to play than AoE1DE.

I bought this impulsively because of nostalgia, which was a mistake. To me, the gameplay is too old at this point (well, duh), so I just get bored of it mid match. Also I appreciate that they remade the sound effects, but I wish there were an option to use the old ones, I wanted to hear that good 'ol lowres ERECTUS and HOONENENES, but it just sounds too good now.
Other than my stupid opinions, this seems cool tho, if you're into playing a very slow paced rts. It looks nice, plays nice, sounds nice. For 20bucks it's not worth it imo, especially since the new AoE2 DE is at the same price, but the game is on Xbox gamepass, so you can try it out there without paying for it. [b]PROS:[/b] 
+ 10 fun campaigns (61 missions)
+ now it looks the way many remember it
+ great soundtrack
+ a couple of QoL improvements

[b]CONS:[/b]
- borderline broken multiplayer
- crashes & glitches
- bad unit pathing
- old intro is gone

[b]Comment:[/b]
An integral part of my gaming childhood and one of the three games that got me into PC gaming (the other two are Deus Ex and LoK: Soul Reaver btw). I still have fond memories of trying to crack the missions and find the best strategy with my best buddy. Some of these have been changed in the Definitive Edition but I didn't mind the new versions. There are four base game campaigns (Ascent of Egypt, Glory of Greece, Voices of Babylon, Yamato Empire of the Rising Sun) + the originally unused demo Reign of the Hittites. Then the four expansion campaigns (Rise of Rome, Ave Caesar, Imperium Romana, Enemies of Rome) + the originally unused demo First Punic War. They are enjoyable for what they are to new players and a nostalgia trip for the old ones like me. And now the bad. Campaign saves wipe sometimes due to Steam cloud issue. I had to run the "home run" cheat to get back to the progress I was at FIVE TIMES! And it sucks to have to do that. AI was changed a bit and this is the most noticeable in the first mission of the Babylon campaign (Holy Man) where your priest gets swarmed by villagers or soldiers. While it makes sense the AI would do that the mission hasn't been designed for this so it seems unbalanced now. Also, sudden resigning is a thing now, it was okay for me but some will hate it. What an absolute mess the network part of the game is. GameSpy Arcade is of course gone so hello Xbox Live integration. There are official servers although they are somewhat region oriented and sometimes you have lag or just don't see any matches. Even LAN had problems when I tried to play with my wife. Setup crashed all the time. Matches desynced. And on one PC it even crashed my GPU driver. The 1997 version had a better multiplayer experience than this. With a VERY heavy heart I have to go and not recommend this one. Apart from the better visuals and a couple of QoL stuff it just doesn't feel like a proper remaster. There are too many problems just left unfixed. [strike]Plus once AoE2:DE gets the Return of Rome DLC, which has all of these campaigns, there really is no point of buying this game.[/strike] /EDIT: Devs have backtracked on this and the 10 original AoE1 campaigns will NOT be in that AoE2 DLC./ Get the game on a good sale for those campaigns, if nostalgia grips you, but otherwise it's not recommended. It hurts the soul to write that but it is what it is...
------------------------------------------------------------------

Age of Empires. A name that these days is well known, and this is the game that started it all, or rather, an updated version of it. While my introduction to the franchise was the all-time classic that is Age of Empires II, I did play a bit of this one during my childhood, if only as a demo for the Rise of Rome expansion. During my teenage years, I finally got a copy of the base game, and even though I played a bit, it never quite grabbed me like AoE II. Still, I'd say it's an obviously important part of history.

For those familiar with Age of Empires II, many of the gameplay elements found in that game are already present here; gathering resources, building armies, developing technologies, and advancing through eras, but this game focuses on empires from ancient history, going from the Stone Age, all the way up to the Iron Age. Given its age, though, it had certain limitations that are obviously present in the historical campaigns; you don't get complex scenarios with different triggers and dialogue, instead getting a narration before starting the scenario and after finishing it. Population is also capped at 50. Luckily, for custom games, this limit has been increased to at least 250 (though I've seen some custom scenarios with up to a 500 population cap).

Graphically speaking, the Definitive Edition looks nice. Nothing too advanced, merely a modernization of the classic graphics (which you can still use if you want), so that it looks better on modern system. The sound seems to have been improved as well, and I think there might've been a few gameplay improvements. It also includes a scenario editor, a staple of the Age of Empires franchise, so you can create your custom maps and campaigns. And the cheat codes from the classic version of the game work here as well!

All in all, I can say I recommend this game for people who want to experience a bit of history (pun intended), but it hasn't aged very well. Going back to talking about the campaigns, some scenarios require some rather precise strategies to beat them; they don't feel very noob friendly, so play it with caution.
Don't buy this game, wait for the DLC to be released for AOE2:DE Return of Rome.

I have deep nostalgia for this game and while I agree with the comments complaining about the AI, there are still lots of ways to enjoy yourself, you only need adjust the settings and challenge yourself. For example -- set up a Single Player Game against 5 AI all on different teams. Set a population limit of 25. Starting age NOMAD. Now up the ante and make it so you're only allowed one type of combative unit. Now try it without any combative units - towers only. I spend hours playing like this.

Nice graphics upgrade. The animations for buildings collapsing are very satisfying. They also added some new campaigns and factions, like the Romans. Will hit you right in the nostalgias. They added an attack move command, only whether your units actually attack enemies along the way is very hit-or-miss.

Everything else is the same (for worse) or just worse. The soundtrack is a watered-down version of the original, albeit with realistic-sounding instruments. The path-finding is still atrocious, and there's really no excuse for that in the current year. Sometimes, if you order a spread-out of group units to a location, the centroid of the group will move to that location while the units maintain their position relative to each other, rather than all units converging on that location like you wanted. Often, this leads to units going the opposite direction of where you just clicked and wandering off into enemy fire. Moving units across the map takes an unnecessary amount of micro. Trying to get units onto a transport ship is like herding cats. Priests still have infinite lock-on. They added a new unit to the barracks, which makes it more annoying that they couldn't have incorporated gates like in AoE2. The game offers the option to play on "classic mode," with the original graphics and music. Only, I'm old enough to remember that the graphics on my Windows 98 machine weren't THAT terrible. It would be nice if you could play the original soundtrack with the upgraded graphics, like StarCraft 2. As a matter of fact, Microsoft should just sell the rights to Blizzard, a company that actually knows how to make RTS games.

Hey everyone! If you're a fan of real-time strategy games, Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is a must-play. This game is a classic that's been remastered with updated graphics and gameplay mechanics.

What I love most about Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is how immersive and challenging the gameplay is. The game allows you to build and manage your own civilization, and you must use your resources wisely to expand your empire and conquer your enemies.

The game also features a wide variety of civilizations, each with its unique strengths and weaknesses. This makes the game feel fresh and exciting, even after multiple playthroughs.

Overall, if you're looking for a classic real-time strategy game that's been remastered for modern audiences, Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is definitely worth checking out. It's a game that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

Before this Definitive Edition, I had never played the original Age of Empires, only the later games, and I'm thinking that was a good thing. Age of Empires I is a rough experience. The gameplay is nowhere near as polished as it is in AoE II, the AI is really poor, there's a lot of quirks that just don't make a lot of sense (why is there an option to make farms unwalkable?), and the campaigns [i]feel[/i] like they were written and voiced in 1997 (which they obviously were, but my point is that AoE II was way ahead of its time by comparison).

What's more obvious is how little Microsoft, Forgotten Empires, and Xbox Game Studios cared about this Definitive Edition. The main menu UI is disgusting, and the game has had very little post-launch support to fix some of its remaining bugs and issues. AoE I DE released in August 2019, and as of this review the last update was in April 2021, nearly [i]two years ago[/i]. Meanwhile, AoE III was updated two [i]months[/i] ago, AoE IV was updated two [i]weeks[/i] ago, and AoE II was updated [i]last week[/i]. While I don't personally enjoy AoE I, I don't think it's so bad that it deserves such little attention.

In the end, I can't recommend AoE I DE, either to veterans or to newcomers. You'll only find value here if you really enjoyed the original AoE I.

I love most aspects of the Definitive Edition of Age of Empires. However, two things that really bugged me were the new voice over sounds of units, the new fighting sounds, and the new voice over reading of text before the campaign scenarios. The new voice over readings during the campaigns sound really cheesy... especially with that fake accent. A few of the new voice overs are annoying and kill some of the enjoyment of the game. The old voice over sounds for units in the original release of Age of Empires are much better, in my opinion. Also, the old voice overs would bring nostalgia and familiarity for players. 

If developers could add old voice over sounds and old fighting sounds that would be great. Maybe a toggle within the menus to switch between "Classic sounds" and "Definitive Edition sounds." Also a toggle to disable the new voice over reading of the text before each campaign scenario. It's bad. 

Would I recommend this game?

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is an exceptional game that has proven to be a timeless classic. As an ardent fan of the original game, I was thrilled to see the updated graphics and enhanced gameplay that this version offers. The game offers an immersive experience that allows players to create and develop their own civilizations, explore new territories, and engage in epic battles.

What truly sets this game apart is its attention to detail, which is nothing short of remarkable. Each civilization has its own unique strengths and weaknesses, as well as an intriguing backstory that players can delve into. From the Egyptians to the Greeks and the Babylonians, the civilizations are all rich in history and offer an unparalleled level of depth and complexity.

One of the standout features of Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is its ease of play. The intuitive controls and user-friendly interface make it accessible to players of all levels of experience, whether you are a seasoned veteran of the original game or a newcomer to the series. The game's tutorial mode provides an excellent introduction to the game's mechanics, ensuring that even novices can get up to speed quickly.

The new features that have been added to the game, such as improved pathfinding and enhanced multiplayer capabilities, make it even more enjoyable to play with friends or against other players online. The multiplayer mode allows players to compete against each other in a variety of game modes, adding an extra layer of excitement to an already thrilling game.

Overall, I would highly recommend Age of Empires: Definitive Edition to anyone who loves strategy games. The game offers an incredible amount of content, from the extensive single-player campaign to the various multiplayer options. With its attention to detail, accessibility, and depth of content, this game is sure to provide hours of entertainment for both casual and hardcore gamers alike.

Again, the lack of of meh... or whatever option in Steam reviews... The original Age of Empires was one of the best RTS games of this era, though not perfect. Unfortunately this remake only manages to elevate the graphics to modern standards, but the the aging gameplay and the simply non-existing pathfinding AI makes playing the game a master level course of frustration. To be fair, I am not sure how much of this is because of the outdated gameplay formula of the original game or the result of the remastering. On the other hand there is plenty of content of oldschool historical RTS here. While AoE2 was better in all aspects when it comes to single player gaming, one cand find fun for plenty of hours. That is one does not mind the complete lack of pathfinding AI for the units and the AI's micro capabalities - the latter is defeinitely not cheating in the sense that nothing brakes the rules of the game, but perfectly microing a dozen scorpions to avoid stone thrower projectiles is definitely something a human player is incapable of.

Awkward gameplay.

It's a disgrace to the CD era that it tries to pay homage to. Disc games had to be shipped without bugs, because they couldn't be patched back then. The units in AOEDE get stuck against eachother (or objects) constantly, and go the long way to destinations (if they don't get stuck in a loop).

Villagers can go idle without showing as idle, sometimes just standing on the building outline you ordered them to build. Sometimes military units don't fight back when attacked, and priests won't heal nearby units, but your catapults will take the initiative and kill your own units. Sometimes units run off and do their own thing across the map.

You can't select a unit behind another unit. Your units don't even obey orders, like if you order a unit to attack a catapult, it'll just attack the storage pit next to it (and then get hit by the catapult). The enemy AI can micromanage each unit though - sending them to pick off all your villagers and dodging any missile launched at them.

Enemy towers that have less range stats than your units somehow fire back at your unit's maximum range. The campaign could have had some work, as it has the potential to be a fun way to walk through history, but their gameplay design is frustrating (made worse if the objectives don't work).

Match outcome feels far too impacted by the wonky generated maps. AI micromanages each unit to dodge shots and target your villagers whilst growing an economy, until they stop doing anything at all or just resign when you get near their base. If the AI doesn't resign then you have to tediously kill each last unit that tries to avoid you.

The game doesn't like to minimize. Units can become invisible. Resources can be invisible on the minimap, or appear on the minimap when they're no longer on the map itself. The achievements are poor - like train 1,000 of a specific upgrade of unit. Some units can fire over hills, while others can't but will keep trying without moving.

I think they even messed up the nostalgia factor - the menu and graphics look too little like the original, and the music doesn't sound as I remember it. The RTS genre is so under-served that despite all these issues there's still a playable game underneath it all, as too many later RTS games added pointless mechanics that weighed them down.

One of the great things about the original Age of Empires games was that they were well polished, but this digital release is a sore disappointment in terms of quality. I might play it sometimes, but digital downloads should have been better; more convenient, not worse. Much like AOE2HD (which gets really choppy) they'll leave the issues in, and by 2023 it's still terrible.

I am a 48 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
