I have dumped hours upon hours into this game, game after game, match after match campaign after campaign, and I have yet to see a crash. Seriously every time I launch it, it runs fine, even after running for several hours the graphics and smooth FPS hold up. For reference I'm currently packing an Intel i5 integrated UHD 630 with 8Gb of RAM, and let me tell you this game still looks like something I would eat off the floor if it were edible, from the advanced unit designs, to the epic environment, and the cataclysmic building destructions, that in any other game would crash my PC, are all bonkers. I wouldn't for gameplay reasons buy this at full price but Steam decks out sales every two days so you never have to worry about overpricing. The gameplay is the only weakpoint but this game is still stupid fun alone or with friends, as a professional like Starcraft 2, this game is garbage but as a fun RTS age based unique design it is craploads of fun . If you're looking for this unique and amazing gameplay but with a bit more seriosness and playability with modernized balancing and sleek multiplayer action then I would recommend the second DE of Age of Empires becuase of the amazing replication of graphics.

It's disappointing that the AI in this effective remake has been calibrated as so ruthless that there seems, at least to this player, to be little difference between the five (that's *5*) difficulty levels. Two of the campaigns are effectively unplayable for casual play, on account of the initial scenario in each being practically impossible for anyone except those used to the highest difficulty. Unfortunately I've played way more hours than indicated, and it's made little difference. 

Seems to me that the game has no tolerance for players who'd prefer a fair fight, or to develop their civilisation without having to worry about being spammed by every opponent on the map. As others have noted, AI opponents appear to be better resourced from the beginning; and it seems they are set to attack the player rather than each other. Sorry, but if I'd wanted to be flayed alive every game, I'd play PvP. 

I'd like to see an update that fixes this issue, but it's been four years already, so that's doubtful. Unless you're an extreme RTS player, avoid this one. Shame, because otherwise it has a lot going for it. 2/5

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is a decent remaster of it's original real-time strategy counterpart. It has the appeal of a strategy board game you might have tucked away in a closet somewhere and pulled out every now and then to be played with some friends and a few drinks. It's fun but nothing I would spend any time at length getting into. 

I mostly enjoyed playing while listening to YouTube videos or podcasts; I could see myself getting bored with it otherwise. If you're thinking about getting it, I can recommend it, but only really for existing fans of the Age of Empires series. Age of Empires II does everything this game does but much better. 5.0/10.

I'm sure you are wondering if playing Age of Empires Definitive Editions worths your money and time. Well, I think it does, since is an updated version of the classic game with better graphics and better quality soundtrack. The original version of this game was my childhood, and seeing it with better quality makes me feel happy. 

Most of the campaigns are really good, and playing with different civilizations being unique in some ways makes it much better. If you are someone who loves classic history, this will leave you a good taste.

Gameplay is really well done and easy to learn. You can play with only mouse or with the hotkeys. You have some units that are unique for some civilization, but the system is similar: barracks, town center, houses, etc...

Graphically has the same ambience to the classic Age of Empires, yet it looks cleaner and more fluid than the original game. 

Soundtrack is trully a blessing to hear. You have the original OST but remastered, so it sounds fresh and new.

Archievements are not impossible to get. Some of them are just about finishing campaigns, or doing a specific activity or just creating units. 

And price? Worths it. Yeah, sales are good, but for full price the purchase is not a sin. You have tons of game hours with the campaigns and (if you want) many hours of multiplayer matches.

Age of Empires is really a nice strategy game and one of the most important titles in its genre, and if you are not fan from this kind of games, I recommend you to at least try it. Just think that this game was the first of many strategy games

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is definitely a remaster of an old game. Definitive Edition breathes some new life into the classic game. Game looks now more beautiful than ever before, and the newly composed music gives it its own identity, while still retaining its distinctive character. Throw in the fact that players are able to compete against each other online, and you've got a number of reasons to check it out. If you loved the original Age of Empires, the Definitive Edition is well worth a visit. Ultimately, though, it's still the same old Age of Empires, for better and for worse.

PROS:
‚úì Campaign covers ancient history and It‚Äôs really well done
‚úì Looks gorgeous, while still retaining the feel of the original vibrant visuals
‚úì Higher population limit, balance changes, faster speed, and more small tweaks
‚úì Classic gameplay
‚úì Excellent soundtrack 
‚úì Playing multiplayer is easy and fun
‚úì Expanded editor mode

CONS:
- Still has annoying pathfinding issues
- Lack of unit and building diversity
- A little clunky at times
- Primitive AI doesn‚Äôt always meet modern standards
Brutal, unforgiving, surprising amount of depth for such a classic, and, excellent replay value, even after 20 years.

There is nothing definitive about this "definitive edition", it's a broken mess:
- Original tribal music in the main menu missing, instead the AoE2 music. They dismissed what made AoE1 special and tried to copy AoE2.
- The new graphics don't look so impressive anymore when you zoom in close enough.
- PHOTON MAN and BIGDADDY, remember these cheats? Everyone loved these. They were lazy with this remake, they didn't bother to remake the graphics of these characters. Instead their graphics looks worse than in the original, because of the higher resolution.
- In custom game mode, you can activate the classic graphics, but they look worse than in the original game, because there is no appropriate resolution.
- The AI is broken. Your computer opponent cheats like hell. You can see that if you reveal the map in custom game mode. Therefore the game is too difficult and sometimes very unfair.

Stick to the orginal AoE1, not to this bad remake here. The original AoE1 is still a great game, no inferior remake needed!

The campaigns provide awesome historical scenarios with fair and balanced challenges for the most part. My only major gripe is there was an AI update for this game some time ago, and the AI update has made some levels exceedingly difficult even on the easiest setting. here's my honest opinion on age of empires

- GRAPHICS -
The graphics in this game are smooth and crisp, but if you zoom in they get a bit muddy and blurry. Other than that, I think this game's graphics are magnificent. 10/10

- GAMEPLAY -
The pathfinding AI in this game is awful. Every time I order a unit to move somewhere it takes the LONG WAY, or tries to find a nonexistent shortcut to the destination and waste time, or just bugs out and stands there midway through its walking animation. Also I think the difficulty in this game is hard, even on easy (or that could just be me being extremely bad at aoe1), but it feels so rewarding when I complete a mission (that usually takes up more than 30 minutes of my time). Other than that complaint about the AI, the gameplay is rewarding and compels me to play the game more. 8/10

- SOUND EFFECTS AND MUSIC -
I think the sound effects are a bit annoying and grating (except WOLOLO), but they're growing on me. I also don't like the music that much, it only plays a select few tracks that it feels like I've heard over a billion times now (I'm looking at you, 'I Shall Return'), and even when I haven't heard them a lot they still sound mediocre. But the other tracks that I almost never hear actually sound good, it's just a shame that they never play for me. 6/10

Overall: 9/10

This game has probably impacted and influenced my life more than any other. It helped fuel my fascination with ancient history and civilisations, which I am still passionate about all these years later. Don't be fooled by the time I've spent on this modern remake (which is excellent despite some minor problems here and there). I've poured countless hours into the original. 

So, is this version actually the Definitive Edition? Not really, but it does an admirable job. if anything it does a far too faithful recreation of the original from 1997 at times, as it imports some of the bugs, poor pathfinding and weak creative design decisions of the original into this newer edition. Hopefully Microsoft will foray back into this period in the future with a new edition, like they did with AOE IV regarding the Middle Ages. Fans of the original will enjoy jumping back into this game for nostalgic reasons, but newer players, or those that started with AOE II will find this game rather lacklustre and unpolished in comparison to Age of Kings or Age of Mythology. 

The new HD graphics are a faithful rendition of the original, and the new reworked soundtrack is a joy to listen to as well. Luckily the old soundtrack and graphics are included too. The missions have been given something of reworking as some scenarios play out a little bit different from the originals, which can cause some problems as the a.i struggles at points (The Holy Man mission from the voices of Babylon campaign comes to mind). They're still enormous fun to play, and I raced through the Egyptian and Greek campaigns. The only new content is the Hittites campaign, which is basically a re-imagining of scenarios included on the demo version of the game from 1997. 

I can't express how much I enjoy this game, and all the fun it has brought me over the years. It's one of my absolute favourite games of all time, and certainly the most influential. Even though I don't play it as often as I did when I was younger, it still lives on in my thoughts. Even the sound effects are utterly iconic (Wolololo, Rogan? Zookontah!) and the music is evocative. A very big thumbs up from me.

Stepmom Simulator. Why? - Because pathfinding in this game is s-so horrible, that units risk to stuck literally everywhere. And I wish it was the only problem, but boi, let me start from the very beginning. While I absolutely love AoE II and admit that it is far superior game, the first AoE is my favourite nevertheless. It was my first RTS and the 3rd game at all (2 others and NFS2 and Captain Claw). I can't even imagine how much time I spent playing it in my childhood. As you can see, Age of Empires is special for me. But when it comes to Definitive Edition...

At first, when I launched it, I was excited as a kid. Finally: my favourite game, on modern hardware, huge screen, with modern graphics. Unfortunately this excitement ended abruptly and very soon. Right in the 2nd mission of Egyptian campaign. This is where I've seen [b]that[/b]. Pathfinding. Look, I will not pretend that everything was great with pathfinding in the original. Absolutely not. It indeed had problems. Units could do some stupid things. But here is the thing - 25 years passed! 

From DE that comes 25 years later, you expect not just better visuals, but at least some techical and gameplay improvements. But in fact, pathfinding here is even worse! Your stepunits literally stuck [b]inside[/b] each other. You can unstuck them only via 'delete' button. Or, they can start infinitely walking into the edge of the map. Forever. Have you seen that gif in the community, where peasant is infinitely walking around unfinished buiding? - that's not a rare AI bug, that's rather usual situation.

But enough about pathfinding. Let's talk about mapdesign. And... it's hits and misses. Most of the maps remained more or less the same, and that's kinda good. They also improved some, let's say, inexpressive maps. And they removed some clearly stupid things, like Perseus hero in Yamato campaign. That's also a good thing. The problem is, they also totally butchered some iconic maps. Remember that mission with the temple on the hill, in Yamato campaign? Map was huge, mountain was very tall. Reaching the top was a hard task. True pilgrimage! And now what? - you reach the mountain, left, right and here is your temple.

Or, remember "I'll be back mission" from Greece campaign? That was... something. Running away like beaten up dog, tresspassing hostile lands, ambushes at every corner and in the end - you finally reach your allies. You regroup, heal your wounds and start retaking lost territory. And what a satisfying moment it was, when you finally reach initial location and raze that cursed temple... It's all gone in DE. You just run little down, to the left and hop - here is your huge base with tons of resources... Meh. 

One more thing that leaves sour taste after you play the campaigns - AI. And man, it's really bad. In original, even moderate AI could mentally crush you, while here the hardest AI is dumb as a cork. Only few missions here can give you some challenge. I supppose it's bugged, because sometimes if you save/load or restart mission, it becomes more agressive. Probably something triggers him to be more active. But in versus AI is clearly better.

Next issues I'll put in "lazyness, negligence and indifference" cathegory. Where do I even start... remember warships? All of them had oars. Here, they animated oars for triremes. Sounds cool, right? I also think so. The problem is - that's the only type of vessels they animated. [deep breath] How can you explain this? They animated one type of ships and probably decided: "ah, that's enough, or the game will be too good". Or Microsoft gave them so few money, that they could animate only one ship?

Also, when ballistas and triremes shoot their projectiles, upon hitting target they transform into... stones. As if they were launched from the catapults. How can this be explained? Everything is ok, right? Definitely not a bug, yeah? No need to fix?
And what's wrong with elefant's attacking animation? He is shaking as if he was electrocuted. BTW, a word about attacking animations. In original, almost all units had 8(!!!) different attacking animations for each direction of attack. Here, each of them has only 1.

The last drop for me was MP. And I mean network issues. You enter lobby, bam! - disconnected. (XBox something something - I don't even have XBox account, why I get such messages?) You successfully ended the game - get a desync. You start 3vs3 or 4vs4 game - somebody already lost connection. Playing intense match for 20-30 mins - desktop. FYI, I don't have such issues with AoE II DE and even with AoE II (2013). 

Also... ah, guess what? I said enough. Let's make some conclusions. What did we get? Modern visuals? - yeah. Music? - well, they changed few iconic melodies, but overall quality is good. Destruction? - nice. The rest - clearly worse. 25 years. The first game in the legendary franchise... It had to become something big. Instead, DE of my favourite RTS is rotting on the outskirts of Steam with 10-20 people in MP. If you think that I'm too harsh or unfair - just compare it to AoE II DE.

And I don't even blame Microsoft. M$ is just a bottomless money bag and totally incompetent as a publisher. Always was. Even now, they bought lots of studios and franchises and have no idea what to do with them. I blame Forgotten Empires team. I realise that probably they have not as much experience as Ensemble Studios. But I could not imagine that they will handle AoE so negligently. For me, to pretend that these issues do not exist, is to betray good memories of the original game.

***   ***   ***

Updated. You know, that fact that I had to leave this negative review last time left a taste of regret. But after investing more time into the game (mostly in multiplayer) I regret only one thing - that I can't make 100 more negative reviews and downvote this joke of remaster into oblivion.

Why? Because overall multiplayer experience is just pathetic. I won't even adress that fact that it lacks tons of obligatory features and it is half-dead in general, no. I'm going to talk only about technical aspects - constant crashes are making the game unplayable. It seems like it has something to do with their server maintenance. Sometimes they kinda improve the situation, sometimes - make it even worse. 

In mid September - early October game worked almost perfectly - almost 0 crashes. But since previous maintenance it became totally unplayable. 6 crashes yesterday and 4 more today. In the last 4x4 sesion I played, [b] two [/b] players from the same team got disconnected right in the beginning. This is unbearable. I give up.
 
On top of that, the game is not protected from griefers who spam pause button. These little pests keep spamming pause or constantly switching game speed back and forth, what crashes the game for other players. Thus, if you failed to deliver worthy remaster of once legendary game, at least fix what'd already done. I simply lack words to express my disappointment.

The AI is broken and makes for a very irritating gaming experience. It's either too easy or too hard and nothing in between. I don't like the updated graphics. I'll keep this simple. The game came out in 1997. You may find it crude by your standards but it's a great game to let kids play.

Start with a civilization in the Stone Age. Put them to work collecting wood, food, stone, gold. Collect enough of these and advance to other ages with improvements to each of your production or military structures. Defend them from the enemy AI and grow stronger and survive by eliminating the enemy.

Those of you who know how to edit or make your own scenarios can eliminate the war/defense option and make your opponent an ally or neutral.

All in all a simple starter game for kids to cut their teeth on.

Age of Empires 1 was an important step to get where we got, but is now dated. Some common features in current RTS that are not present here (in the Definitive Edition!) include:
- Formations: no formation button and units do not go into formation by default, instead choosing to move as they were when selected.
- Trading resources: the market only has technologies. On water maps you get the merchant ship but land maps will run out of gold eventually, along with stone and wood, and without wood, food.
- Waypoints: impossible to make an order queue (e.g.: shift+click to order a villager to build two buildings then go back to work).
- Unique units/heroes: civilizations are differentiated by a handful of bonuses and a lack of technologies and units (e.g.: Greeks do not have the composite bowmen upgrade, but Babylonians do).

Other than the lack of unique units, I feel like the above features should have been added to even qualify as  a "Definitive Edition"; but I'd consider them minor issues were it not for the true abysmal issue: AI pathing. It's so bad it's almost unbelievable. AoE2 and 3 have it nowhere near this bad. A usual case is if an enemy unit is moving in a straight line and you order your unit to attack it by right clicking on the enemy unit, unless it's on a direct collision course with the enemy, it will walk to where the enemy unit was standing the moment the order was issued and then some times start chasing the already gone unit or just keep walking.

If you want to play an ancient age RTS, try 0 A.D. It's not perfect, but I feel confident saying it's way better than AoE1DE.

I can't put it on any particular feature, but the game feels worse than the ([url=https://upatch-hd.weebly.com/]user-patched[/url]) original.
Music, visuals, pathfinding, campaign missions... all somehow feels better in the patched original.

Especially pathfinding.... I'm not sure what the problem here is? It is freakin' Dijkstra and I have the CPU equivalent of a full NASA server farm in my midi tower, compared to back in the day. Please utilize that, ffs.
We can see the same villager-problems as in AOE2 DE, with vils getting stuck in each other, unable to resolve the problem for seconds at times (just to be repeated for the next resource drop-off).
You can spot things that should never happen, like units giving up searching for a path after being blocked 2-3 times. user-patch already upped the retries, lowered the time between pathing attempts and overall created a smoother feeling pathfinding system than we got in DE. WITHOUT ACCESS TO THE SOURCE CODE !

I played the campaigns side by side at some point to see how it feels, and both are horribly trial-and-error for modern standards (especially when compared to AOE2). But DE adds a weird layer of buggy AI that seems to either do nothing, or go completely crazy, rushing max age and hitting you with everything they got, no matter where you are on the map. It's the worst in those "limited-army" or "one-monk" starting scenarios.
Even with improved missions when it comes to eye candy and overall map design, those issues again make me recommend the original instead.

The new visuals are great, especially with what underlying systems they had to work with. Still, the originals fit the clunky gameplay better. I feel a 1997 game, and I see a 1997 game. No fluff.
The problem: You can ONLY switch to the original graphics set when playing skirmish... WHAT THE ACTUAL F*** ???
On top of that, there are bugs (trees without shadows, wrong sprites for the shore line), and you are not allowed to zoom. You can only choose a resolution and stretch the sprites to fill it (== zoom in/out). Why? How is that a "Definitive" edition? The user-patched version achieves the same with less bugs.

Music is fine. But why is there not a button to switch between the original and modern tracks. Or mix them? Again: "DEFINITIVE" should mean grab and preserve what is there, improve what you want to improve as optional changes, then put a sensible price tag on it.

The only REAL positive feature I can list is the updated farming system. It's basically AOE2's system, allowing to walk over farms and have them auto-reseed.

TLDR: Half-arsed modernization attempt. Stick to the [url=https://upatch-hd.weebly.com/]user-patched[/url] original or get it cheap in addition to the original. No substantial patches since release.

This was the game that introduced me to the RTS genre that changed everything. 

I was playing Microsoft Combat Flight simulator on my Windows 98 computer and in the introduction menu had an option for demos. In it included Monster Truck Madness 2, Motorock Madness, and this game. At first I thought this was a biblical game considering the civilizations of the Egyptians and Babylonians. Not to mention the fishing boats resembling Noah's ark and the priests resembling ones depicted. I opened the demo campaign where you played as the Egyptians fighting the Greeks and destroying their town center. I had no idea how to play and I kept sending Soldiers one by one to destroy the buildings and they kept dying. It wasn't until I accidentally dragged a whole bunch of them by mistake and sending all at the same time to the enemy base, destroying everything. I thought it was one of the coolest things I ever saw. It was than I also played the Hittite campaign though I never beat all of them since I wasn't good at creating a base and fighting off the enemies.

I ended up getting Age of Empires II: Age of kings as a surprise gift for good grades and the I stuck with that game. a few years later I ended up getting the dual pack CD that included the first game with the rise of Rome Edition and discovered more fun with that.

REALLY WISH they created new Civilizations in the definitive edition as well as new units, new research techs, and maps as well as porting more quality of life improvements from the 2nd game to here. Other Civilizations certainly exited in this time period such as the Olmecs, Huns, Celts, Harappan, Akkadians, and more that exist as enemies in the campaign already. 

Only a few things were brought like passable farms, idle villagers, and military stances (ones I can think of at the top of my head). Of course the one issue that has existed since the beginning is the Path finding, which I think is the hardest to fix since the game is older than the 2nd game.

Other than that, Great game that introduced me to the genre and one Ill never forget!

This is the time that started it all, both literally and figuratively. The updated game is new and shiny whilst remaining old and classic as a timeless bridge between past and present history in both game and real terms. There are new crisp and clean graphics for new players as well as older, shabbier modes for we Elders of the Parish who remember and enjoyed the original. There remain the old challenges as well as new features for everyone to enjoy in this challenging remaster. If you learn anything from this game, it's history. And if history teaches us anything, it's that history belongs to the victors!

Update:
I revealed the map with cheats to see what they are actually doing during the first few minutes and i could not believe my eyes ...  They build 4 Huts, a Storage and Grain Silo, send some villagers off to reveal the map and send their other villager off to get food, while simultaneously creating new villagers until they are at 24 ... Every new villager is instantly sent to hunt for food ... WTF? Thats so much micromanagement in the first few minutes, that a human can never achieve ... or at least not in a way that is actually fun to play ... 
If you don't do it like this you can play for 10 more minutes then they will be already in the bronze age, have an army of 10-15 units and come attack you, while you are still in the Tool age with no army ...

Remember THAT was EASY difficulty ... how are you supposed to do any higher difficulty if EASY is already almost impossible ...
You can't see where you were last in campaigns.. :(

Classic!

So, is this game worth buying? Personally I'd say no. At the time of this games release I would say it was one of the worst remakes or "Definitive Editions" I had ever bought. I loved the original Age of Empires, the style, the love and effort put into the little details, everything. And this remake didn't live up to the nostalgia. If you want to read my original review, I've left it at the bottom so you can see how I experienced the game when it was first released on Steam. 

Since then I have actually got it to work and still found issues with it: Pathfinding is still appalling, the hitboxes for mouse clicks are oddly finicky: try and send a lumberjack to cut down and tree and he will occasionally develop a love for staying at bark..., the frame rate at times was down right atrocious, dipping into single digits, and the AI was either mentally brain dead or an omniscient god, sending troops across the entire map despite the fact that they had never scouted you out yet. Yes I despised playing this game a lot of the time. 

But then I thought to myself: did I really enjoy the gameplay when I first experienced Age of Empires all those years ago? Yes of course I did, because I didn't have anything to compare it to. Don't get me wrong the original Age of Empires was a monumental game, a monolith of the RTS genre, but it hasn't aged well. Most of the issues I find with this Definitive Edition are there purely BECAUSE it is Definitive. It is a remake of the game as it was balanced all those years ago. Could it have done with a lick of paint? Sure. Maybe make Axemen useful after the Tool Age, some added bonuses that make Camel Riders a unit worth investing in more than 5% of the time, some changes to Chariot Archers that make them less infuriating to defend against a rush of. But it wouldn't have been DEFINITIVE.

Yes there are other things I find problems with: as an avid Scenario Creator, the tools you are given (or rather lack there of) especially in regards to the Scenario Instructions section is just mind boggling. The art style seems "muddied" for lack of a better phrase, especially when you zoom in. 

But I cannot truly hate this game. When it was released I certainly did. I will stand by my belief that releasing it on Steam was a last ditched attempt to boost up sales (we had been asking for it to be released for Steam for a year and a half to almost no avail) and when it was finally unveiled it was atrocious. But a small team HAS been steadily fixing and adjusting it. But you can only polish a broken vase so much to make it shine. 

OLD REVIEW YET STILL SORT OF APPLICABLE - Yet another highly anticipated release marred by a publisher greedy for cash. I, like many other Age of Empires fans was incredibly excited to see this game was in progress, and as a fan who found many problems with the original games despite my adoration for them, was looking forward to seeing those issues addressed.

First red flag was the pushed back date of release. Now this isn't always an issue, see A Hat in Time and Cuphead for examples why it can be a good thing at times. However, it usually indicates a company is trying to push a game out for a certain date but realises that the product is not up to Steam (amazing pun I know). Second red flag was that when it was finally released it was a Games for Windows Live exclusive, suggesting that Microsoft wanted to force people to use their frankly useless service for more money.

And so we waited, and waited, and commented on every post that we could "AoE IV is good and all but can you spend like 5 mins to release AoE DE on Steam?". And then at last NEARLY ONE AND A HALF YEARS LATER, we get AoE DE on Steam. And it's a sh*t show.

I have only 7 minutes clocked in on this game and that will give you one of two reactions to this review: A) He doesn't know what he's talking about, or B) God this game must be really awful. And both are valid points. On the one hand I didn't get enough time to experience things like path-finding or gameplay bugs or tweaks. But on the other, the fact that I got a refund 7 MINUTES IN tells you that something is seriously off to dissuade a fan such as myself.

The biggest issue for me, as well as many others, is the fact that the game clashes with many other programs most notably antivirus software. The solution should be simple but as I am using a free trial version of Avast means I can't actually whitelist this game so I cannot play it. So you may think "That's a you problem" but the fact that the game was released in a state in which vast portions of its playerbase cannot even run the thing for more than 5 minutes astounds me.

Age of Empires: DE is not only one of the best games in the RTS world, but it is also one of the most well-made remasters in the history of gaming. It feels like a different game entirely, but at the same time it managed to keep the soul that made the original 1997 title so great.

This isn‚Äôt to say there aren‚Äôt issues, though. I‚Äôve found some shortcuts really difficult to use and I had to tweak most of them to be able to take advantage. Some unit commands don‚Äôt seem to work at all, such as ‚Äústand ground‚Äù, which some units insist on ignoring. Pathfinding is another problem, but even that was absent in the original game and, in some way or another, it forces the player to micromanage a little so it isn‚Äôt all that bad.

I absolutely love the fact that Age of Empires is based on the world‚Äôs history, even if there‚Äôre inaccuracies. I didn‚Äôt play all the campaigns, but the Tutorial (based on the Egyptians) and the first one (based on the Greeks) were a joy to go through. The narrator does a pretty decent job to give some background info before each mission. There‚Äôre real world maps, hints and further history insights for every campaign scenario, which is something that one mustn‚Äôt ignore to fully enjoy this game.

Some companies should do their homework and learn how to do remasters like Forgotten Empires. It is safe to say that Age of Empires: DE isn‚Äôt only a timeless classic, but also a masterpiece of how to properly reimagine a game in the modern era. Everything is done correctly here: skirmish against AI, online multiplayer, LAN (!), ranked matches, custom campaigns and so on. If you played the original and liked it, there‚Äôs a good chance that will love the remaster even more!

There are lots of single player campaigns, so plenty of content. But in some scenarios, the difficulty is unbalanced. Like, first you are strolling through the scenarios, and then suddenly the AI goes bonkers, and you'll find yourself save-scumming a lot. I've heard rumors that in some such instances, actually INCREASING the difficulty makes it easier. Haven't tried it, though.

Multiplayer is practically dead. Unfortunately, one achievement requires winning a ranked multiplayer match. So that sucks for 100% achievement hunters.

Some people say path-finding is bugged. And it is. Not game-breakingly broken, but annoying, nonetheless. Units getting stuck while trying to pass each other. But as far as I can tell, it was quite similar in the original, too. Apart from the occasional brazen AI and the erratic path-finding, I didn't encounter any bugs.

I bought this game twice, first on the Microsoft Store, then on Steam. Unfortunately, both times it's become abandoned. This game was a sacrifice on the altar of AoE2 to test if people wanted that game's definitive edition. Which is a shame because I always preferred 1 to 2 since I prefer ancient history to medieval history, but in every way this is outclassed by AoE2. The lobbies are barren and empty and the game hasn't had a patch for ages. Again, it was to test the waters and die since barely anybody cared about 1. The game fixed a lot of issues like villagers not auto-tasking, but the game still lacks a method of generating infinite resources so it's incredibly easy for the game, especially island games, to run out of resources. But since AoE1 is way more aggressive, this isn't a bad thing.

TL:DR: The multiplayer is dead and the game is abandoned. Go play AoE2 instead.

[h1]Very Mixed Feelings! - Worth trying but not necessary playing[/h1]

I played the original AoE1 and it's Trail version (Hittie Campaign) and I appreciate the remake of the game to modern standards. However I feel more affected by the cons than the pros. :/

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Unit PATHFINDING is VERY BUGGY, sometimes resulting in units blocking themselves while moving or standing; villagers sometimes cannot find way to a resource they previously accessed;  This sometimes requires spending time on manual controlling units every second step (and grants even more frustration)
  (I also have a feeling like it's not just the pathfinding but also unit-to-map size ratio that's an issue here)
- Player Unit AI stances don't seem to perform well - aggressive unit can start attacking after being hit first
- The change of campaign mission intro screen seems to have little place for text and I find the audio intro (and outro) somewhat irritating
- For people looking for the original feel of AoE it might come a bit of a dissapointment at first since unit sounds and interface have been significantly changed (building icons for example)

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Visual redo of units, buildings an environment, so not just a port or patch
+ Works under higher resolution than the original
+ Some new units and propertis of technologies

Classic!!

Pros
1. Graphics
2. Sound
3. Gameplay improvements 
    a.) The ability for each building to produce soldiers separately
    b.) The rally point for buildings
    c.) Villagers are a bit smarter and try to not remain idle
    d.) The information the game gives (idle villagers and how many villagers are gathering each resource)
I'm sure there are other improvements that I don't know about since I barely played this version of the game.
4. Voiceover in the campaigns

Cons
1. Pathfinding, although it's a bit improved
2. There are very little differences between civilizations in terms of unique units and there are some units that feel out of place. For example everyone has hoplites, which was the main greek soldier and greeks do not have a better archer than the bowman which is considered a "trash" unit.
3. The campaigns don't offer much variety


Summary
If you played the initial version of the game and liked it and want to feel the nostalgia, then you will definitely like this one because it's the same game with better graphics, better sound and better gameplay. You might also like to play the game if you are new to the series, it's not a bad start, but play it first because the other games are better and you might dislike it otherwise.

Personally, although I finished the original version of the game, I found it to be more of a chore rather than a fun experience. I played it for the sake of playing all the series. I can't say this version of the game is bad by any means, but I found the overall experience just ok. I find the pathfinding problems frustrating. I also felt that all the civilizations were mostly the same with minor differences and I found the unit inaccuracies annoying.  The overall gameplay is just a little outdated in comparison with today's standards and the campaigns don't offer a lot of variety to keep me interested. Age of mythology is a much better game in my opinion and each civilization feels and plays differently. When you play with the greeks, you instantly know you play with the greeks, when you play with the vikings or the egyptians, you instantly know it. I just can't find the will to replay the same boring campaigns just because the graphics, the sound and a few aspects of the gameplay are better.

84/100 Not as good as Age of Empires II, but still fun.  The biggest problem is that despite this being a Definitive Edition, the path-finding is atrocious, with units frequently getting stuck or colliding with each other, monks often going the complete opposite direction to where you told the rest of their group to go, and loading transport ships can be frustrating.  I took just over 80 hours to work through the single player campaign and really enjoyed it.  With the population cap of 50 (compared with 200 in AOE2), and earlier civilisations (so no trebuchets), it plays a bit differently to AOE2.

I played original AoE, Rise of Rome plus all other AoE like HD up to DE now. Game is basically the same. Newer graphics, old problems with AI, pathfinding. Civilizations got new balance pass, animations are good. Actually it feels not so strange after all.  

Old campaigns work, old scenarios too work simply - insert old files and change extension. However there are no intro movies even for newly done campaigns. :/ And some campaigns are little changed. But you can easily get old versions. Changes are sometimes for better, sometimes for worse. New music is good, plus there is option to insert old tracks for nostalgia.

Honestly there is option for fan made AoE HD https://www.moddb.com/mods/age-of-empires-hd-edition (now discontinued) however this version is closest to original you can get. This is new, updated. But not perfect. Fan HD mod is having some old problems...so pick your favourite.

Overall I would say the DE is solid. Nothing new but no big clusterfuck like Warcraft III. But looking ad AoE 2 DE...I would love some some expansion of some new units, pathfinding...well one can dream.

Game lags on LAN... like I played on literal potatoes back in the day that never had this issue. What's worse is that there appears to be no fix or any sort of address to this. Research led me to either AoE DE2 or 3 or blogs talking about this issue dating back two years with no fix whatsoever. 

I miss when games had this thing called "standards". It was a metric on what made a good game versus a bad game. Now it seems like standards have evaporated in favor of overzelous game designers who think they can just milk old titles by updating visuals and then doing nothing about the real issues. My game should not lag on a LAN setup. At. All. This is flat out unacceptable that this happens. And if your answer is "well games have evolved" no. Unacceptable. This is an old game that LAN played seamlessly by comparison back when it launched. That should be the primary focus. I am tired of games getting away with low effort projects and the responses always being "wElL aT lEaSt It LoOkEd PrEtY". Lol. Hard to enjoy when it has unbearable lag ON A LAN GAME.

I have mixed feelings about AOE 1 DE. On the one hand, it absolutely looks like you might have wanted it to in your mind's eye 25 years ago when Age of Empires came out, with a (small) number of tweaks to QOL (I think the reseed farms button is new) while still being mostly faithful to the old game. It includes all of the original game, Rise of Rome, and two reworked campaigns from the demo, and all the associated civs for online and comp-stomp play, giving it a fair bit of meat for your money. I got to see a lot of stuff I'd never seen before, experience a lot of stuff I'd never experienced before. Some of the missions here are a ton of fun. (Turning Archimedes' fabled sunlight reflectors defending Syracuse into laser towers for the sake of a video game was inspired.) On the other...it is indeed faithful to the old game, kind of to a fault.

The missions here have been tweaked, remixed, and occasionally rearranged or replaced, but you still have to contend with the limitations of 1997: a low population cap, wonky AI (despite admirable efforts), and a general lack of strategic options compared to AOE 2. This results in the difficulty curve being all over the shop irrespective of which order you play campaigns or missions: one of the hardest missions in the entire game is the first Hittite scenario, which the tutorial campaign subtly points you toward at its conclusion, while the very last Rise of Rome mission chronologically (The Coming of the Huns, here remade to resemble the Catalaunian Fields scenario from AOE 2) becomes piss-easy after dealing with the early Wonder rush.

It's a fun piece of gaming history, and clearly since I saw it through to completion so I didn't *dislike* it. It's just frustrating sometimes when the old mechanics wind up not quite holding up the way your nostalgic brain wants them to.

Ah.. Age of Empires, my favorite childhood game.. Just kidding, it's not, but I do have a pretty funny memory related to this game that I want to share. When I was a kid, one of my older cousins brought me to one of those internet cafe places and told me to play Age of Empires with him. I can't really remember why he wanted me to, since I barely knew how to even play the game at that time, so I guess he just wanted me to become his punching bag or something. We played our first game and to no surprises, I was trailing behind pretty far at first. But then out of nowhere, there was this random dude who stood behind me and told me that he wanted to offer his help with the game for some reasons. I agreed, and after about 10 minutes or so, he overran my cousin's army and completely destroyed him. He was pretty mad about it and walked toward my desk and told that dude to let me play by myself. I wasn't reacting to any of this, but from the inside I was having a blast about it lol. That was my fondest memory I ever had with Age of Empires, and even though it was never my thing back then, I'll always remember the moment when my cousin got destroyed by a total stranger every time I think about this franchise.

Fast forward to the present. When I heard the news that they were going to make a Definitive Edition for the game, I was pretty stoked and couldn't wait to try the game out. I wanted to see how much they have improved over the original one, relive some of my childhood memories, and lay this theory that I would never get good with it to rest once and for all. Turns out, I couldn't, because I still sucks at this game lol. Age of Empires: Definitive Edition reminds me of the main reason why I can never get into RTS games: Too many things to worry about at one time. Yeah.. Multitasking has never been my strong suit, but I will say that out of the 19 hours of playing (Finishing the tutorial and the first campaign), I did manage to have some fun with the game. Ain't nothing like eviscerating every single AI's units, then building Wonder and feeling like a complete douchebag am I right? The game overall looks good and works well, though sometimes when I was moving a large number of units, some of them were starting to behave weirdly. I heard this is an issue with the AI pathfinding that was presented even in the original game, but since I never was a serious player, it didn't bother me too much.

Normally in my review I would point out some pros and cons of a game, then give the final rating, but I don't feel like doing that with Age of Empires: Definitive Edition since I barely scratched the surface of it. However I did enjoy my time with the game and would recommend to anyone who's new to the franchise, as long as you have some interest with the RTS genre, unlike me lol. But if you are a hardcore RTS/AoE fan then consider getting the second game instead, I heard it's a much better product than this one.

I have always been a latecomer with regard to the "Age of Empires" franchise, but with each title, so far, I have always been glad when I finally got around to playing it. This first game of the series is no exception. Even though this is a remaster and despite the fact that I had never played the original version before, the music and graphics instantly took me back to what it was like playing games in the 90s. While it does not have the same rich variety and sophistication of its successors, one can already see the many great foundational blocks in "AOEI" that later made "AOEII" the great game that it became. Although the visual overhaul of this "Definitive Edition" is well done in my opinion, the questionable unit pathfinding and the low population cap (at least in the standard campaigns) will probably test the patience of many newer players.

This game may not be quite as good as the sequel, but it's loaded with charm. I never thought it would get a new version. The sound effects are perfect, makes the game feel the right amount of chaotic when battle starts up. But it's also fun to just watch your villagers shuffle around and gather resources. I love the new graphics, it's such a nice step up from the original.
I'm glad the Definitive Edition has the tech tree in game. I spent so many years not knowing what civ did what because the original had it separate from the game.

What I wish though, was that this 'Definitive" edition did more. It's almost too faithful to the original? There are some lovely QoL they did add, like reseeding farms and the ability to production chain techs and units. I would love more maps, especially the MegaRandom map option from AoE2DE. What we got feels so bare compared to the love and attention the sequel got. Also strange that the game doesn't "remember" the last civ you played in skirmish, or that you have to keep clicking the reseed farms button every match. 

I am thankful this Definitive Edition is much more lax when it comes to using cheats in campaign, the other DE releases clamp down on it. Just let the player decide if they want to cheat or not in single player.

Overall though, I love AoE1. It may not "historically accurate" in areas, but it was made in a time when computer space was at a premium.

Age of Empires was my first glimpse into the RTS genre and the definitive edition has done a wonderful job bringing that classic into the modern era.  The updated visuals, controls, and UI have been a welcome addition to the game that had me waking up early before school to play.  Being able to view the tech trees before custom games, along with setting the population count higher is also very fun.
However, I am hesitant to recommend the title for those who are not interested in the nostalgia trip.  The gameplay feels a bit clunky compared to many modern titles.  With slower units and frustrating path finding, a match can get a little frustrating.  Especially compared to the polish seen in AoE II and beyond.  If you can get past that there is a fun historical campaign with a nice narration to enjoy.  It is also always fun to play in an ancient worlds sandbox which is so rarely explored (Age of Empires Online does a great job however ‚Äì and it is free to play).

Good: This is an accurate remake of AoE1, but incredibly pretty. I wouldn't think AoE1 could be a joy to look at on a 27" screen, but here it is. This is a history lesson in itself about classic, oldschool RTS and still tons of fun to play with a great atmosphere.

Not so good: This is a VERY ACCURATE remake of AoE1, including very dumb AI and a few other quirks. Your units are incredibly dumb and will often get stuck on obstacles or each other, and as soon as you barely scratch an AI opponent, it will pour all its resources into murdering you from that point. Also, it seems in campaigns the population limit was not changed and remains at 50 (!!!). These things really could have been modernised, and some things from AoE2 like formations would be very welcome.

Still, if you prefer ancient times over medieval or just want maximum oldschool, it's great. And it's really, really pretty.

Solid game, if outdated.  Takes some getting used to.  Only thing is, unless you're a masochist, play with map fully explored and no fog.  Computer AI-- regardless of difficulty-- not only has this enabled by default, but is also keenly aware of your exact line of site, and will hide their own units in areas you *think* you have explored, because it knows the exact pixels it needs to avoid in order to stay completely out of your side, but still very near your territory.  

As a multiplayer game, it's still one of the best RTS games ever, even better now with new civilisations and rebalancing.  AoE II still beats it, but it's nice to sometimes go back to oldschool.

The Campaigns are very good and the tutorial campaign taught me how to play this game very well and what I learnt from it has helped me play the other games in the series. The pathfinding and AI can be a bit annoying though with the AI sometimes being pretty challenging even at easier difficulties but challenge seems to be what makes up this franchise as a whole. In all that I've said I would 100% reccommend getting this game.

One of the best Real Time Strategy games I have ever played.

+ Tons of history lore. You can learn so much about ancient empires and civilizations.
+ 10 campaigns, that is a huge amount of content. Took me 77 hours to beat them all.
+ In each campaign you play as different civilization and each of them have different technology trees.
+ Gameplay is RTS and has pretty much what you'd expect from it, resource scavenging, building buildings, improving technology, demolishing enemy empire or empires. Because of different map variations you have to adapt to situations based on geography, recourses and civilization you're playing for and that's why the game never gets boring as in each level you have to use different tactics to defeat your enemies.
+ Improves over original game with many quality of life improvements to make it smoother to play.

- Troop pathfinding is terrible.
- I preffered graphics of original game, it was more colourful. Of course, it's nice that the textures are higher resolution now, but I wish it was less realistic looking and more colourful or at least let us choose the colour palette.

This is an updated review almost a year after my original posting. It is at this time my nostalgia has been set aside and I can post something from a relatively non-biased perspective.

Age of Empires has a special place in my heart as it was the first RTS I ever played, courtesy of my grandmother receiving a free vanilla copy with her new laptop (circa 1999).  As a child, I didn't exactly understand what I was doing and this continued for the next 20 years as I would play the game on and off. Only since last year have I come to truly understand what I am doing through research and trial and error and it has made the game that much more enjoyable.

With that overview stated, let's talk about what makes this game what it is:
1. The improvement of the graphics is pleasing to the eye though if you want to take a trip down memory lane you can refer to the available classic mode which gives you the original experience for the most part. 
2. Farms now have the option of being solid (like buildings) or not (like AOE2 farms), the latter allowing you to maximize your economy and increasing your game-play experience.
3. Definitive Edition includes all DLC from the original game (which was a surprise to me; prior to my purchase of DE, I was unaware of any expansions.)
4. Many attack animations for the units have seemingly been removed with the introduction of DE which may leave you feeling at a loss concerning visual aesthetics. 
5. Possibly the biggest flaw, the AI seems to have taken a turn for the worse: "handholding"  has almost become a necessity to increase lethality.  Pathfinding quite often causes your units to clump together and become stuck or even send them in the wrong direction altogether before correcting themselves. Even after this, sometimes intervention is necessary.
6. As AOE2 remains the proverbial Golden Goose (and with AOE4 now on the market), major updates for this game have ceased.
7. All buildings now allow unit construction/improvement research stacking which may also improve your experience as you no longer have to check in constantly to keep the ball rolling.

For those that are die-hard AOE2 fans, this installment will feel quite foreign to you. Some examples of this: 
1. The market system and build orders are drastically different. 
2. There are no unit formations.
3. The constructable units and buildings are fewer. 
This allows the game to be simpler and yet more challenging at the same time.

With all of this said, I would still recommend this game. It is highly enjoyable if taken with a grain of salt and knowing full well it has its kinks which, in all likelihood, will not be addressed by its producers.

There are two types of remasters. The first is where a new splash of paint is applied but no effort is made to update the game with quality of life features employed since the game was originally released. The second actually improves the game. Unfortunately, this game falls into the former category.

I played Age of Empires when it was released in 1998 so purchase of the Definitive Edition was meant to be a trip of nostalgia. Playing Age of Empires now reminded me how far the series has come. There are so many quality of life improvements which aren't included, pathfinding is terrible, the AI poor, the UI feels clunky and the game itself hasn't aged well. 

If you want to play it for the nostalgia, sure, get it on special but be prepared for disappointment. If you are a new player, skip this one and rather play one of the other Age of Empires games. The series may have begun here and while AOE2 and AOE3 continually improved, it seems that AOE got left behind.

This game is awesome.
The game is fairly hard even on Moderate, some levels require tactics which take several attempts to find out. The game was rebalanced, some units, stats and upgrade paths were changed. The expansion is included, as well as some demo campaigns. There are achievements to unlock, some require a bit of grinding, but all of them can be collected.
The game has around 80-100 hours of content (largely depending on how meticulous your approach is to campaign levels).
The AI is not cheating (as some critics say) in terms of resources or unit production, but it does exploit its ability to do lots of tasks at once (like archers alternating between backing and shooting), which you have to find your own methods to counter.
Recommended.

I have played AoE 1, 2, 3 original and definitive editions. AoE 1 original I have played from my 5 years. So I was really excited about Definitive Edition of first part. But I got strongly disappointed, mad and angry during all the games and especially the last mission in campaign "The first Punic war." You have only 50 of population limit, you get constantly raided from two AI players, both on land and on water (even with transport ships). You have to spare resources for your Wonder and then you have to destroy enemy wonder. No problem you will think? Well, if the AI has ton of heavy catapults with range 12+2, ton of monks with range 10+3 and you are not able to make more army than 25 it really sucks. You do not have heavy catapults, only stone throwers, if you will make cavalry, elephants, centurions, all gets smashed by heavy catapults WITH BALISTICS - so they will hit every target. And the cherry of the cake - your units are not able hold formations, and they are randomly stucking at each other and at terrain, sometimes the units got stuck for no reason.
So, this game cannot be compared to AoE 2, Stronghold, Command and Conquer etc. Even units in Total Annihilation are much more inteligent than in AoE 1 original and Definitive edition.
And it is really bad. The potential of remaster of this original game is huge. But from my point of view, it is not good.
10/10, great game, very fun and time consuming

I am a big fan of the AoE franchise and been playing it for over 20 years but this one has left me terribly disappointed. 

Graphics is great but AoE was always less about graphics and more about the gameplay. Key issues that are affecting the game are as follows.
1.  Pathfinding is terrible. Troops navigate so badly that it is often impossible to control them properly. 
2. Units can get stuck behind other units as every unit's occupied cell is quite big and often only a few troops can move simultaneously.
3. Troops don't always follow commands. I have troops in stand ground formation that keep moving around.
4. I have difficulty using transport ships. Safest way to load is one by one.
5. Priests have high variability is converting enemy units.
6. Sometimes when a resource is depleted, instead of going idle, villagers move into enemy areas and get killed.
7.  AI is weird, the enemies are sometimes tough even at easy level.

Many of the core aspects of this game are fantastic. The new graphics and gameplay functionality are wonderful, and manages to bring back some of the childlike nostalgia of 20+ years ago. It is a great upgrade to the original game series... except for what I feel is one glaring flaw: the unfair AI scripts.

After 75+ hours playing the game, I can say with certainty that the AI are not designed to play according to the rules of the game. For one thing, they always know where all your units are at all times, despite never building or using a scout to explore the map. They'll know as soon as they ready their forces, where your defenses are weakest, and proceed to somehow walk right through a defensive perimeter full of opposing units to strike at the villagers hidden somewhere inside your territory. I've tested this by having a villager run across the map, and far out of line-of-sight of some much slower military units, only to have the AI perfectly follow my villager across the map and back. When a human player's unit loses LOS to a unit, they give up; meaning the AI get to play with no LOS... which leads to some very ridiculous situations in which they attack villagers in far away places they shouldn't even know are there.

On top of that, player-controlled units seem to behave differently to AI-controlled units. Whereas the AI units spread out and attack as normal, my own units often get stuck on themselves, or randomly wander off. My units often get stuck on each other, and are unable to move when 2 or more units end up partially inside each other. The AI don't seem to have that problem, despite having their base units and buildings in very close proximity to each other. Another issue I have sometimes, is where units I've put on Defensive stance randomly wander off from the location I've tasked them to, despite an absence of enemy units. They pick up and move to another location beyond their defend area.

In the last match I played before writing this, I also had issues with my units retreating from an opposing unit they're in melee with. I had a squad of 20 hoplites retreat from one nearby (range 3-5) elephant archer because one of their number was being shot with an arrow. Now, I know that is normal for melee units being attacked at range (on defensive stance), but why does the entire group move with him? That is unusual, especially in a remake of such an old game. They were well within their defensive area, and should attack any enemy that comes into it.

Lastly, I wouldn't be surprised to find that the AI receive free resources throughout the match. This seems to be the new standard in numerous Real-Time Strategy games (like Dawn of War series, Age of Empires series, Halo Wars series, Company of Heroes series, etc) for the past few years; and even old games are being updated this way. I'm guessing it's an easier way to program AI; for the developers. This wouldn't be a bad thing, especially for those who like a seemingly-impossible challenge, but there's no way to turn off this benefit, even on the lowest difficulties. For someone trying to learn how to play RTS's, this is a very steep learning curve, and I can't be the only one who feels this way.

I hope that this game, and other RTS's, will include better fairness and difficulty controls in the future. Video games like this one need to be more accessible for those who can't keep up with the modern gamer (People with disabilities, illness, etc), but still want to enjoy this beautiful piece of history.

Age of Empires 1: Definitive Edition brings with it an inescapable dose of nostalgia, it's been more than 20 years since the original release until this edition. For those (like me) who played the original version at the time, you know very well what you'll find here, how you're going to play, shortcuts, difficulties, and everything else. Original AoE 1 is one of the greatest classics in the RTS genre and a lot has changed in the genre since then. For those who are having contact for the first time and already know the genre, you may find it a bit simple, but it is necessary to understand that the changes made here were more graphical, not in structure or gameplay, in general everything remains the same (although that they took the original song off the menu, that should be considered a crime!).
In short, for those who know it, it's wonderful, for those who already play the genre and don't know it, get to know the advances that happened in RTS 20 years ago.
For those who have never played and are not used to RTS, it can be a good way to get to know the mechanics, the time variables of each stage, but the tip is: if it is your first experience, consider lowering the difficulty level, as some stages are REALLY difficult.

We STILL have to hold a unit's hand to get them where they need to be in long transit from point A to point B. Clustering units confuses the units at times rather than allowing for smooth game play. I am simply giving a thumbs up due to the fine job the Devs did in the graphics upgrade, and I must say...I barely smashed the thumbs up. I just feel like they could have done better with AI. This, is a remaster of the greatest RTS to ever be made. The game has been polished up in every single way, and is one of the best games you can get your hands on if you are a fan of RTS games. Perfection.

Update: 7/11

They added "proper" zoom options and tweaked the AI on easier levels to be more manageable. The game still isn't anywhere near as smooth as it should be, some stuttering still happens when it shouldn't, the AI pathfinding is still a disaster and the UI is still just as intrusive, but the game is actually half-way playable now. I'm changing this to a very cautious recommendation, but only because it's still the only ancient era historical RTS we currently have. If the era isn't a draw for you and you just want a good RTS/Age of Empires game, you should still go with Age2, it's infinitely superior to anything else out there right now. If you do decide to purchase this, wait for a sale.

I mean, I love the AOE franchise. This franchise is undoubtedly my past, present and future gaming-wise. AOE 1, however, is easily the weakest link. I mean, it's understandable that it is the weakest link given that, even with this remaster, this game is ANCIENT.

The pathing is an obvious one. It sucks, characters can't move through other characters, and their hitboxes are extremely blocky, so your units can easily get stuck or maybe they'll just pick an incorrect route altogether. This isn't really frustrating to me though, I can deal with that with some shift-clicks.

I will say though, the ancient setting is really well done. The visuals of this game feel really cool and really hits home a feeling like it nailed being in ancient Roman times.

The game suggests that you can do a free for all with the AI...... DON'T TRUST IT, FREE FOR ALL's DON'T EXIST!!! In short 1v1v1v1 = 1v3. AI behavior is highly debated in these kinds of games, though, so take that with a grain of salt.

I went into the game for the first time since a child, thinking that it would be a lot easier now that it's been many years and hundreds of hours of gameplay later. I had forgotten. This AI must have blackmailed a genie or something, because as soon as those creatures find you (even though it already knows where you are), they will proceed to sent a never ending avalanche of whatever crap they feel like training. Sometimes it's a tsunami of Hoplites, sometimes it's a downpour of archers, and god forbid it chooses monks as well. Do you remember that scene in World War Z, where the zombies pile up against the wall? It's like that.

If there's a hole in your wall, they will find it. When they find it, the cavalry pours through. When the cavalry pours through... I don't want to talk about it...

Finding a promo copy of this game in a paper sleeve as a kid genuinely charted the course of my life, through high school, college, and now as a teacher of history. This Definitive Edition is aptly named, as all of the quirkiness and brilliance of the original release have been faithfully preserved, even as the visuals and sound have been beautifully overhauled. Thundering across the desert in Assyrian Chariots and holding the shield wall of Greek Phalanxes never looked so great!

My only complaint: this Age of Empires title receives the least support in the franchise, by far. I'm sure that the playtime stats speak for themselves by way of establishing development priorities, but I do wish that the devs would release more content for this game!

Pros:
 - Awesome units and army compositions. Everything feels useful and purposeful (though some more than others)
- Very aesthetically pleasing design, though lacking a little in diversity, not lacking at all in quality (not zoomed in of course)
 - More accurate to history campaigns than the original
 - Feels good most of the time

Cons
 - AI is simultaneously stupid and stupidly hard. Will micro every unit individually, yet won't fill transport ships with more than 5 units. Spams towers in random places for no reason, bum rushes your army with villagers, (some missions are broken because of that), occasionally just stops doing anything for extended periods of time. Will try to build a house right in the middle of your army, and yet ruthlessly stomp you if it can, when it can.
 - Some campaign missions suffer because methods aren't implemented to counteract their massively aggressive AI (The Holy Man and other similar ones specifically).
 - Occasional performance issues and graphical hiccups (Like all the map animations cycling back, visibly resetting)
 - Pathfinding suffers massively, constantly and painfully. I can't do it justice. While it's better than it was, it's still far, far from ideal and makes the quality suffer a great deal too.
 - Many of the achievements are horrible grindfests far beyond reasonable play. 500 heavy catapults? Seriously?
 
I love a lot of AOE: DE, but it has some serious teething issues with its AI and sometimes performance. Pathfinding is also a huge issue. That being said, I love the game's design, i love a lot of the history, themes and memories associated with it. It's rough, but it's a good hundred hours or so of fun if you don't mind dealing with some of it's issues. 

Overall, Don't expect this to be the best game. It's arguably the weakest in the series right now, and I don't see it getting any better (Yes, that includes AoM and the original AoE games), but for what it is, it can be fun. Once you're done with the campaigns, you'll likely struggle to find fun in the random map games due to the very limited map pool, along with the AI and pathfinding issues. Worth a purchase on sale or if you really want that ancient history itch scratched.

Age of Empires DE is exactly what it says on the tin. If you're nostalgic for the oldschool AOE 1 of your younger days this delivers that nearly perfectly. It's pretty, it's AoE, it's what you're paying for.

Word of warning though. The RTS genre advanced a long long way since AOE 1 came out. This might be a case of be careful what you wish for. AOE1's pathfinding was and is shocking. The addition of reseedable farms and idle villager buttons is a helpful concession to modern sensibilities but even prettied up AOE 1 is a bit samey and no longer a shining example of the genre. There are far better RTS games out there.

If you're okay with that, go ahead and grab the game. But it does need that buyer beware disclaimer.

I recommend it mostly to people who want to relive their childhood, are looking for something interchangeable with AOE2 but with a different vibe, or who want a different/classic RTS game that is new to them.

+ The game has very nice and detailed textures when compared to the old AoE game. The campaigns are very interesting and they have the "Easy" difficulty level, which allowed me to just play a chilled game and follow the story (which I'm mainly interested in).

Avoid buying this trash and go play the original. Unfortunately I left this game too long so I can't refund it. I thought "well the original was great so there's no rush to play it as I'm not that into RTS games". Biggest mistake. They absolutely butchered everything about the AI, everything from difficulty to the pathing.

The AI pathing makes you wonder if the devs even know how to actually make games. It looks pretty but its not really optimized well and the AI is total ass. So ass that it just makes them all look retarded.

Easiest way to scout the whole map = build an army and send them across the map. They'll split up that much that you'll likely have the whole map scouted by the time they actually reach where you told them to go due to them randomly splitting up for no reason, getting stuck on themselves and other objects which in turn makes them turn around and go in random directions..

The game is also more difficult than it should be. Harder than the original game that's for sure. Due to this, getting through the campaigns is just an annoyance and you're required to do cheese tactics as much as possible otherwise you get swarmed and lose. In missions that require you to eliminate multiple enemies, you'll get constantly attacked by them all 1 after the other, leaving you with no time to breathe and rebuild until you eventually just can't protect yourself anymore and have to restart.
Very obvious that the AI is a huge problem when only 5% of people that own this game have even completed a campaign.

It's a typical RTS thats been outclassed by its sequels (AOE2). Campaigns are the same (capture relic or destroy X) and some are just boring like the yamato campaigns. Only get this if you want a nostalgia trip, otherwise play other RTS games like Aoe2, RA2 or Broodwar that fullfill the same itch.

As a side note, the pathfinding really isn't bad at all. It's better than its contemporaries released around the same time and those complaining about it recently clearly forgot what it used to be like. Go try some dragoon micro from BW and AOE1 plays much better

If you care about being calm, happy and relaxed while playing a game, avoid installing this frustration bomb. If you're even considering buying this frustration simulator, don't bother. But if you did, make sure you don't play it for more than 2 hours and immediately go for refund.

On the off-chance you didn't take my advice, well, good luck, you're gonna need it. Set the difficulty to whatever you want, it will not make a difference, the difficulty on this game is completely broken. Oh and let's suppose you mistakenly saved at the wrong moment, you can't even restart the scenario, it will always load that save for you. The only way for you to restart the scenario is by dropping to the main menu and selecting Campaigns. How retarded is that? I mean Wacraft II got this right back in '95.

Graphics are kinda nice, though. But all in all, it feels like a retarded mid-school coding project gone wrong.

Stay away if you know what's good for you and your mental health. This application will break you. You have been warned.

The game tries. It really tries. But it fails miserably. It's a frustration fest. I can remember Warcraft 1: Orcs and Humans being more forgiving and actually enjoyable than this silly prototype of a game.
It has light years to go to even reach a decent level of playability.

The AI in the game (not the opponents, your units' AI) is horribly stupid. Collisions and units blocking one another resulting in both being blocked happen all the time. And this is a feature that needs to work 100% in order for you to actually have a shot at winning some mission. Except it doesn't.

Also, the difficulty levels are all wrong, playing on Standard, some missions are boringly easy, while others are mayhem, almost impossible to complete.

If horrible, utter pieces of trash games are your thing, though, maybe you could get some enjoyment out of it. But, again, keep in mind: this game really tries. Do not consider it a polished final product. It has decades of fixes and balancing to go before trying to even think it is a deliverable product.

Classic game I grew up with. If you played the original, and don't mind some of the clunkier aspects (AI, path-finding, etc.), it might be worth a buy for some nostalgia. A remaster of Age of Empires(1997), really well done. It's such a good remaster that it made people believe it was a complete remake, and not a lot of people give it credit for that.

The game functions more or less the same as the original, but with some updated stuff, such as:
Gather points
Traversable farms
Slightly more aggressive AI
Slightly better pathfinding
More intuitive UI
Rebalances to techs, civs and units.
A few more quality of life things.

I would suggest if you expect the game to be more or less the same as the 1997 release, then give the game a go. This game is by no means better than AoE 2, and won't be, even if they completely overhauled everything. 2 is more advanced, and is overall just a more complete RTS experience.

If you have any expectations that this game will be any better than the 1997 release, then this most likely won't be a game for you, since it can be pretty hard on unskilled RTS players, it's still the same game from 1997 with a lot of updated things. It still has some of the same bugs the original had and a few new ones even.

Overall, I like the game, despite that I grew up with AoE 2 when I was younger, I can still appreciate what the original did, and still enjoy it from time to time.

I'd say get this, if you:
Loved the original, despite its flaws.
Don't have any high expectations for the game to be anything more than an average RTS game.

However, do not get the game if you:
Expect this to hold a candle to modern RTS or even AoE 2.
Have bad patience.
Can't handle moderately hard games.
Have any high expectations for the game.
Expect this to have updates to mimic AoE 2.
Can't handle lowered frames when zooming.
Have only multiplayer in mind.

I know it sounds like the game is bad when I say all this, but I do like the game, and the original 1997 release with the Patch, I just think the reviews speak for themselves. It's not a game for people expecting it to be anything that is highly superior to the original, because it's really only a minor step up, outside of visuals.
