Age of Empires: DE is finally on Steam out of tosh Microsoft Store, making me squeeee my legs in nostalgia happyness remade with awesome graphics. Well, of non-AAA level. AoE1 was an old RTS, released somewhere between Red Alert and Starcraft 1. And it was real unique due to historical setting where you could go through ages. Well, ancient history only, from Stone Age where you find recources, to Tool Age where you build up farms, defences and may rush with units that you can't upgrade in Bronze Age which is where it gets hot and then Iron Age with it's many upgrades. It was great RTS for it's time because it hit that nice balance between economy and military. With economics you had four recources which had their uses and place in match progress. For example, you may not care about stone if you aren't going to build defences such as walls and towers. And of course you had to set up drop points for them. And food was quite detailed, as each food type has it's own gathering rate. Well, actually hunting and gathering had same rate before Definitive Edition. Using villagers to fish at shore is still Sonic fast while boat fishing and farming are the slowest kind.

So while it doesn't cover whole human history, the ages progress doesn't feel like just a reskin of units with better stats in this game. Compared to Rise of Nations and Empire Earth from what I know, that is. And it's historical. YEE, sending centurions on those axeman.
Yea, it's not historical accurate, it was designed to be Hollywood history of 90s kind, just read old interviews. Gamefied on top of that. Cue the unit called "Phalanx" that is upgrade from Hoplite. Those who don't know, Phalanx is troop formation of Hoplites in RL. AND they get some strange reskin on upgrade.

If you have played some other AoE games, here are some unique features of this game compared to other ones: Absolutely no defence at the first age for you can only build stone walls. No gates either, you have to close yourself and then Delete when you feel like leaving. Town centers have no defence by themselves, can't garrison either. But at least town centers are real cheap when you get to building more. Nations use one of the five architectural styles, real nice. They are defined by passive bonuses, like Greek getting discount on Academy (a place from which thousands aggitiated Aristotles in hoplite attire go to war) unit who are also faster along with ships, as well as what techs/units they don't get. There are no exclusive super units, but there are Iron Age super upgrades to certain units, very expensive, each nation get few. Oh, and size ratio of units to buildings is silly.

Definite Edition brought in balance changes. Mostly lessened passive bonuses while giving more techs to nations that didn't have them, homogenizing. There are now many QoL additions, such as farm reseeding, just press on icon in Granary. Siege projectiles fly faster, for they felt like on moon physics before. They also don't explode in gray dust, instead leaving a hole in a ground. 

Talking of graphics, it's freaking awesome. It's 2D prerendered of 3D models. And they managed to blow my 8-sided tiny Doom brain by including 32 freaking sides for units. And building destructions are now unique animations. Albeit they look weird, as if friction between each brick stopped existing and it all flopped, not like real building destruction. No skeletons for decaying units either, they cheapened out on this part. But overall, it looks awesome, especially shore environment, so much pleasant to my eyes, albeit I still miss colorful simple stuff of original, but!

Oh, and the biggest change is that farms are now walkable. They removed the houses from farm graphics too, they are just fields now. I kinda miss them acting like building, another thing that made AoE1 unique. But then again, you had to micro villagers around them so they don't block each other in their 1-space-wide inbetween tunnels. Yea, I was putting farms close. So I guess it's for the better.
But they left the trade mechanics as is. Not the tribute where you send recources to ally for real but mechanic to generate gold. You use trading boats and send them to anyone's port where 20 recources of your choice disappears into void, for no one gets it, and it generates gold for it once it gets back. Here is a funny thing: the amount of gold it will generate depends on the lenght of a route, the longer you get... OK, I lied. It's actually calculated by drawing a straight line between the chosen port and the closest port of yours to chosen nation. You can ruin it by building port closer, yes. Frankly, I don't think that many peeps used it.

And pathfinding, so much awful pathfinding without troop formations. It's actually better than original 80% of times, worse 20% when individual units calculate that choke point will be busy and go around half of a map, but overall less than acceptable.

Presentation meh. Well, it's as basic as original, but now they replaced the intro movie with battle to low-budget logo showoff. And there are no intros or outros for campaign. Even if they were like 10-seconds low-budget CGI renderings that sucked and had no plot in them. But QoL in interface tho, with it showing global queue and how many workers work on each recource. Music arrangement is lovely but I am disappointed that match-starting song is the first song from Rise of Rome CD instead of original CD which was ten times better. Could use original battle song for main menu too like original instead of what later became an AoE main theme.

You can also play original mode but only for custom matches versus AI.

And I am disappointed that there was not a single history or unit stats section in the game or nearby. Originals had manuals with info that they had back then on ancient history of nations. And there was help file as well in game files that you could access with F1 or so that included info and history bits on each unit and tech. Nothing here, save for campaigns where each mission has a map and historical info, updated over original. Much better too. Most missions were streamlined to waste less of start time. Some not as awesome, some are better. More consistent. But overall, it still feels like build and destroy for many missions without any story in-missions or much so it gets tiring. For example, in Rise of Rome campaign your objective is to build defences of towers at set spots and you think that it will help you too but enemies just run past it all and you have to defend yourself first until they run out of motivation and then you put towers which would be no different from destroying enemy at that point. So I only played a bit of campaign. 1/4 of it. Samey.

And they are all 50 pop caps. Which is the way that game was designed anyway. Being small enough to micro. Can increase in skirmish to 200 at least or 300, didn't check, I don't like it, without good pathfinding or troop formations. There is even upgrade that makes units of Barracks take half as much space, so.

While pathfinding sucks, AI enemies are better this time around. Until they get depressed after a hour of play. Tho sometimes they screw up and get stuck in stone age. Not as good as AoE2 tho either. Just play with them on Moderate or Hard. Hardest cheats, they will be in Bronze Age by the time you are in Tool Age.

Protip: Ranged units on higher elevations get bonuses!

Overall, nostalgia with great QoL changes. Loved it for what it is, as something they build up over original engine while trying to keep spirit same instead of becoming homoginized with AoE2, farms aside. Gonna force my friend to play it. 1v1 me Stone Age only, biatch.

And yes, this is where the original priests with their Wololo came from. Respect it. So precious.

'Twas 2001, the first time I played Age of Empires, an epic and unique experience for me. I was enjoying playing with the civilizations in antiquity, especially with the Romans. It was a little different and exciting since it was my first strategy game experience. Now, while playing Definitive Edition, I realized that I wish we were still playing the old versions, even if these games were out of date. The development effort called Remaster results in disaster in many games. They think they can sort out the job just by doing graphic polishing. However, since there are target groups that buy those Remaster games, I think the developer team doesn't care about the balance of the game because of it.

I enjoy playing Age of Empires Definitive Edition, but I also think some obvious bugs need to be fixed. Like, enemies directly rushing through your villagers, not the army they are facing with. That is obvious; there is an army full of swordsmen, archers and cavalries, but the enemy army is still searching my villagers, which these villagers staying behind the army and lots of walls. This is not how to make a game, this is a disaster! In other words, I do not think of how these errors escape from the eyes of the developer companies. There is a huge game developer company and a huge distributor company behind it, but they do not fix even the slightest obvious mistake. Look, I'm not saying that they can't fix it. They do not fix it.

Still, it is an old-school strategy game that unique and like an heirloom.
Microsoft cares their golden egg - AoE2- more than this game. Server crashing everytime i tried to play with my friends. Had to use the virtual LAN software. Server issues kill this game

This game is my childhood and it brings heaps of nostalgia. To see it come back with amazing graphics is a dream come true. Opening the game for the first time in more than a decade almost had me in tears, the music taking a hold on me. What epic themes! Sometimes I even forget I'm playing a game and just stare in awe at my towns and troops just living their best lives... 

The campaigns are fun but I must admit that the game mechanics are clunkier than AOE2. To me it doesn't matter as the fun I experience is timeless and priceless. Definitely worth to play (especially if you played it back in the day).

The game includes the content from the original game the Rise of Rome expansion. 

The only real shame is that the original opening cinematic isn't present, man that was just epic. I have found it on youtube and admittedly the years haven't been kind to it but it still gives me the chills. 

Would I recommend? Yes, I'll play this until I'm old and senile..

I played Age of Empires since I was a child at my grandpas and was expecting a nostalgic experience. So I really wanted to enjoy this game but sadly, it is unplayable. 

I am very experienced in RTS games but I struggled hard in some campaigns, which are supposed to be a casual experience. Before you smirk at me, I challenge you to play "Glory of Greece" ->  "Colonization of Ionia" on "Easy" and tell me it was a fun experience and since its on Easy, winable by any casual player.

- Upgrades seem to have almost no effect compared to an early rush in a normal game.
- Counter units dont seem to be of any real importance, since the lategame enemy AI often just mass produces every unit it can build and the mix is often what makes it the strongest army -> braindead gameplay.
- Dreadful pathfinding, feels even worse than original. What makes it even more worse is that units have a humongous hitbox which makes ordering units feel like its the most frustrating experience of your life.
- The AI doesnt seem to care if you go on Easy or Hardest in campaigns, it always plays the same. It micro manages every single unit, making it impossible to hit a ship with a catapult even tho that unit is the one of the only true counter.

On the whole, they did nothing to improve actual gameplay, maybe its even worse now. The only good thing they did is give it a better look, better music and hired someone to read out aloud the campaign storys. I would have paid 60‚Ç¨ for a working game but to charge 20‚Ç¨ for this is a joke.

It's a really good improvement over the original game, but has many flaws.

UI is broken, sometimes looking blurry and sometimes pixelated.

The textures are blurry, they aren't properly scaled.

The path finding is as bad as the original game.

So far I have only played a couple of solo matches against a couple of AI opponents (one on one at a time), and I am finding it frustrating as I get my butt handed to me (as Babylonians and Assyrians) by the Hittites and  Assyrians. * This could have been a great remaster. They took some great things from AoE2 and left look and feel of AoE. If only they made a good AI
* Enemy AI is buggy. Stops working at some point. You can see, that enemy units are not moving. Also, I have a very bad experience with AI on water maps. Played on a difficult level.

I'm already falling in love with this remastered classic! I had always wished that I could play the more ancient civilizations, and now, I can! And with all the excitement and challenge that made its successor great, too! For those that played the 97 game, this version is A BIG disappointment.
The game is prettier and some functions from Age 2 were implemented (like able to walk over farms and set destination for newly created units), but that's it.
The AI is as stupid as it used to be (leave a group of units unattended for 2 seconds and they all kill themselves), enemies blend in with the scenery (finding the enemy monk converting your units is harder), same pathway glitches (villagers stop working, units get stuck)...
I suppose the biggest problem was that the play style changed to something more aggressive, and while using the same 50 population limit, the game got caught between ''not Age2'' and but ''not Age1 anymore''.

The strength of the AI is just beyond absurd. I am playing on the second easiest difficulty and was hoping to have a chill game slowly building my empire and not worry too much about optimising. Out of nowhere I got mobbed by units I had no chance of beating, costing me the game instantly. Then I decided I'll actually give it a good go and see how well I can do. I was doing really well, keeping ahead of the AI and had an okay military to boot. Well that doesn't help when you're constantly swarmed by AI armies. By the time I finished one wave, another had arrived. It was relentless, and I ended up losing because of it. On the second lowest difficulty. This kind of behaviour is totally fine on higher difficulties, but the lower ones should be winnable by kids like in the original. Instead the AI is ruthless no matter what difficulty you select, and the idea of a casual relaxed game has been entirely removed. 

If you're good at RTS games and enjoy constant challenge then this game is probably fine. However, if you're like me and want to casually enjoy a game from your youth without worrying too much about optimisation or making the right moves? Stay far away. There is no such thing as casual play in this remaster.

I played the old version of AOE from a disc.  I bought this one because I changed PC and it didn't have a disc drive.  I thought this would be an improvement, they certainly charged enough for an old game.  Unfortunately it's really not.

The AI is bugged.  It was never really good in the old game but it was bearable.  This AI is really frustrating.  It's a real toss up whether they just ignore your instructions; career off in the opposite direction to what you tell them; or actually do what they're told.  

Sometimes they fool you and look like they're about to follow instructions, so you go to manage another part of the map that's in trouble, only to find they got bored and killed themselves trying to take down some random tower miles away from where you told them to go.

And just try and get them to get on that boat.  It was bad enough on the old version, this one is 10 times worse.  Apparently the little darlings can't possibly get on the boat unless the ground is just right and you click in the right place.  They would rather die.

Which brings me to the hit boxes.  There is no rhyme or reason as to where you need to click an item to get the desired result.  For example, if you try to get a stone thrower to attack a tower, you have to click on exactly the right spot (which varies from tower to tower) otherwise it just trundles up to the tower and sits there while it gets demolished.

Imagine.  You're in a battle.  You tell your Cavalry to attack some stone throwers and you tell your stone throwers to attack a tower.  The cavalry all shoot off in the opposite direction and the stone throwers just move towards the tower, peacefully waiting to get disintegrated.

Not only that but the difficulty settings are bugged.  One of my favourite scenarios (Holy Man) is impossible on Easy because the AI is completely bugged.  The only way you have a chance of completion is on hard mode - only then does the game act correctly at the beginning.  How can you sell a game where the easy setting is harder than the hard?

They appear to have rebalanced all the campaign scenarios - some of them work, while others definitely do not.

Basically, if you remember and played the old classic AOE, don't buy this.  It makes my nostalgia buds want to cry.  I'm buying a disc drive and firing my old classic up again.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, and write a positive review but it would be just like smiling through your teeth. But let's not get ahead of ourselves.

First let me point out what the remaster did right. The graphics, the music, and little QoL changes (such as farm reseed button, farms having no collision option, UI changes and so on) are spot on. These alone make the Definitive Edition look like a true remake. But frankly, that's about it. 

The reason why I decided to make it a negative review is because it doesn't "play" like a remake or even just a remaster. The units still have issues with colliding with each other and the pathfinding is still nearly linear (as in - a unit will try to go to their destination in a straight line, which was painfully apparent in the Hannibal scenario). Too many times I've had a situation where I had two Legion units stuck in themselves, unable to move. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. The attack-move command does nearly nothing - the units will bump into each other politely moving out of the way because they targeted some other unit at the back while attack-moving. Unless we're supposed to micro manage the whole fight unit-by-unit, I wouldn't say it's a well done feature. More than that I had many situations where I ordered a melee unit to attack another unit that was moving. My unit then just moved to the location the enemy unit was in, while the order is given and just THEN started chasing said unit. Things like these made me so incredibly sad about the state of this game. 

The AI is also another issue. Throughout the campaings it put up a reasonably good fight but only untill like 40 mins of the game. After that it just stopped attacking entirerly. When it came to me attacking however, I saw tons of units just stationed around their respective barracks not moving at all. I wonder if it's because of the difficulty setting (I was playing at "Standard" difficulty). Another fun little glitch I found is that you can bait the AI priests into converting a unit that has "No attack" stance - the unit will also not move and will not fight back when you attack it, allowing you to deal with the priests and then safely recapture the unit. I found out that it's most easily done with War elephants. Finally I'd like to mention the AI behaviour in random maps. I've played 4 player FFA where after scouting the map I had 3 other AIs at my base, even though I wasn't even first on the scoreboard (I'd assumed that they may join forces only if another player was a threat, but they consistently attacked only me for like 3 games).

Unless the whole "clunkiness" of the game was an intention of the devs - to trurly port a game from 1997 with all of it's flaws, then I would say that they made a job well done. But if not, then I'd just reccomend you getting a dosbox or some other way to just play the original 1997 release - you will get the same experience, with worse graphics but at least it may save you the price of the remaster.

Updated Review:
Got my hopes up with the April 2021 patch.
Unfortunately, the game is still broken by horrendous pathing.  
(Worse than the original game.)

Units still:
-Get stuck on each other.
-Block each other.
-Bunch up in immovable clusters.
-Turn to face left/right/left/right...instead of moving (inside the cluster.)
-March the way you don't want them to, if units block their way.
(IE units take off heading East, if you told them to walk West, however, units were blocking a pass / river crossing to the west.)
-The game is more of "fight the interface" and "constantly monitor for stuck units" rather than "fight the enemy."

Try to guide Hannibal over the alps through mountain passes.
You can't.
(Unless you click on every-single-unit-you-own, individually, and select a series of waypoints.
Try doing that for all 20+ units you get.

It's funny when you realize - the actual Hannibal had an easier time moving his army than we do in this game.

Really sad.  They went through all the trouble to make gorgeous graphics, music...good balance...
Just to ruin it with where it matters most:

MOVING YOUR ARMY!

(PS - Approximately 60 hours of my 87 hours played was reloading my saves to try to move my units again, or undo disaster because they got stuck.  Wish I were joking.)

If you've played Age of Empires II, then it'll be pretty easy for you to get started with this game.

However, if you're expecting it to be a lot like AOEII, you'll probably be a little disappointed with the seeming lack of features such as gates, unique units, garrisoning and so forth. It's also a bit disappointing that all units, regardless of civilization, speak only Latin(?). But despite these missing features, you'll have fun with the game.

If there is one thing that AOE does far better than Age of Kings, it's in its cheats. Think monks are too slow and weak? There's hoyohoyo for you. Thought AOEII's cobra cars were a bit weak against building? Well, say hello to Winsett's Z cars. Oh yeah, and did I mention that you can also spawn a tricycle-riding baby wielding a shotgun?
It's nice to be able to play this classic again.

The release of this game was terrible. The graphics looked amazing, yet the gameplay had no improvements to the original game released 20 years prior.

At this point in time, there have been certain improvements. However, these improvements do not make this game stand up in 2021. Do not buy this game, do not play this game, as it is also dead at this point. Buy AoE II: DE for the definite Age of Empires experience and ignore this one if you can. It has everything this game has, but better.

I *really* want to recommend this game - age of empires 1 was probably the first game I ever played, and beyond the nostalgia, is still a pretty fun rts, even today. The Definitive Edition has some really good and welcome improvements on the original - The graphical overhaul is beautiful, the quality of life changes are great. 

But there is one very large, glaring problem stopping me from recommending it to people: Pretty consistently, when you're well into a random map game the ai will just......stop. All its units will cluster near its town center, if it has any boats on the water they'll hang out in one place, its villagers will continue to gather but just keep finding more and more distant sources of resources, and the ai will make no attempt to win the game. It ruins any game that isn't finished within 40 minutes to an hour. 

I really hope this gets fixed, because aside from this game breaking issue, I love everything about the extended edition. I like how aggressive the ai is, I like the QoL improvements like the UI that shows idle villager locations and how many villagers are on what resource. I love being able to set higher population limits in random map games, and building farms that are similar to those in AoE 2. I think the work they've done on the art is fantastic, and looks excellent. The redone music is really good. But this one bug is holding it back. I know that this isn't exactly the priority over at microsoft, so I'm not really holding my breath, but if they do fix it, I'd heartily recommend AoE 1 DE.

PROS:
1. Nostalgia: AOE was pretty much the first game I ever played, although at that age I didn't really know what I was doing. This edition really gives you an opportunity to go back 20 years
2. Graphics & visuals: I really loved how the original game looked and it looks like in definitive edition they kept original style but with better details and resolution 
3. No technical issues for me 
CONS:
1. Pathfinding is awful, units get stuck all the time. Boarding groups of units into a transport is a nightmare 
2. Campaign AI / scripting: it's really hard to enjoy campaign missions because of AI. Sometimes AI will attack you in early game, but then just stops all of a sudden. Sometimes it just sits on a base does nothing, waiting to die. And a few times it does it's best, giving player a very small room to breathe. 
That was the biggest issue for me. Campaign makes huge difficulty spike up and down and it's hard to enjoy the same either way. I understand that all issue might have come from the original game, but in my opinion, it's not good enough excuse for a $20 game

[h1]Things that I like:[/h1]
- updated visuals and soundtrack
- 61 entertaining campaign missions with interesting historical background information
- new comfort functions such as freely assignable hotkeys, automatic field renewal and idle villager button
- working online multiplayer with elo system
- a manageable amount of achievements encourages play in a positive sense

[h1]Things that I would change/improve:[/h1]
- pathfinding (to be fair the developers are in the process of fixing it)
- adding in steam workshop support
- implementing different unit skins for all factions similar to what has already been done to the buildings
- fixing errors in the German translation

This game was the introduction to many now-adults. It was easy and actually kind of fun at it's youth. The 90's/2000's game was good for newcomers of this game genre. This game started it all.

The definitive edition has forgotten all that. It could have ended the trend. The devs call to make the game a lot harder was not, and still isn't, appreciated. Age of empires 2 DE seems a lot easier. But taking the comments and feedback and making ANOTHER game doesn't fix this one.

So in all technicality, It's not recommended to buy this game. They cared more about making this a prototype. We gave the feedback and they made ANOTHER game. It's not worth buying.

PS:Has anybody tried playing a campaign? Well... I played the first level called "Holy man". It's just, the original leaves the only man you have with something like half health. Here? It's 1 HP! You could have died otherwise!

In short, The original was sweet. This one's bitter.

The RTS that started the saga that is AOE well to a degree at least...

I have some mixed feelings regarding this release, while this is a great game and I did enjoy playing through it there was some elements which I found very annoying.

Pro's:

Good old Age of Empires.
Aesthetically pleasing graphics overhaul.
Good Music and Sound.
Some QOL improvements but nothing ground breaking.

Con's:

HORRENDOUS Unit pathing. Some of the worst I have ever seen.
Campaign missions are insanely difficult. Even on the easiest difficulty.

While I can understand the unit pathing is not something they can change since its a product of its time, my biggest problem is that the AI just spams units into your base with no cohesion or tactics. Had to resort to cheesing my way through almost all of the campaigns missions because of this even on the easiest difficulty. It also seems the campaign difficulty options make no difference. I never had this issue with Age of Empires 2 HD Edition with the campaigns on standard difficulty.

So while I did enjoy this game it still has some issues that need to be cleared up. I would highly recommend rather playing Age of Empires 2 HD Edition (2013) which is the vastly superior sequel and has waaaay more content.

TLDR: Enjoyable old school RTS with some issues.

And here is a hint: I have just read in other comment that logging back (after you accidentally logged out like me :D ) to the xbox live is not possible on windows 10, Here is the way: you will need to enable (I advise to temporary only!) the scripting host in the registry:
[b]HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows Script Host\Settings[/b]  add a new REG_SZ (string) with the name [b]Enabled[/b] and the value [b]1[/b]. After it you can log back to the xbox live.

Overall a great game but it does have some frustrations. I appreciate its a remake of the original but the pathfinding is infuriating, especially in crowded cities. I am glad since I first started playing they have added a few non original features like being able to set units to defensive mode and catapults to no attack stance. 

The campaigns are quite fun and whilst scenarios should be challenging sometimes they are nigh on ridiculous, maybe I'm a bad player but sometimes its taken me 3hrs to clear one scenario in a campaign. The AI even on easy is very aggressive and usually rush you within minutes of starting. 

Anyway I'd rate this game 8.5/10. I do also wish like A02 DE the developers might consider some new campaigns.

I wanted to recommend this and it is so close to being an amazing game... but some flaws are just too big to get over them.

First, a positive note: game looks and runs great. Atmosphere is awesome and I do think devs did a fantastic job there. Truly, spirit of the original is captured here...

That being said, AI is where this game falls flat. It straight up cheats, and not in a subtle way. I could live with game giving slight edge to AI on higher difficulty settings, but AI cheats massively even on easiest setting. You can literally wall off player, cut him off resources and he will just keep spamming the most expensive units in ridiculous numbers. This varies slightly between missions, but because of it, some take more than an hour to pass... on EASIEST setting!

I finished just one campaign in 20 hours of play and I have decided not to play anymore until devs decide to balance the game a bit. Doesn't have to be perfect, just not straight up insane. If they do that, they will get my whole-hearted recommendation.

This game is good. It runs smoothly. It plays well. The art and animations are all well done. Different civilizations are all clear. Everything in that regard is great. Most of the negative reviews here on steam seem to just not be aware of some of the quirks in the Age of Empires games, particularly regarding movement. It's always been like this.

That said, I think in general AoE2 is a better game than AoE1, and the only case I would really recommend this game as opposed to the Definitive Edition of AoE2 would be if you want the older civilizations here and know that you're getting a game that isn't quite as refined, but nature of being based on the older game. I don't mean there's any problems technically, just that the later time period comes with some advancements in in-game tech and units and whatnot that make AoE2 better.

But if you're okay with that, this is a fine game. I would wait for a sale. I paid 5 bucks and am very happy with my purchase! Full price, I might feel a little unsure.

Unless all you want to do with this is random maps with AI then it's a game INSPIRED by AoE1, but it isn't AoE1 and it's certainly not definitively so.

EDIT AFTER RECENT PATCH: UPDATE 46777

1. [strike]Most of the time[/strike], units get stuck on each other and the environment. (not as often)
2. [strike]The unit path finding is the worse I've ever seen in an RTS.[/strike] (most significant fix!)
3. Some units do nothing while stuff is happening to them in defensive stance.
4. [strike]Unit models have an absurd about of space around them, which creates the illusion that they can stand closer to each other, but they cant. Trying to cram a group of units into a small area for an ambush is a joke.[/strike] (this is somewhat fixed)
5. When you select a group of units and you click on a location, some units may run in the other direction for no reason. 

It's not a broken mess now, but there are still significant balance issues. If you throw 10 villagers at a 1st tier soldier, the villagers should have some form of chance to survive. Not in this game, that 1 soldier will slaughter your entire village.

Update: Saw that yesterday they released a bug fix and decided to reinstall it and give it another go. I did the dungeon crawl mission with the elephants, in which I had lots of issues with units getting stuck, and it went much much smoother this time. Didn't have a single unit get stuck, they still body block each other but I can live with that, and units no longer move in the opposite direction of where they're told to go. I'm quite lenient with games and I give them a chance til the end and I've played a fair amount of lower quality indie games but never have I ever played a game this off-putting that is not even worth giving a shot. The game starts promising and the Yamato campaign was really good but the rest was just ruined by bugs. The most game breaking one is mainly horse and elephant units getting stuck in other units constantly - there was nothing more infuriating than when you're being attacked with full force and your units keep getting stuck. Adding to the flames the pathing is bad and there is a bug to it as well. Units will block each other and get stuck on the smallest of pebbles. The bug is when horses attack workers they will run up to them do 0 to 1 hits if the worker is moving and then give up on attacking them. Units also have issues when moving as a group - if they are spread out some of them might go in the opposite direction in which they were told to go and they don't adjust their speed to the slowest unit in the group. All of this combined makes the game next to unplayable at times. A side note is that I personally don't like the priests' conversion ability because of the RNG which can be easily countered by just saving while your units are walking up to them and keep loading back til RNG works in your favor. The game genuinely feels like it's in an early beta state and if they fixed all of the issues the game does have potential to be good and the Yamato campaign is proof of it because that campaign was great mainly because most of the time you weren't affected too much by the bugs.

This is a historically important game, and likely a contender for my favourite game of all time. That said, I cannot recommend this game in its current, and likely forever future state. The AI is incredibly hostile, even on the easiest setting, making most campaigns (the reason you're likely looking to buy this, nostalgia) completely impossible. As it stands the AI can out produce and rushes you at the outset of any sort of interaction, which makes starting off with a single Priest an impossible task. If you are hunting for the Age of Empires of old, you're best off buying Age of Empires 2 DE, which is the current and all time gold standard for RTS games.

AGE OF EMPIRES was my first proper PC game back in 1997/1998. it's what got me into strategy games and i loved it. I would play nonstop and it's probably my favourite game off all time. It wasn't perfect but back in 1997/1998 this game was the shit!

I'm happy to inform you that this game is still so much fun to play. Yeah sure AGE OF EMPIRES 2 has features that this game would have loved too have and AGE OF EMPIRES 2 is the better game overall. This game is set in a different time, much earlier than AGE OF EMPIRES 2. I actually find the older CIVS, TECH and UNITS more interesting. You can battle through 10 campaigns on this version and also add custom campaigns if you wish. 

Offcourse the game is looking gorgeous now with the updated graphics and you have added feature such as a zoom further out and in option.The multiplayer dosent seem very populated but there are always some games going on. This game is worth it for the single player anyway. The game seems to get small updates every once in a while too. 

I saw the release off this game on the microsoft store with a few problems and bugs, AI issues but the updates have done a decent job in improving it since then.It's already had a patch but it will need more to iron out a couple BUGS i've seen but it's not a game breaker. The ones i seen anyway. 

One last note - This game will work on WINDOWS 8.1.It runs perfectly fine and i've only had one issue which was the sound. There is a thread that is pinned on the forum for WINDOWS 8.1 users that is an easy fix for the sound. You can play this on WINDOWS 10 and WINDOWS 8.1!

This classic game is a must buy for strategy lovers!

It's as good as I remember it from the original release, although may not be as technically perfect like the second or third game, Age Of Empires : Definitive Edition still has a lot of heart to it, it's art design, soundtrack and character sounds are still my favorite in the series. With a splash of high definition to all of it's aspects, it's an almost perfect example of a remaster. 

But as mentioned before, it has mechanical faults, the character path-ing is horrendous - as units just follow whatever direction they choose on their own even if it means they'll have to move halfway across the map to cover a tiny distance, and often times 2 different units can clip through each other and get stuck, they may get unstuck if you're lucky but you'll eventually have to kill one to free the other, I may be wrong but I believe these bugs existed in the original release as well.

But the worst sin of AOE:DE is it's campaign difficulty, it is extremely difficult on "Normal" difficulty for some reason, and leaves no room for error in the starting minutes of some missions, and now there's lots of these new missions with terrible designs, for example : requiring you to convert enemy villagers and start a new civilization with just one priest all the while other cities are hunting said priest, or move from point A to point B with a given number of units, in a path littered with hordes of enemies and towers.

But it's still a fun game if you're willing to overlook it's drawbacks. Plenty of hours (atleast 70 hours) to kill in the campaign missions, deathmatch or multiplayer - which still has a lot of players in it. There's also the map editor, which is always fun to experiment with.
If you like RTS, played other AOE games, or played the original AOE1, then this should have plenty of value for you.

Having grown up with this game and played countless hours of the original Age of Empires as well as this game, sadly, I have to give this a thumbs down. You'll see why in just a minute.

Now, Definitive Edition (or AOE:DE) by itself, like the original (and the Rise of Rome expansion) is a great game, however, it seems like the developers don't even care about this game at all. 

This is the game that started it all (that's what they said), but it has received no respects from its devs. 
No events being hosted, no regular updates, and bugs have existed for months, heck, even years, but has not been resolved. 
(There are "maintenance", but that's happening on all the sequels at the same time, so that doesn't count.)

The people who read the bug reports for DE has always been the other people in the community, I have yet to see any post that actually got a response from an actual developer for this game. 
(I know this cause I read all the ones in a list gathered by a community member)

Overall, the only reason why I gave it a thumbs down, is because of the developer's attitude towards the game, and its players in general.

If you're getting this game, you should only get it on a sale of at least 75% or higher if you don't want to waste your money on those who are never going to fix, or even care about the game you paid for to play on.

Thanks for reading. You have a good day now. 
I'll change my review if what I said above is no longer true. We'll see how long it takes.

After having completed the campaigns and achievement hunting all I could, Here's my Review for Age of Empires Definitive Edition:
-
I really like the time period this game takes place in which is something none of the other AoE titles have. Growing your civilization from the Stone Age to Tool Age, Bronze Age, and all the way up to the Iron Age to duke it out with the enemy civilization is so satisfying.  And the soundtrack is godly beautiful. Even the opening cinematic alone gave me goosebumps and sometimes gets me choked up. When I first started the game and saw that, I knew I had to give this game a fair chance after I bought it. And I'm so glad I chose to get into this and Age of Empires II DE. (My thoughts on AoE II will be separate from this one)
.
As far as gameplay, RTS hasn't been a common genre of mine, but I ended up liking this quite a bit. The civilizations all have their unique strengths and weaknesses which keeps the game exciting in it's own unique way. The fact that there's no perfect civ keeps anything potentially game breaking out of at least the campaign and online multiplayer. (If it's a local game against Ai then that's the only exception if you want to use cheats.)
.
Following the history of Ancient humanity through the many perspectives of civilizations like Babylon, Rome, Egypt, Carthage, Greece, and many others is really refreshing and intriguing. 
While the History taught in this game is already in history books throughout schools, libraries and searchable online, apart from slight deviations in how our educational system wants to tell these stories. 
.
There's something about playing through historic battles as a given empire. Building up your Economy and Military force along the way, and finally crushing your enemy in battle. Just interacting with the world in that way which you just cannot get from reading a book or watching a documentary about these same subjects. But that's the beauty of video games for you.
.
Overall, I would totally recommend Age of Empires if you're into the RTS Genre. It is so worth it to me.

I won't lie - This is probably my favorite strategy game of all time. I know that the second game in the series has made many improvements to the gameplay, but I still prefer this one, because this ancient era interests me more than the medieval era. I also think that many of those improvements that the sequel made has been brought back to the first game via this Definitive Edition. Of course not all of them, but most of them. I think it still plays great today and most players will be able to enjoy this game even now, more than 20 years after it was released. If you like strategy games or history, then I think you should definitely at least give it a try.

Played the original a looong time ago when it was first released.  Upgraded graphics and game play makes it even more fun.  Some of the same original bugs still exist, such as units getting stuck together and priests not converting troops but if you know the workarounds, it is still really fun.

Don't get me wrong, I LOVED the first chapter of Age of Empires, in all means, but this has some HUGE problems that make me impossible to review it positively.

The most annoying thing, is the movement of formations.
Units always go to different areas instead of where you're actually clicking it for moving them, making it so frustrating to execute an attack or anything similar.

Second, units get stuck sometime, making them impossible to move. This can often lead to lose those units if the enemy is attacking them.

All the rest is quite acceptable... and if it wasn't for the two problems I previously described, I probably would be very happy to recommend this game positively.

But at this stage, I suggest you to avoid it and go for the second or third chapter.

The new look is indeed eye candy. Immersion is even better than it was back in 1997. Good narrator, here and there some humorous lines. Real cool remake of the original game from 1997.

There are some significant downsides to the gameplay though. 

- The pathfinding AI is sometimes just dumb. Units are not able to circumnavigate certain cliffs. They struggle to take narrow "entrances". Instead they might get stuck on cliffs. It also can happen that units jam other units close to them causing them to get stuck and unable to move in any direction. Selecting individual units trying to "untangle" them does't help any. It takes some time for them to idle and be able to move again.

- Priests tend to be disobedient. You can order them to heal a unit but instead of healing, and when necessary following them, they stop healing the unit they were ordered to heal and try to heal another unit which often results in the death of the unit they are supposed to heal. 

- Conclusion, babysitting your units is in order to avoid "unfortunate" outcomes of battles in too many situations.

The original Age of Empires was a pretty awesome game when it came out, but after growing up with AoE II and III, in retrospect it's insanely primitive. This DE remaster is imho my favorite out of the DE series as it does the best job addressing the most common issues with the original game while retaining its quirky gameplay mechanics to a T. It turned a game which, in 2021 is not really all that enjoyable, into something I could totally see wasting a few hours in here and there.

The main changes are graphical. The art has been completely re-modeled or re-rendered up to very high resolutions, though they have also retained the original game art it seems which is very cool.

If any of the three AoE games deserved and would benefit most from a remaster, it's this one, and I think they struck a very good balance here.

My only complains with the game are with the sound and music. While they did a really remarkably good job trying to echo or stick to the sounds of the original game (except obviously at better than 8-bit depth!), there are a few sounds which are irritating like stone mining which is rather unpleasant sounding. Ironically the bird sound from selecting/building towers which was horrendously irritating in the original is now much improved with the replacement, so, hit or miss.

The remastered music I think was really quite well done... aside from the fact that it's absolutely swimming in way too much reverb. The original game was DRY MIDI sounds (depending on your soundcard of course), or at best, moderately reverby CD audio. That gave the original soundtrack this really nice clarity and driving rhythm which kept the songs moving, and in which EVERY sound was equally and clearly audible. With all this reverb and admittedly nicer samples, it just sorta gets mushy at times and less enjoyable because you just can't hear the intricate details of the rhythms and counterpoint which made the original score enjoyable in the first place.

Now, the one thing to keep in mind is AoE is pretty cartoony. Dudes with big spiky sticks walking around and slapping each other upside the head. The game is by far its most fun and adventuresome in the early game through the stone and bronze ages, and sort of becomes a nasty slog by the late game, at least to me. It's sort of like if you turned the attitudes and perceptions people had about the ancient world from the time of classic movies like Jason and the Argonauts and Ben Hur into a video game. The idea of little early settlements waging skirmishes and protecting hunting grounds is really a lot of fun, but to me it falls way short when you get to the Iron Age with the lack of formations and primitive AI. For that, you're better off with Ensemble's other take on the ancient world, Age of Mythology, or for a historical purist approach, 0 A.D.

So with that minor nitpick aside, I do recommend this game to anyone who wants to dip their toes in early AoE! Just keep in mind that despite the pretty looks it still mostly plays like a 90's game, and that's imho a good thing. :)
Dope

I feel bad giving this a thumb's down. I can tell the developers meant well and put some love into this. It LOOKS and sound great too.

But do I recommend you play it? No.

You may be tempted to return to the original Age of Empires if you're nostalgic for the days when you'd log onto your dial-up and peruse various shoddy websites for new game demos. It was a really cool game back then. No sci-fi or fantasy trappings, just historical campaigns based on real empires and eras on our planet.

But man it has no aged well. You just can't go back to the grandfather of this franchise. Age of Empires II expanded and improved SO MUCH on the original that it's barely the same game and I can't recommend spending time with AOE1 now that both have received a very generous helping of remastering.

At the core of it, AOE1 is just clunky. The population caps are lower, the units have no concept of how to group up properly, building placement and tiling feel much finickier, the gameplay is sluggish on slower speeds and then cartoony on higher speeds, and the AI is a cheating poohead. You feel like you're micromanaging a couple of sluggish, braindead soldiers every second you're playing, trying to stay ahead of an AI who is perfectly managing dozens of units at a time, simultaneously, always.

The campaigns feature some really cool settings, some undercovered in games (Hittites?) and others very well represented (Rome, baby). But the actual missions are just obnoxious. Sometimes you're pitted against way too many AI opponents, all perfectly managing their armies, while you're stuck with 50 POP to fight them all off. Others require managing a tiny force to near perfection. It might be less annoying if the game's unit pathing and lack of unit formations didn't leave me feeling like I was fighting the game more than anything.

I don't want to rain on anyone's parade. Again, this doesn't feel like a cash grab at all. it feels like a labour of love. I just don't know how much I love the original anymore and no amount of fancy building destruction animations can change that.

 Looking for a unique experience? Watch as the game you know and loved from the Kellogg's cereal box gets turned into a circus, where you feel like bombad Jar Jar Binks directing an army of defiant cats. 

No matter what you tell them, your units will do their own thing, often the direct opposite, and they love getting stuck on top of one another in clumps, like clusters of sleeping felines. It doesn't help that priests need a lot of convincing to heal nearby units, often they walk away all together, not wanting a bar of it. Even when the unit is just behind another unit in front of the priest, he just won't do it, and the others won't budge to let him through. I know we are losing faith these days, but this game is not meant to be a reflection of modern life!

The enemy doesn't help things by being comically on the ball. This, combined with your incompetent cat army just makes you feel like a failed commander. Just like in school when you were chosen to be the leader and nobody wanted to follow your directions.  

If you are prone to gamer rage, DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME - you might find yourself sectioned in a mental asylum, and when you return home there will be a smoking crater where your PC once was.

What this game is NOT: A reboot of the original. The 'HD Edition' of AoE2 greatly improved its namesake and they later remastered it even further with the definitive edition, overhauling the AI yet again including the visuals not to mention some quality of life improvements.

This is just the same old AoE1 made to work better on modern hardware. Minimal quality of life improvements, minimal changes.

What this game IS: A supplier of memories. This was the first strategy game I played on a computer back in the mid 90s and I loved it. It got me into history as more than just a school assignment and it set me on a path I would never wish to change.

It may not have aged like a fine wine but it sure does feel good to reminisce every now and then. If you have never played the Age of Empires series then I suggest you instill yourself with the power of an open mind and play this first. Travel back in time to the 90s when there was nothing really like this (yes I am aware there were other strategy games, but nothing involving history) and enjoy what it was like for me when I was a kid.
THEN, after having fulfilled yourself with the taste of a classic, get into AoE2 where the real changes were made to make it into the legend that it became.

This was the first RTS I ever played as a kid.  I just absolutely adore this game, and I get this sense of wonderment whenever I start it up.  The fact that they remastered the entire series in the past few years just lends itself to how excellent a title this is, and I'm really happy to be playing through it again.

One of the things that makes this game so magical is building your settlement into a city, and even a fortress if you want it to be.  The way you utilize your villagers is what allows you to be victorious, and that's never been more clear than playing against stiff competition.  It's just the computers for now, but they are giving me a run for my money.  And I gotta say I'm enjoying playing by myself, but I'm pleased to be able to note that it appears there's still a competitive scene for these games.

Age of Empires is where my love of RTS titles began, and it is wonderful to see it remastered not only for myself, for any other person who wants to spend some hours civilization building.  I used to have a go to culture back then, but these days, I just go with the flow.  And if you're a fan of great games that don't stifle your cash flow, you gotta be on Steam.  All three Age of Empires, completely remastered with all expansion packs for under 50 bucks.  Thank you very much, and I will come again.

The first Age of Empires is a unique, simple RTS game that puts you into the basic premise of gathering resources in order to develop technology and evolve from the Stone Age to the Iron Age, while you sustain your civilization battling your enemies with axes, bows and arrows, swords, lances, chariots, ballistas, catapults, elephants, wololos...

This game got fastly superseeded by its ultra-famous sequel, Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings, which translated all of this into the Medieval Era and added new features, content, and made the overall experience more welcoming for RTS newbies. So don't forget this: Age of Empires Definitive Edition is a remaster of the PREQUEL of Age of Empires II, and that means that still holds up with almost all of the original game features (plus some quality of life improvements), and thus you will not find the same features as in AoE II. That means no formations or no wall gates, for example.

Does that mean that this remaster is basically for veteran players that want a technical remaster of the same old game? As one of them, sure, I'm really enjoying it a lot. But this game has the charm of classic RTS that has been mostly lost this day with modern titles, and still has a lot of fun to deliver with the classic formula revamped and wraped in a glorious visual upgrade and amazing remade soundtrack, making it a very recommendable experience for anyone who feels attracted for the idea of a RTS set in the Ancient Era. Babylonians, assyrians, hittites, persians, egyptians, minoans, yamato, shang... there are not many RTS games out there that give you the chance of playing with such civilizations. And yes, you still have classic romans, greeks, carthaginians and so.

So don't be afraid, get this jewel of a RTS and jump into the real old times hunting elephants, developing the wheel, finding ruins and artifacts from even older times, preparing a huge phalanx horde, or even going full wololo and converting every enemy to your side. This is a wonderful remaster for one of the best classic RTS out there, and truly deserves more love.

In an era where RTS gaming is already dead, Microsoft has resparked interest in the genre by remaking its THREE signature games. Age of Empires Definitive Edition is a built-upon remake of a classic, with much MUCH better visuals. The graphics are totally stunning, shadows make the game look quite fantastic. Whether you want to play with friends or play single player, this game has got you covered. There are 9 campaigns in total to sink a dozen of hours in. With over 16 civilizations, there's plenty of replayability in this game (and plenty of strats to try out). As compared to other remade games, Age of Empires Definitive Edition still lacks a proper pathfinding system and a proper Art of War campaign to get newbies to really learn how to manage their online games since I've personally found that playing against the computer is NOTHING like playing versus real humans (hence why an Art of War campaign should be present to get you to grasp things like: When you should age up, when you should swap vils into gold production etc...). Furthermore, there is a new "Rank System" involved with Multiplayer that, after a couple of games of calibration, puts you in an ELO that you have to grind. It's fine if you play Ranked Games 1v1 since then you'll only have yourself to blame for getting utterly destroyed.

However, this seemingly perfect game is still, to this day, in dire need of balance patches. In ranked, people still spam OP civilizations like Macedonians with +5 Hoplite armor (literally invincible against any other civ) and Greeks with increased movement speed for Centurions that will leave you flat in 10 mins if they rush your busy-farming peasants. With the right balance fixes and improving on the pathfinding, this could be as good as Age of Empires II or III; but it seems like Microsoft has already abandoned ship with this project and is more focused on making AOE II and III better. It's still a great game if you force those who join your lobby to go for Random Civs on Random Maps. For me, this is a solid 9.1/10. A great RTS game with a great online community that will teach you how to play and will mostly not rage if you fail in 2v2s or 3v3s.

[h1]Solid recommendation for people wanting to revisit the game and to newcomers to the series alike.[/h1]

¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†[b]A[/b]ge [b]o[/b]f [b]E[/b]mpires is one of the most important strategy games in history, a true titan in its genre and a classic position. I had a lot of concerns about the remaster of this game. On the one hand, it fully deserves second youth, on the other - by today's standards are a pretty bare-bones RTS mechanics-wise, in many respects it is an archaic position and there is not much room for developers of the remaster who want to remain faithful to the original from 1997.
Fortunately, after a dozen or so minutes with the game, I breathed a sigh of relief - apart from the beautiful audiovisual setting, AoE: DE is a game extremely faithful to the original, avoiding making changes to the gameplay (for better or worse), apart from what is absolutely necessary for its proper functioning (mainly multiplayer).
Although I would love to see the first part recreated in the convention of the current AoE II: DE, an honest remaster required restraint and the creators definitely showed it, focusing on the complete reconstruction of the entire visual setting, which significantly improves the experience of the game. Compared to the original - it's a real eye candy.

¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†At the moment, both in terms of the content and quality of the product as a whole - there is nothing much to criticize.
For some time after its premiere, the game has had some problems with proper functioning, especially AI, fortunately everything has been patched up and Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is now working very nicely.

¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†[b]A fantastic way to relive your first time with AoE - lots of fun for single and multiplayer enthusiasts.
If you know what you're getting into - I recommend it with all my heart! Especially during promotional campaigns on Steam - you can complete the entire series for a fraction of the normal price.[/b]

¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†By the way - I also highly recommend going back and checking the original release with 'The Rise of Rome' expansion. It's as playable as it ever was and still has a lot of magic after all these years. It should run fine on modern systems, and in case of any issues- there's a decent number of solutions to overcome them. It's worth it- not only because it's part of a history.

People complaining about the jankiness of unit movements clearly don't remember (or have never played) the original game. This remaster plays exactly how I remember the old Age of Empires, and yes, units do get a bit stuck unless you know how to manage them. Starcraft is the same, as were so many other RTS games of that era. I still have the original Starcraft and Age of Empires installed, so I can definitely confirm the unit movement issues.

I bought this remastered version because the original Age of Empires does not scale well on 1080p monitors and each new update of Windows 10 causes compatibility issues that I'm sick of trying to fix.

Now to the remastered version. It looks very good and runs beautifully on modern machines. The music has been upgraded but still has the original melody and the sound effects have also had the same treatment. It's a blast hearing the same units and music from over 20 years ago, now in crisp HD quality!

The only thing I have noticed is that there are now gather points and the ability to queue troops & research together. As much as the original version didn't have those features, I don't mind that they've been added - it does make the game play a bit better.

All in all, it is exactly what I expected in a remaster and I am glad the developers didn't change the way the game plays too much.
Path finding is so bad, units are so stupid, and population limit is so ridiculous that I wonder how could I play this game 20+ years ago. Maybe Age of Empires II would be better, we'll see.

A modern remake of a classic RTS from 1997. Any 1990's folks will know this is one of the strategy games to arrive at the time of Command and Conquer, Total Annihilation, Red Alert, Warcraft and helped shape the "RTS" genre as we know it today. A brilliant era for the genre and thankfully one which is being given the remastered treatment for Windows 10, alongside Command and Conquer. 

Pros:
- A beautiful graphical overhaul, giving the appearance of a contemporary game in its own right. Each unit is remastered, alongside buildings, ambient world effects and water. While not groundbreaking it looks modern without breaking the graphical bank and ensuring compatibility across generations of PC's, the more higher end systems enjoying the increased zoom and 4k compatible visuals. 
- Soundtrack which is remastered and is one of the biggest improvements as the music is very calm, melancholy and fitting and easily a pro against the more hectic, medieval soundtrack of it's successor. The music fits the speed and pace of this game (even the most frantic of which seems rather calm compared to Age of Empires II). 
- Quality of life improvements. Automatic reseeding of farms, traversal across farmland, a proper tech tree for each civilisation and unit resource allocation amongst those which warrant this game another look. 
- Another visit to one of the most storied eras of human civilisation. Campaigns are easy to follow, and provide a keen insight to the era culminating in the rise of the Roman Empire. 
- Great for new RTS players. This game is easy to learn and provides accessibility for players across many skillsets and while the finer nuances of each civilisation take time to learn, the basic mechanics are easy for younger or new players to pick up. A great introduction RTS to master and then hone their skills in other games. 

Cons:
- Pathfinding leaves a lot to be desired. Units become grouped at choke points and can often be near useless unless they either engage in combat or through the passage of time become free once more. This is not game breaking but something to be aware of when generating several large groups of infantry in particular. 
- At times unbalanced. AOEII is constantly receiving updates to the unit roster, tech tree and civilisation specific bonuses, making a very balanced game. AOEDE suffers from a lack of care in this respect. Glaring deficiencies such as wall gates missing also harm this aspect. 
- Wanting more. While accessible it does have disadvantages, especially against its successor which has more units and strategies to win, which may harm replayability. 

Overall this is a welcome addition to any RTS fan's library. This was the first foray into this series for many in 1997 and remains my spiritual favourite, despite the arguably superior gameplay of AOEII. The music, time period and calm demeanour of this game invite seasoned and junior RTS players to jump into this fascinating era once more and experience one of the torchbearers to this genre. I highly recommend this to all RTS players and those who wish to step back to a simpler time, with window dressing.

AOE is an RTS game based in antiquity (Stone Age to Iron Age, goes up to Roman times). It's one of the progenitors of the RTS genre, so if you've played an RTS game at some point in your life, chances are it followed a similar formula: Make workers, gather 4 resources, make buildings, make soldiers and beat up your opponent.

The remaster comes with brand new beautiful graphics and a reworked soundtrack, as well as many quality of life improvements such as balance patches, new functions (for example, unit stances, which were absent in the old version) and changes such as farms being walkable over like in AOE 2 instead of being regular buildings.


While nowadays it largely lingers in the shadow of its child AOE 2, the game holds up surprisingly well in 2021. Larger and blockier units, as well as the general lack of preset formations, allow for body blocking, while arrows being slow and seeable allows you to dodge them if you manually move your units to the side - things like that make AOE potentially more micro-intensive and focusing on controlling a small amount of units, tho late game deathballs are still very much there. Resources on the map can run out quickly (even wood), and the lack of gates, as well as the presence powerful options in Age 2 and 3, make AOE generally a more aggressive version of AOE 2 - Age 4 games are less common, games ending in Age 2 or 3 are. The fundamentals of AOE 2 still apply in AOE 1, and the choice of civs and map types on offer allows for a good amount of variety in play, and should be enjoyable to people who have played a latter installment or like RTS games in general (however, the balance of this game is all over the place, with some civs being particularly dominant, like the Romans, while some languishing in bottom tiers, like Carthage or Greeks).

There's plenty of campaigns to chew through, which can take a long time, so even if one does not intend to dive into multiplayer (which is still active, in case the reader is wondering), the singleplayer offerings should keep one engaged for a long while, if money spent->content ratio is important. While the campaigns are rather challenging (if one plays on high difficulties), the scenarios are significantly more simplistic due to lack of triggers or in-mission voice over, so they might come off as stale after some time, since most scenarios rely on you starting off with little, building up a base and beating your opponent.

Overall, it's a gorgeous and well put together remaster of a classic, which should appeal to a lot of genre fans and those after the nostalgia.

A Legend of a game

Haven't played this since I was too young to play without cheats, so wanted to give it a legit go. Pretty fun.

Took several days' playtime just to get through the campaign, so you do get your money's worth.
The game teaches you some history, and refers to famous events and people you're already familiar with. Losing (or saving and quitting) often has a humorous story to go with it. The win, loss and instruction messages are all voiced.

The gameplay itself is fun and quite impressive given the game's age. It aged very well. You usually don't need a lot of war tactics or strategies, but there are a few near impossible levels where you need to know what to do to even stand a chance (but there's a bunch of cheats that'll help you overcome almost any level. You can cheat just enough to make a level 'fair', or go overboard and enjoy being the all-mighty ruler of the map. Cheats don't disable achievements).

One problem with the campaign is that the enemies tend to resign when they are losing, cutting the fun short. Luckily there's a 'bug' you can abuse to fix that. On maps with multiple enemy groups, beat one of them (you may need to leave a wall standing), then ally with them and tick the allied victory box. Then even if all the other groups resign, the game will continue till you untick allied victory, in which case you immediately win the level.

There is one annoying bug where units get stuck together on the same spot. Unsticking them requires either waiting a minute or so for them to unstick themselves, or killing one off. This requires a slight delay as you need to arrange your units in a way that minimises the odds of them hitting the same spot.

Many achievements are obtained during normal play, but there are some brutal ones that require way too much grinding. So I wouldn't recommend this game for completionists.
Still a fun Game easy to play a few hours without breaking a sweat

I wish there was a mixed option for this review, seeing as I cannot recommend this game nor can I not not recommend it.

Pros:
-High resolution graphics
-Nice update from the original game (animations and visuals in general)
-Combines everything from AoE and AoE RoR into a single game
-For those looking for that old feeling of playing the original game, you will feel it

Cons:
-So many things could have been improved to make this a much much less irritating experience

1) No troop formation: Troops just wander and bump into each other continuously making it almost impossible to control and perform an effective attack or defence. It's hard to control more than 10 units, imagine a whole army. You have to select one by one in order to move them where you wish them to be.

2) Pathfinding sux: Troops and villagers get stuck all the time. If you don't pay attention, you might find out 15 minutes later that that villager you sent to build a watch tower was stuck in the forest all along. Combine this with the absence of troop formation, it becomes impossible and very painful to use strategy in a game that relies mostly on using strategy.

3) Priests range is 10+ yet for some reason they won't start healing unless the unit is almost completely next to it. Sometimes I have 5 or more units all wounded very close to the priest yet he doesn't do anything. Same thing for some units like War galley that won't start shooting enemy units on sight. No matter what position you choose for them, they see enemy troops next to them such as a villager constructing a building and they just stand there without any reaction.

Another issue with range is that your war galleys have 8 range and the enemy tower has 6 or 7 (less than you), yet for some reason, go figure, your boats need to get into the tower's range in order to shoot it and at the same time be shot by it? What's the purpose of having increased range if they put themselves withing enemy's towers range?

4) Population caps at 50 in campaign: How are you supposed to beat a very difficult AI that constantly spams attacks at you and rebuilds everything that you destroy, when you have 20 villagers on resources, 10 boats and 20 army units = 50 population.

5) AI cheats or difficulty setting is bugged: I circled an enemy on an island, no resources left to gather, for 30 minutes continuously killing his villagers and troops with my boats without suffering any damage on my side, yet the AI never stops sending troops my way and never stops rebuilding every building I destroy (Easiest mode).

5)General bugs like a Gazelle running and stopping at mid-air jump position.


I know the original game lacked everything I mentioned here, but how hard would it be to make a better pathfinding and options for troop formations like in AoE2? I doubt anyone would complain about this for not being like the original game.

So as others pointed out this is a bit of a mixed bag. I bought this because AoE 1 was a game I grew up with, so there's a ton of nostalgia involved for me. Also this is a single player only rating, because that's what I bought it for and honestly I don't see why you wouldn't play AoE2 if you wanted to play AoE multiplayer.

AoE1 is noticeably a game from the early days of RTS. Pathfinding was still in it's infancy, archers can't hit a target that doesn't move in a straight line towards them, bonus damage for triangular balance wasn't a thing. They added waypoints and a-move, but the pathfinding and core mechanics weren't noticeably touched, so these issues remain and they have quite a bit of influence on how much fun this game is because units get stuck quite a bit.
Otherwise AoE1 is a solid game. Factions have very different strengths and weaknesses (and looks), there isn't a super-dominant unit that doesn't have a counter and the low supply limit forces you to often micro small balanced armies and think a bit outside of the box. AoE 1 has a surprisingly solid campaign mission design that often rewards exploration and generally the missions are fun.

In terms of remake this gets a 8.5/10 from me. I loved the way the original AoE1 felt, the sounds when you went through the menu, the soundtrack and in general the representation. These are mostly gone, the menu looks and feels very generic and minimalistic, the soundtrack is mostly replaced and only occasionally hints at original tracks. An option to switch these things off and on would have been appreciated. The campaigns in- and outros are now voiced, but unlike in AoE2 where you have multiple voice actors with fitting accents and voiced dialogues during missions here you have a single one who gets a bit tiring to listen to after a while.
That being said the new tracks are nice and fit the atmosphere, the new effects are neat and the DE makes the game look every bit as pretty as it was in my idolized memory. It's freaking gorgeous and pictures really don't do it justice. The higher resolution naturally is icing on the cake.

Overall It's easy to see why it became a classic, but also why it got completely replaced by AoE2. Realistically the pathing is holding it back quite a bit. As such I think it's easily worth trying out for the 5 bucks it's currently offered for if you have an interest in RTS and antiquity or played and liked the original, but it certainly can't compete with titles in it's full price range like AoE2DE or Sc2.

[table][tr][th][h2]Pros üëçüèª[/h2][/th][th][h3]Cons üëéüèª[/h3][/th][/tr]
[th][list]
 [*] Automatic farm rebuilding
 [*] Great campaign content

 [*] Perfect archaic-themed background music
