[quote]Like our reviews? Check out: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/][b]United Critics[/b][/url]![/quote]

[h1]‚úî Opening Comments[/h1]
[i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] is a complete graphical overhaul of the original game, released over 20 years ago. The Definitive Edition has fully replaced the graphics of the original, making it much more visually appealing compared to other games these days. Some other quality of life features such as auto re-farming have been added, making it less frustrating to play.

[h1]üéÆ Singleplayer[/h1]
Probably the main part of the game, [i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] gives you the option to play historical campaigns, from Egypt to the Huns, or to play matches against as many AI as you wish. Another feature is the ability to play the game in the original 1997 graphics for some added nostalgia.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2346258638

Campaigns are quite good, but I found that because of the 50 pop cap, games could drag out needlessly for hours until finishing. Another annoyance was the difficulty of the AI on some levels. Some levels are horribly easy and then some are stupendously hard, even impossible.

The number of civilizations included is suitable for the time period and geographical location, but some nations such are clearly missing that were quite important in this time. It is unlikely there will ever be a DLC for [i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] because of low popularity.

[h1]ü§º Multiplayer[/h1]
Multiplayer is nice when you can play a game with it dropping out, but due to [i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i]'s lack of popularity, there are not many lobbies available to choose from.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2346284763

[h1]üíª Graphics[/h1]
One of the main selling points for [i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] were the new and improved 4K graphics. The developers did a fabulous job in updating everything into beautiful visual quality. There are three zoom detail options able to be selected, depending on how much RAM is currently installed in your system.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2346254605

Another updated visual is that of building collapse animations. When you destroy a building, it will collapse into a colorful mess of many bricks, adding an extra appeal to watching things being destroyed.

Overall in terms of graphics, the developers absolutely aced it. Pity that it can not really make up for lag issues.

[h1]üé∂ Soundtrack[/h1]
The in-game soundtrack is relaxing, and helps you focus on the screen. It is fully instrumental - another change that the Definitive Edition introduced - and sounds great. The music perfectly fits the age and theme the game is set in.


[h1]üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶ Audience[/h1]
[i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] contains mild violence and death noises, and is not too complex to grasp the basics to be able to play, so I recommend it for anyone twelve or older, and especially those with a knack for history.

[h1]üî• Performance[/h1]
The game performed below average due to the single-core bottleneck. This caused frequent FPS drops throughout game-play, and was a real 'put-off' for me, making the game thoroughly less enjoyable. Although you could experience a smooth 30FPS (in-game lock in settings), this made everything clunky.

[b]My system specifications:[/b]
CPU: AMD Ryzen 3 3300X @3.8/4.3 Ghz
RAM: 16GB DDR4 @2666MHz
GPU: MSI AERO GeForce¬Æ GTX 1660 Super OC 6GB
Storage: 480GB internal SSD, 1TB ASUS FX external HDD

You computer will need to be stronger than the specs advertised on the store page, and if you want a high refresh rate, you will need a CPU with very strong single-core and thread performance.

[h1]‚ùì Conclusion[/h1]
To wrap up, [i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] was a splendid job in terms of graphics and quality of life improvements; however, the huge flaws such as bad path-finding AI and CPU bottle-necking which causes huge and unsuspected lag make the game very hard to play much of and let-alone even enjoy. And since the latter is by engine design, it is highly unlikely performance in this category will ever be improved. 

I recommend to buying this game while on sale and only if you happen to have nothing better worth playing.

Rating: 5/10

[i]Age of Empires: Definitive Edition[/i] is a subpar [b]real-time strategy (RTS)[/b] when compared to the likes of [i]Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition, Supreme Commander, and StarCraft I/2[/i] but it is still [u][b]different enough from other games in the genre, that it is worth your time and money to learn and buy the game.[/b][/u]

The biggest issue currently, is that the [b]pathfinding of units is appalling.[/b] Multiple units can get stuck on top of each other and large-scale engages are more clunky than [i]Broodwar[/i] (which was messy but a controllable mess) matches. This is [b]an issue you will surely face multiple times and not just on the odd occasion[/b], significantly ruining the gameplay at times.

[b]Multiplayer lobbies are fine[/b], and there are usually [b]plenty available[/b] but [b]ranked matchmaking does not work very well[/b]. This is simply because there are [b]too few players queuing up[/b] for it and not because there is a significant issue with the system that matches players together.

It is genuinely [b]very pleasant to play this game with the newly updated graphics as well as the few quality-of-life features[/b]. Furthermore, there are [b]lots of campaign scenarios[/b] (you won't finish them any time soon) and maps to play on. 

The [b]AI has its issues, but in general, it provides a challenge for most casual players.[/b] The [b]civilizations are different enough from one another in the different playstyles that they promote[/b] because of the unique bonuses they each provide. I am therefore repeatedly motivated to try out something new depending on which civilization I have chosen, allowing for [b]reasonable replayability[/b].

This is basically a graphically and technologically uplifted version of the classic AoE experience. This includes the content from both base AoE and The Rise of Rome expansion pack, both conveniently combined (they were separate executables in the original release). This means it is everything AoE was, for better and for worse. The only con I can think of over the original is the pathfinding AI sometimes craps itself and needs a little bit of babying, more so than the original but not enough so to really be a problem. I had it happen twice over the course of the entire Ascent of Egypt learning campaigning which I consider pretty good for what is essentially a 90's era strategy game. Overall I would definetely recommend this. This is the defacto way to play on modern systems IMO, and the best entry point for new players. Its all of the classic experience, with almost none of the classic jankyness.

D.E is a delightful update of one of my childhood favorites. 

It's practically impossible to be objective about a game that I literally played while sitting on my Mom's knee, but this blast from the past holds the fuck up to the test of time.

The visual updates to classic aren't the only changes either. The Campaigns have updated as well, with some scenarios featuring minor cosmetic changes, such as the position of starting bases or resources been adjusted to improve the game balance and provide a better challenge, while others have been radically altered.

However, what is a multiplayer strategy game without on an active online community? A decent campaign mode I guess, but AOE:DE also has a sizeable community of active online players as well. Although the average calibre of online play is significantly higher than I'm capable of :D

The best way to play this game is casually.  Leave build orders and metagame with Age of Empires 2, and just enjoy the nostalgia and art style with this one.  That's where the fun lies, in my opinion.  Also the cheats are as awesome as before.  PHOTON MAN, am I right.

My main complaint is a big one.  There are times when the path-finding is ATROCIOUS.  I will echo another review in that it actually feels worse than I remember (although maybe we just don't remember how bad the 1996 version was).  Sometimes you have to babysit your army though tight passageways or corridors.   Occasionally your units will decide that the best way to walk around another unit is to WALK ACROSS THE MAP in the other direction.  Other times, two units in a crowd will accidentally overlap and get stuck, and you have to tell them to stop moving for about 5 seconds and then move them one at a time.  As long as units' pathways are about 3 tiles wide or more, the pathfinding is OK.  Thus, the best experiences are in wide open maps, not heavily forested ones.

The AI in this game is really broken, both of your units and the enemies. Your units gets stuck on each other a lot making a simple "attack this enemy" command be way more difficult than it actually should, they also do not update their target location very often, so if the enemy start to move away your unit will go to were you clicked to attack, not where they are now.
Enemy AI is also a problem, they keep attacking your city no matter what you do, even if you didn't attack them, your only viable option is to build towers around your city and gather a big enough army to destroy them in a single attack, because they will rebuild everything you destroyed before you can prepare a second attack. If you don't defeat them fast enough you will literally run out of resources and lose all the progress you made because you never have more resources than the enemy (unless you use cheats).
Also, WTF is with the kamikaze enemy units? You cannot bring any weak but useful unit with you because the enemy will pass your stronger units and kill them no matter what, even if your stronger unit attacked first, you also cannot keep the villagers anywhere near your towers because the enemy will ignore them and attack the villagers, you need to keep a literal wall of soldiers at the entrance of your city or else you will be expending all your food replacing the villagers.
Mind you I had all of these problems with the enemy AI in the Normal difficulty, going for easy doesn't help much and I'm not even going to try the harder ones, only buy this game for the nostalgia and use cheats as much as you would like, you don't lose the achievements. If the devs fix the stupidly aggressive AI and balance their cities to take into account how much resource you can reasonably get, I will recommend this game, until them, get AoE 2, it's much better in every way.

Pros- It's the good Old Aoe1 you know and love
Cons- It's EXACTLY the good old AOE1 you know and love. BUt let me explain further.

While the DE is what the name says, it keeps out many of the things that made AOE 2 better. No resource trading system unless it's gold, and if it's gold it's only by trading ships.
Path finding is exactly as bad as the original. tech costs while rebalanced are still the same ( you need gold to upgrade gold farming and stone to improve stone), population limit for campaign is still 50 , and houses still give you 4 pop. points

That being said. AOE1 is a pretty good game for it's time. and this is an improved version of that game. Not only in graphics but also the rebalancing changes and the music, wich we are going to talk about now.

Changes in graphics. Not only the game is now 4k compatible, units have a turning animation. wich i wish could be disabled. there is a problem with that animation. sometimes units get stuck inside other units. They usually de stuck after a while. but it's still annoying. However it doesn't happen often.

Rebalancing.

Farms , like in AOE2 DE can be auto restocked if you set it from the granary. Wheel is far cheaper now. And some civs passives were toned down because they were absolutely broken in the original AOE. some others where changed due to their passives being way too focused on water or teamwork only.

You have a tech tree available to see, no more checking the manual or a wiki, Zoom function, Defensive stance, attack on movement, attacking doesn't override stances,  You can combine different unit creation, and even queue a tech and unit together. All important info is right in the hud, you know how many villagers are being used for each resource... Even if they are not actually working on it, wich can be confusing if i wasn't a idle villager maniac and was always using the idle villager button (not a new feature tho, it's from rise of rome)

Now. Let's talk about the biggest contention point 

The campaign.

As i said pop limit is still 50. But not only that, adding the brain dead AI on most difficulties, you also have reworked maps. And most of them are EASIER. and not in a good way. The first Babylon map, holy man, is still a nightmare, even if you got more resources now, But THE HUNT, 4 4th in this campaign, and possibly the HARDEST in the original game, is now a cakewalk. And the reason is... Forgotten empires NERFED The skirmish levels. 

Skirmish levels are levels where you start with a limited set of units and find more trough the level, you can't build or replenish your troops.  And The hunt was the MOTHER of the skirmish levels. It's unforgiving, and requires good use of your troops, specially priests.

what did they do? Give you villagers, lots of resources to gather. and since the AI is set on defensive, waiting for your next move like in the original level, You don't have to worry about being attacked. You don't even have to worry about accidentally killing the villagers, because you later find more! And this kind of situation repeats on EVERY map where you used to have limited resources. Some of the maps where they actually made a new map instead are actually harder, but the ones that used to be skirmishes are a cakewalk.

The Yamato campaign was the worst in the original, it was rushed, difficulty was all over the place, so FE did a good job getting rid of most Yamato maps. Didn't play ROR yet, but i hope not a lot changed, ROR maps were very refined. And didn't really need a rework.

Overall if you play this game do it for the campaign, because even if the difficulty curve is all over the place, it still plays really good. Don't bother with the multiplayer. Most people are playing the superior AOE 2 Definitive. But AOE1 is a great piece of history, and despite not aging as good, It's still damn fine to play

Improved AI. BUT ONLY ON SKIRMISHES. While the campaign AI seems to be less stupid than vanilla AOE , anything under very hard makes it brain dead. I remember in the original AOE Moderate was pretty challenging. Here it's way too easy and the PC gives up on attacking you too fast. main problem, The campaing population limit, the game spends a lot of population on villagers and barely attacks you due to most of the population being lumberjacks. Don't expect a lot of challenge from the campaign because of this.

Music. It's okay, but i wish the OG OST was available. Mostly because the new one is good but lacks any impact. While i don't mind losing AOE1 music, I CARE about Rise of Rome music, and this OST doesn't do a good service to the original wich was top tier.

I was disappointed in this game, and maybe that's a misalignment between my expectations and the developers. I'd done no research on the game, I just had a burst of nostalgia when I saw it, and so I, more than the game/developers, may be at fault.

Graphically, it's a beautiful game, and its great to be able to launch it without having to worry about compatibility issues, but it feels like a game from the mid-90s not from the ~2018. Whilst I can understand sticking with the original mechanics - no gates being the obvious one - having the units be as stupid as the were back in the original release is just painful. I don't want to waste time watching a trio of axemen wander in a circle whilst getting shot to pieces because their fourth friend is two pixels too far one side and it's confusing their tiny 90s brain. 

I will say that if you're looking to experience the original AoE feel, this game is great; but for me, i'm just left feeling disappointed.

This could have been a great game for fans of the original AoE. Beautiful new graphics, 4K support, carefully improved interface, the "Rise of Rome" expansion pack included - BUT, unfortunately this game is ruined by an AI completely unlike the original game. The AI appears to know only two modes: Passive or berserk, no matter how you set the difficulty (which appears to make zero difference in gameplay). This makes the free game incredibly frustrating and some campaign mission outright impossible to complete (even when the game is set to "easiest").

As a fan of the original AoE when it came out, I can say that this completely changes the atmosphere of the original game. There is no "casual" gameplay possible anymore, and I imagine most other original fans are now at least 30+ and have no desire to give up and restart a single mission a dozen times, either.

Instead of buying this, do what I did: Go back the playing the original AoE instead! It still works flawlessly on Windows 10.

The Age of Empires franchise will always hold a special place in my heart; Age of Empires II was one of the first games I ever got into, on the PC; so much that my friends and I had a group that would meet at lunch and after school to play it in our science lab in middle school. Age of Empires III was my go to game with my brother, as we'd spend hours building massive bases as we'd slowly dwindle resources and take on the AI.

I have less experiences with Age of Empires the first one; however, it started the franchise for me. It runs extremely smooth, supports 4K and Triple-Monitor Gaming, and the soundtrack is stupendous. I would highly recommend it for anyone looking for an optimized RTS game.

This is a beautiful remaster of the original AoE, but damn is it bad. I understand that it was staying true to the origins, and that the idea was to make it modern and beautiful, which they did.

Except, one major flaw: they did not modernize the most important parts: adding more advanced commands like formation movements etc. The worst part is the path finding. It is simply terrible. Units get stuck trying to push the buildings out of the way. I had soldiers get stuck on a damned tree, unable to move anywhere until I manually moved them AROUND the stupid tree. I would send the army on attack/move command to enemy base, only to have them MOVE there and stand perfectly still, completely ignoring enemy units and buildings. They would only fight if someone attacked them directly, and only units that are directly attacking them. Other units will not move at all to come to aid unless I do it manually. Aggressive stance does not help at all.

It is a beautiful remake of the original AoE, but damn is it terrible to play. Do not buy at full price, it will hurt less when you realize how little time was spent on optimizing the most important parts of any strategy game - actually moving units and attacking others. Be ready to micromanage every single damned unit you have, since they will get stuck on trees, buildings, other units, etc, while also at the same time forgetting to fight enemies.

This game is very fun,but hard to control unit. 


PS.If you used to play aoe2 or aoe3 before this , i don't recommend (those two are better).

Multiplayer works fine .  Steam achievements are doable without strong efforts and game overall is pretty cheap.

Pros: Graphics, good multiplayer online and all expansions campaign single player included into product, cheap price.
Cons: Strong players in multiplayer can ruin your experience, Limited roster of maps (nothing new added ) Same building and civilizations like original game, on long term this game can be boring and repetitive.

AoE:DE has a great look and play well but it's still essentially the same game, you get 3 simple guys ( why only men? ) and you have to build a mini-civilization based one of the many civilizations formed in early human history. 

Sadly the DE update is really only updating the graphics, adding in the online play and a few tweaks to the fairly simple AI. There's really only one way to beat AoE:DE, same as you used to beat it in AoE, simply raise the biggest army you can at the highest tech point you can get to for your civ and then go kick seven shades out of your neighbour. Originally played this game as a beta on the Microsoft Store, and later bought it when it released on that platform. The game's nostalgia factor was excellent: I was blown away by the remastered soundtrack and graphics, and a campaign mode that had been basically remade from scratch to be more historically accurate and better designed for gameplay. However until recently there were still a lot of problems with the AI in random map / skirmish mode, and no ranked multiplayer online, which detracted from the game's strengths.

Then there was a major revamp on the 1-year anniversary of the DE release, with several major updates focusing on shoring up the AI and online matchmaking. I'm happy to say that the updated version, which is the one now available on Steam, has satisfactorily addressed most of my previous complaints, and to thank the development team for their additional work I went ahead and bought a second copy on my preferred platform. The quirky unit pathfinding in this game is my only remaining complaint, but it's still much improved from the original AoE1. Having grown up with this franchise since childhood, I am now very satisfied with the Definitive Edition remake of the game that made me fall in love with the series.
I would recommend it for the nostalgia but it still has a lot of bugs in pathmaking and sometimes certain units might even get glitched out. The graphics look stunning though.

The original Age of Empires defined what RTS should be at the time. It arrived on one CD and after installation the CD wasn't required any more.  The game ran fast and smooth even on a potato machine and everything worked properly. It was the incarnation of "definitive".

The only thing "definitive" about this version is the title.  Somewhere in the transition all the things that made the original engaging, accessible and above all fun were stripped away in a poor repackaging for resale.  The game somehow manages to run terribly on more modern machines and isn't even worth the sale price.  Fans of the original will be disappointed.

units get stuck behind other slower units which causes me to get slaughtered :(

Can not say am pleased by this "definitive edition".
20GB of HD just for mild cosmetic enhancement (ships' oars still do not move as 20 years ago...nor any effort was made with animations: unlike AoE3, there is a single attack animation for both units and building and it is quite comical to look swordsmen or archers in vain fighting with building which at a certain point, and for unknonw reasons, collapse), a resampled soundtrack (which in my opinion has less "personality" than the original score: why on Earth the game start with AoE2's intro theme???) and the minor tweaks already added by the Rise of Rome expansion.
If rule out the nicer graphics (an utterly useless feature for strategic games) developers did nothing to truly improve the 1997 game, not even fixing the major flaws which were addressed in AoE2:pathfinding is still awful as it used to be, and the game become less and less fun as the unit cap is increased. Which makes me wonder why unit cap could be raised up to 250 when the AI is not able to move coherently five war chariots or keeps clogging up villagers...speaking of which I must underline that the flag and idle button of AoE2 have been included.
To sum it up, the Definitive Edition is basically a pile of chaff attempting to hide the horrid truth that the game is the very same of 20 years ago, which did not aged well at all.
So may wonder why did not asked the refund but, well, the answer is pretty simple: my AoE cd is damaged beyond repair and this is the only version available for when feel the urge to unleash a thundering nigthmare of horses and chariots upon the blue and yellow player (in truth the new animations and sounds of collapsing buildings and their razed remains make all this much more satisfying).
If are a long-time fan of AoE, then it may be worth the purchase if can not play the original AoE anymore; for all the others, there are many much better options

EDIT
Unlike the HD edition of AoE2, this one comes with the very same original AI, dumb as a brick.
Even at the highest difficulty setting AI can not handle sea maps (can not colonize new islands, waste a large fraction of the limited wood for useless buildings and, if wait to see what it does instead of wiping it away in the Tool Age, trains the most expensive land units and send them in suicide missions against the blockading fleet to the point it is even merciful to destroy the docks), and can put up a bit of challenge only through numbers: if pick an open, huge map with eight players, 2-3 AI-controlled civs should survive the bronze age onslaught and put up a fight.
AI performs better on deathmatches because of the horrid pathfinding which greatly increase the need for micromanagement when sizeable masses of units are assembled.

I am a huge fan of AoE2 and really enjoy playing AoE2 HD and AoE2 DE, because both do not only have better graphics, but also come with awesome improvements in terms of gameplay, usability, etc. AoE DE on the other hand is a huge disappointment for me. The game comes indeed with better graphics; unfortunately the animations cannot keep up with that and so look cheaper than ever. Also AoE HD lacks those improvements which you can find in AoE2 HD or AoE2 DE. If you frequently play AoE2 HD/DE, you definitely will miss those features in AoE HD as much as I do. 

So here is my advice: In case the retro fever hits you, think about playing the good old classic version of AoE from CD. I am not kidding. That's what I do from time to time and this way I really can enjoy an authentic game experience, without modern graphics making poor animations even more obvious.

I got age of empires in a box of cereal when I was a child. We had a piece of shit computer, even for the time. It had a 800mb hard drive, and 128mb of ram. We typically only had 1 or maybe 2 games installed at a time because of the disc space required. Age of empires was put on and did not come off. It would of course lag, have some occasional colour rendering issues because of how garbage the computer was. But it was quite well playable.

Fast forward to now. My computer is beyond the recommended specs of definitive edition (not that you should need such specs for a game like this, but that's another issue). On opening it I set every setting to maximum, as I typically do with games to see if it's playable, and my god it was horrifying.

Of course I set everything to minimum. What happened? Nothing. Exactly the same behaviour.  What behaviour might you ask? SO. MUCH. LAG. Building finished? Lag. New unit? Lag. Tell a villager to do an action? Lag. Battle horn? Lag. But this could just be an optimisation issue. Maybe I need to configure launch options. Thank goodness the game is so polished otherwise.

Oh, no.

How the fuck is the pathfinding WORSE than the original? How is this even possible? Units get stuck on each other, trees, coastlines, buildings, and it is CONSTANT. When 2 villagers get stuck on each other they can get trapped in this dance, and they don't show up as idle villagers either so unless you happen to notice they just dance forever. There are things you would have noticed just by playing the damn game. When villagers finish chopping down a tree on the edge of the map, they walk forever, facing the edge of the map. There are some sprites which just don't look the same as the others, they jitter slightly, like the lion. Something weird has happened with the edges of it and it just looks like it's floating near to the ground. But once it's in the dying animation and dead it looks normal. Oh and the fucking xbox live bullshit. No matter what I do, it just keeps opening the window again and again. Sometimes it crashes itself out, sometimes it freezes, sometimes I can close it and it leaves me alone for a while. No one in history has ever thought to themselves "God this game would be so much better if I was forced to log in to a microsoft account".

Given how long the game has been out for, it's fair to assume they don't intend to fix these issues. I suggest avoiding the game.

Much enhanced graphics.

Old Wine in a new bottle. There are some very noticable improvements like 
(i) Ability to walk over unconstructed buildings 
(ii) Ability to walk over farms and automatic reseeding of farms
(iii) Having waypoints for units
(iv) Villagers allocated to each resource (near the resource bar) 
(v) Villagers start resource collection after building Granary/ Storage Pit

But, there are lot of issues, which haven't been solved in the last 22 years
(i) BAD path finding (this is a BIG issue)
(ii) No new civilizations. Seriously Devs? What about the Indians (Harappans and Mauryans?)
(iii) No Trade Carts and inability to trade for Food, Wood and Stone. (AoE 2 does a fantastic job)
(iv) No Formations for units (like AOE2 has). Who can forget the legendary Roman and Greek Formations? This is frustrating when coupled with bad path finding. The cavalry goes fast, the archers and infantry are slower and the Siege weapons and priests are stuck at last, thereby falling easy prey for attacks
(v) No Gates (like in AOE2) ; this prevents units from going astray 
Although micro-management has been improved (from the original game), it is no way near to what AOE2 offers. We need ability to group units, Auto Scouting... just to name a few. The issue is after a point of time, these problems are magnified. 

Make no mistake, I'm a huge fan of the AOE/AOM Franchise and I have finished all the games multiple times over the last 2 decades, but the price isn't justified and this is an insult to the original game. The Devs should realise that we gamers play AOE for the fun and not for the graphics. 
I have been playing AOE Upatch HD with mods and it was more entertaining than the Definitive Edition.

I don't remember the original, so I can't compare but this feels more like a game from over 20 years ago than a modern remake.

The main issue by far (we're talking light years here) is that units are getting stuck with each other to the point you have to delete one to set the other free. The pathfinding is almost non-existent. They just wander of in whichever direction and get stuck somewhere, most commonly in the middle of battle when you task them to attack the enemy unit.

The balance of units is dreadful. I have used maybe half of the units available when playing through all of the campaigns. Just because the rest is utterly useless (we have a saying "useful like a bobsleigh during summer"), so with pop limit of 50, they'd just be wasting space. And the half I used was only because the 2-3 unit types I wanted to use are not available to every civilization, so I had to use whatever the next best thing was they had available.

And the AI difficulty scale seems to be set higher than AOE2. Playing against medium AI is no walk in the park. And playing deathmatch (high starting resources) was a chore even against the easiest AI. I think the major difference between the difficulties might be resources available to the AI.

Yeah, the graphic looks ok but who cares? If I wanted something nice to look at, I'd buy an aquarium. But it seems to be the only thing worth calling definitive edition about this game.

I feel it would have been better to maybe stray further from the original, and overhaul some stuff. Like maybe add gates to the walls, add strongholds that are stronger than towers, make fewer units with more upgrades, so there's a sense of progression, make the civs more distinct from each other.

As it is, I don't see any reason for this game to exist. Would be better to just port the campaigns to AOE2:DE, so we can enjoy this historical era inside a playable game.

I wish there were a third option between "Recommended" and not...because that's where this game sits. It's tough, because I imagine most people bought this game largely for nostalgia reasons, and any criticism of this game is likely to be construed as criticism of some of the community's most cherished gaming memories; I for one remember bonding over this game with my cousins as a young boy, and the patina of innocence and past-yearning are worth rehashing for its own sake.

But as a game, even in the context of a re-imagined retro game, AOE:DE falls short of the ambitious claim that it is the 'Definitive' experience. As in, no more improvements to be made.

I am okay that the game retains some of the tastefully retro elements, like cheesy 90s menus and buttons, a minimalist UI (much improved from the original), and lo-fi voices. But there is a difference between retro aesthetics, and flaws that make the game less enjoyable. These flaws are as follows:

- Very stupid AI and pathing. I mean, terrible. Units get lost or stuck moving from A to B; fishing boats constantly forget to keep fishing, requiring me to retask them over and over. Units needlessly take round-about paths, can't negotiate simple obstacles like narrow gaps, and react in weird and annoying ways when tasked as a group. I did not find these quirks endearing.

- High learning curve. With no tutorial, and an AI that even on its easiest setting still wrecks new players, I found this game hard to settle into. Enemy AI has to be able to see my units with or without LOS; there have been too many times where they randomly wandered through that one weak point in my defenses, past all my units, and slaughtered my Vils for it to be an accident. Plus, many times I have destroyed their economy and yet they still seem able to spam units...how?? They have to be receiving bonus resources or something. I think it is fair-game to compare AOE:DE with its natural successor, AOE2:DE, which handles new players much better, with both a tutorial and War Academy.

- Bugs. Why are there still frame-rate drops, glitched movement, animal bugs, and the like? This game has been out for 20 years, and the DE spent a year on the Windows store before coming to Steam...my personal opinion is that the Devs knew that AOE2:DE was going to be their money-maker, and so they put their focus there. Well fine, but it sucks as the consumer.

It has improved much since the first release. Especially the AI was a huge failure. But even though it became a quite good game, one important thing doesn't work and when I found out it was too late. I play AoE with friends and we play with AI, so to scout for us I bought the game and played a test game against the AI and I enjoyed it so I recommended it. My best buddy bought this game, we played a MP match against the AI and we wondered that it was too easy. We played team isles so maybe the AI isn't that great on this map type so we tried it a few more times but even on the highest difficulty we had absolutely no problems to win against enemies with only a few units, several buildings and almost no resistance. It seems the multiplayer AI is different from the AI used outside the multiplayer and is extremely passive. We both wasted 5 Euro so it didn't hurt that much but it was clearly a bad investment for both of us.
If you play it for the campaigns, it more or less works. If you solely play MP with and against humans it will work fine. If you plan to add AI in multiplayer matches, don't buy it.
Edit 31.08.: seems the singleplayer AI became worse. I set a waypoint to a tree and the trained villager did nothing on their arrival. In addition to that, I ordered my two ships to attack another naval unit but one of the ships ignored that and attacked another unit instead. I won't judge that anymore, decide for yourself.

As someone only interested in the singleplayer side of the original Age of Empires, this remaster is a disaster: not only is it lacking in adjustments that would make it as enjoyable to play as Age of Empires II still is in 2020, but the "improved" AI is somehow worse than the original one.

In Standard games, this AI is - quite incredibly - too easy and too difficult to deal with at the same time, acting nonsensically when it comes to actually building a economy or army, but capable of divine skills allowing it to guess your position and actions at every single point of the game without ever needing to properly scout. There's a few strategies to eventually deal with it, but playing against the AI never feels remotely close as fighting something with actual sentience. By the way, do not even try to fight more than 2 AI at once: as soon as you launch an attack against one player, the other AIs will instantly turn hostile to you and send their whole army to your base - they always magically find its location -, no matter their alignment with the player you attack, no matter the difficulty setting you choose.

The campaign mode is unfortunately where this new AI is most damaging to the game, as it will always act just like it would in skirmish/deathmatch: if the scenario is a mission where the original AI started with a giant army which was supposed to stay in its starting location until you're ready to engage it, the new AI will simply send its army to your base to steamroll you before you even get the chance to do anything. In other missions where the objective isn't tied to destroying the enemy, this "improved" AI will often give up before you complete the mission objectives if you deal too much damage to it, ruining the mission's narrative.

All in all, this new AI addition renders the singleplayer experience nonsensical, unenjoyable and void.

I have no idea of how the multiplayer fares, as I never had any desire to play it ; maybe it is good, since you don't have to deal with the AI? Still, if Microsoft and Forgotten Empires only ever desired to remaster the multiplayer component to this game, maybe they should have made this remaster multiplayer-only and advertised it as such, because I feel it's somehow more damaging to include the singleplayer content of this game in such a state than simply getting rid of it.

If you really want to experience Age of Empires how it is meant to be played, find a copy of the original game and its expansion or the Gold version, and download the Upatch HD (https://upatch-hd.weebly.com/) as it offers several improvements from improved resolutions to AI and countless bugs and textures fixes, even adding a few new maps to the game.

And if you want a Definitive Edition that actually does justice to its original game, get Age of Empires II Definitive Edition. I'm saddened to see the state of Age of Empires 1 when Forgotten Empires did so well with the second installment, and I can only hope that Age of Empires III Definitive Edition will be more like the latter, not the former.

In a nostalgic viewpoint, this game is ok, 3/5 maximum. For new players, its not even 1/5. Its a micro management hell when it comes moving the units around the map.

- Pathfinding is so awful that it makes the campaign pretty much unplayable or at least very frustrating/annoying. Unit collision size and how it affects all that, will make you find some strong rope and attaching point for it. Its that bad.

- Because of the collision size and how the movement is so clumsy (because the game engine behind all that is so old), the units will collide with each other even on a field with no obstacles. When two of them collide (going to same direction), the other unit makes 90deg turn and goes that direction for a sec. Then it will collide with an another unit (running to its path) which makes that same manouver and the show goes on. Its just plain horrible and ruins the whole game. Also, they make choke points even on wide paths because if one stops, then the unit next to it stops and then its all blocked like dozens of times that day you have been playing the game and finally, you uninstall it and start playing games like WC3 or SC2 where all those problems mentioned in this review, are nonexistent.

- A group of units easily get jammed together for no reason and they "release" themselves totally random after time X, Y or Z has passed after that: They literally are stuck tightly and cannot move. I dont remember that from the original games so they have made all that previous even worse.

- No formations. Or there is, one fixed that is just pure BS: If the units have distance X from each other and you command them to place Y, they will keep that distance to each other and the location where you clicked is right between those. Just think what happens when there is not much space in the are you ordered them... They will be all over the place and blocking other units etc etc.

I could give a dozen more examples why the game mechanics in this game suck so hard. It seems that they were in rush and just polished this turd without making it more playable. If you played this game when you were 10yrs old kid, buy it if its on sale. Others, dont bother. There are wayy better RTS around.

What I wanted was AoE 1 with updated graphics and compatibility. This version delivers those, in addition to some good balance changes and a fantastic high-res soundtrack faithful to the original music with which I am very impressed.

Despite all this I unfortunately cannot recommend this game, due to the overbearing new AI even on low difficulty settings that, on the original game, would give the same player little trouble. This is quite tragic, as so much good work has clearly gone into this otherwise fantastic product.

NOTE 1:
This review is regarding single-player modes only.

NOTE 2 (further details regarding new AI):
For the sake of reference, I typically play on "standard" difficulty, which is 1 step above "easy" but 1 step below "moderate", which was my preferred setting on the original game and rarely gave me too much trouble. On all difficulties I find the new AI drags every single map (notably including campaign missions) down into a gruelling war of attrition which only ends when they run out of resources to the point where they physically have nothing left to produce units. An interesting observation I figured out last night is that at this point any allies will tribute resources to them until they too have nothing left (even to the point of self-sacrifice; in this example the AI providing tribute gave away so much that it never produced more than about 20 military units or even advanced to Iron Age, despite the map lasting over 2 hours). The AI will construct many redundant buildings (typically 4+ of each: town centre, barracks, siege workshop, archery range, etc) which will clog up the terrain, confounding micromanagement and continuously churning out units until reaching the population limit or no resources. This makes some campaign missions (including the tutorial campaign!) truly horrendous due to the single player (typically starting with little or no base) but facing multiple enemy players (typically starting with one or more highly developed base(s)) from different directions at the same time. To summarise as succinctly as possible, the AI expansion and multitasking capabilities are similar to the highest difficulty settings on other RTS games, regardless of which setting you have actually chosen.

NOTE 3:
On the positive side, my previously-mediocre RTS skills have sharpened a bit.

**EDITED from original**

I'm a massive AoE fan. I still have the original somehow running on my Windows 10 PC. So, it saddens me that a "Definitive Edition" must get a down-vote from me.
Here is what I like about it compared to the original:
- Looks updated, better graphics.
- A new campaign based on the Hittites
- The old campaigns are there too, as well as the Rise of Rome campaigns
- Built-in tech trees you can explore (like in AoE2)
- Unit queuing (like in RoR)

Here's what I really don't like about it:
- You can't even use the Return key to go down a line when trying to type in the Scenario Instructions box on the editor. What is up with that? (**EDIT** They have fixed this. However, now if you try to edit the text in the Scenario Instructions, it doesn't just crash the AoE game, if the window doesn't close automatically, you have to shut your whole computer down to close the game. Not even Task Manager is getting rid of that crash.)
- Still a limited zoom function on the editor, making maps is still as clunky as in the original. IMO, pretty much no improvement, and for an updated release of a game over 20 years old, that is unbelievably shocking. (**EDIT** Still not fixed with new update)
- "Connect to XBOX live account" is fraught with issues (UI suppressed etc.), and I still can't do it, even after troubleshooting from Microsoft's website. If Microsoft bloody Solitaire can connect and synch seamlessly, why can't AoE DE? (**EDIT** Got this working on my laptop, must have been an issue with my PC. My bad)
- As far as I can tell, there is no way to port old campaigns/scenarios I (or anyone else) made on RoR or AoE original into the DE version. Again, that is absolutely shocking.
- All this game seems to be is a graphically improved (though not perfect) version of the old RoR game, with a new UI, which is somehow more limited. No new civs, no expanded tech tree, no extra depth, music has been updated (and some tracks are actually worse imho). 
- It is absolutely not worth ¬£15 (which is what I got it for). You're better off getting your hands on Age of Empires: Rise of Rome, which for a 20 year old game, should be cheap or even free. If you aren't a graphics snob, and would rather a game that does more than what you expect for a 20 year old game, get RoR and enjoy it.

(**EDIT** It still isn't worth ¬£15. I have played it some more and given it a go, but it still needs basic improvements to make the actual gameplay match the original.)

That's it really. If you are a dev or modder or have any fixes to what I have mentioned, I'd be more than happy to edit my review. The AoE community is an amazing one, and I have learnt so much from them, an had years of enjoyment playing community created campaigns. It's a shame Microsoft didn't consult people who have played and loved the game for 20 years, and they don't seem to care about fixing those issues either. Unless you want multiplayer, stick with RoR. You'll be glad you did.
AoE original: 7/10 (considering the hours of game time and enjoyment it has brought me)
RoR expansion: 9/10 (a great update with more functionality and 4 new campaigns)
AoE Definitive edition: 1/10. (I genuinely regret buying it).
I'm off to play RoR.

Other gumpf:
I bought this game thinking that I'd be getting a polished, sparkly, updated version of the original. I was expecting the same campaigns (which it has, plus another one for the Hittites), I was expecting all the features that the new games had that the original doesn't (remember when you couldn't unit queue? Myself and Pepperidge Farm remember), I was expecting an enhanced scenario editor where I could make historical campaigns the way I wanted to and play them with all the depth and detail I have come to expect from online AoE scenario and campaign sites, and that I try to emulate. I was expecting polished graphics, and easier online connectivity, fit for purpose going into the 2020s.
And by and large, I'm really quite disappointed.
Here's a few disclaimers about the way I play: I don't do multiplayer, and even having played the game for a long time, I'm still not very good. As I said, I try to make historical battles and campaigns. I'm not a pro or a modder, just a standard user who likes RTS games and a really keen interest for history.

Been a microsoft Age of Empires / Mythology fan since the early 2000s and i always found these games fascinating. Got so happy about the release of these definitive titles but i can't really recommend AOE1 for now.

First of all, what made me buy this title instead of AOE II was being able to play with ancient cultures, something that most games in general lack, and i saw a chance here, like the Romans and Egpyt, but this game offers a lot of limitations compared to the other games.

[h1]First of all, the pros[/h1]
- Much better graphics
- Much better Interface
- Tons of empires
- Tons of troops and upgrades
- Soundtrack
- A lot of campgains

[h1]The cons[/h1]
- your troops getting stuck at each other multiple times (unable to move)

Overall, this game plays pretty much just like the original AoE (which I have played since release) with some minor differences in feel. The improved graphics look great, the arrows make satisfying snappy sounds when fired, the buildings (and their destruction animations) are a treat to look at, and the water and landscapes look pretty. It's fun to play and looks great (high quality 2D graphics). I logged over 24 hours within the first week after getting it (yay quarantine).

The AI could be improved, however. The pathfinding is still a bit dumb, and sometimes AI opponents will just be too stupid to feed themselves and "starve" - get all of their soldiers and villagers killed with no food in reserve, therefore becoming dead in the water. This really sucks when you get to the Iron Age and have an army built up, and you find out that your enemy is still in the Tool Age and is completely idle. Pillaging a desolate village already destroyed by famine just isn't all that fun. The shortcomings of the AI are disappointing to me, since I usually prefer to play against the computer by myself or with my brother (I'm not good enough to face human opponents).

If you don't get a dumb opponent, prepare to be crushed by catapults and war elephants early on - there is a huge jump between the different difficulty settings, going from far too easy, to brutally difficult (IMO) very quickly; brutally difficult as in being annihilated less than ten minutes into the game even when everyone started in the Stone Age with minimal resources, but then again, I'm still not that good at AoE even after all these years.

Then, when I had gotten a good game going against competent AI opponents, I had problems with them resigning when I started to win against them (literally after they lost just a few houses and towers, "RESIGN!". This is easily fixed by editing the .per files using a text editor like Notepad to disable resignation (change to 0 to a 1 in the Death Match and Random Map .per files and enjoy crushing your enemies with relative impunity).

Minor complaint is that sending a game invite through Steam seems to do nothing - other player tries to join the game, waits 5+ minutes, and still can't get into the lobby. I have to make a public match and kick anyone else that joins besides my bro (sorry). Also, I realized that you have to select unranked match to play against AI online rather than selecting Death Match or Random Map when creating the game.

If they fix the AI incompetence and pathfinding issues, this game would be perfect. I would have literally zero complaints. It's all problems with the AI. I would still recommend getting this game despite this.

[h1]Playing with friends? Forget it.[/h1]

Friends on Steam joining your multiplayer lobby via invitation causes the game to hang and ultimately crash for them. Why? After investigation on the Steam forums, unless joining players log into an Xbox Live account (including the host), the game doesn't know what to do and, as said, just hangs and breaks.

Clearly the devs haven't covered situations where Steam players don't use Xbox Live, which in the days of Microsoft Game Store exclusivity wasn't a problem. New store, new platform, new problems.

What's more - how come the newer game, Age of Empires II Definitive Edition, doesn't have this problem?! It's weird. This makes me think that it's an oversight as opposed to a strategic, snide, 'use our online service or get an incomplete game' move. It's been long enough since the Steam release though - must be low priority. Low priority = 4 players (including myself) refunding.

Shame.

If you played the original, know that most changes are on more modern graphics, but there's also a new soundtrack, some minor changes on UI/playability and civ balance, and some completely remade campaign maps. In my opinion, worth it for the sale price but not full price, considering the original still runs on Windows 10 and much, much faster on low/middle end computers.

Visuals: everything is gorgeous. Change the zoom level in settings for even more detail and gorgeousness while giving up playability. Cutscenes have been replaced with voiced actors for Instructions.

Sound/Music: sounds have been remade completely. Each original sound has been replaced with re-recorded variants, but keeping the essence of those original sounds, making them less repetitive. Music has been rescored, but to me it has lost some of its magic this way.

Playability: some standard features have been added such as gather points, autorebuild farms. Hotkeys now depend on the position for each button in the UI, not on the unit's name, but I think it was reconfigurable. Units may now walk over farms (this was not possible in the original). All these changes are appreciated. Some civilization bonuses have changed slightly for better MP balance. You can play random maps using the 1997 assets if you want, but some visual features are broken (i.e. look worse than the 1997 AoE/RoR), for example some trees have no shade, water has no waves, etc. Even in this mode it still requires the same specs as the DE, so it will run much worse than the original on older systems.

Campaigns: campaign maps tend to follow the same structure as the originals. I haven't checked if some are identical (sans visual enhancements) but at least are very similar in shape and feel. Some maps have been completely remade, but didn't feel anything was missing, I only noticed because some maps were new and gave some freshness to the game.

Overall, it preserves the essence of the original with more modern graphics and audio, but it's hard to justify paying $10 for this if you already have the original, other than curiosity.

The difficulty I find in reviewing this game comes from a taste of nostalgia that it so well feeds. Age of Empires: Definitive Edition (AoE1 from hereupon) is of course a well-remastered rendition of the game of the same title from the late 90's. Instead of blathering on about all of the satisfaction this game brings me, I'm going to keep it quite curtailed and just explain the good notes, and the bad.

AoE1 is a real time strategy game built upon a wonderful campaign system that could be completely ignored in lieu of it's robust randomizer engine. Ever wanted to play out a violent war between China and Rome? This game lets you do that, while being completely unforgiving in the process. The AI pathfinding is absolutely horrendous, leading to controlled units aimlessly wandering back and forth while they try to get around the seven trees in their direct path. the AI for the enemy factions are somehow telepathic and often know your strategy way before you do. But that all doesn't really matter, as it's hihgly likely the reason you're looking at this review is to discern whether or not it remains faithful to its original counterpart. It most definitely is. The only major difference of note is that you're no longer limited to just a population of 50, which leads to some very interesting brawls once you break the game with as many cheats as possible.

First thing first, what we have here is a remake, not a remaster. Even though technically, you'll be able to switch to the ‚Äúold school‚Äù visuals from the original [b]Age of Empires[/b], it's a different game and the difference is way bigger than what you can see in [b]StarCraft Remastered[/b], for example. And yet, [b]Age of Empires DE[/b]? It's a remake done right. Even though a lot of stuff from ‚Äúmodern‚Äù real-time strategies was added (for example, you'll be able to use rally points, which were not a part of the original gameplay), pathfinding, which was a pretty big problem back in the days, was improved again (it was already improved in [b]Rise of Rome[/b] expansion before), there's a new zoom feature, etc, etc, etc.

The funniest thing, though, even with all the changes, the game manages to feel the same somehow. I'm not kidding. I've played (and finished) the [b]Definitive Edition[/b] and the original [b]1997[/b] version side-by-side and I must say ‚Äì the original soul is totally here. You loved the original [b]Age of Empires[/b] back in the days? You'll love the updated version. Especially since all the campaigns from both the main game and its official expansion are here. Heck, even the [b]First Punic War[/b] campaign from trial version of [b]The Rise of Rome[/b] (which wasn't in the full game, in case you didn't know that) is included! I totally love the attention to details here.

Now, about the bad stuff. First of all, the atmosphere sucks. I mean, yes, gameplay-wise, this game feels totally right. But stupid new voiceover? It just sucks. Especially that awful narrator who'll narrate all of the briefings. I mean... the original [b]Age of Empires[/b]? Even though it had quite a lot of bright colors in it, there was a certain kind of atmosphere in it. Which was one of the reasons why so many people called it a mix between [b]WarCraft[/b] and [b]Sid Meier's Civilization[/b]. And even though I never liked such comparison much, I mist admit, there's sure something in it. The voices of your units, the music, the menus... there was a certain mood in all that. And the new voiceover and menus? The game started to feel way more bright thanks to them. Almost like a comedy (again, all thanks to the stupid narrator). All the darker mood is gone now and the game began to feel more like... well... more like [b]Age of Empires Online[/b]. If you know what I mean. Atmosphere-wise? It's more [b]Settlers[/b] than [b]AoE[/b]. And I can't say I like it. Doesn't sound like a big thing, sure, and in a way it is not (especially since [b]AoE[/b] always relied on multiplayer quite a lot and it's not like you'll need atmosphere there, simply because you won't have time for that), but still, I can't help but feel that certain something was ruined together with the old atmosphere.

The cutscenes were also completely removed with pretty much nothing to replace them (again, nobody played [b]AoE[/b] for cutscenes, but still) and, well, there's a lot of small cons here. For example, optimization can be better (got a lot of weird [b]FPS[/b] drops here and there), [b]Xbox[/b] integration is a little big bugged (achievements can pop up with some delay and in my case one of them bugged and, while being unlocked in [b]Steam[/b], stayed locked on my [b]Xbox[/b] profile), while [b]AI[/b] is pretty dumb. Can't say I hated dumb [b]AI[/b] much, though. I mean... make the computer way too smart and [b]AoE[/b] just won't feel the same. There was a certain balance between smart [b]AI[/b] and the old school experience and personally? I think they did it all right here. They even kept the [b]AI[/b] being exactly as nasty as it was back in the days. Leave one enemy villager alive and in only a couple of seconds he'll build a freakin' empire right around the corner. That certain feeling of frustration from the original [b]AoE[/b]? It's still here. And I loved it. Because that's exactly how I remember it.

Like I've said, if you liked the original [b]1997[/b] game, you'll love the [b]Definitive Edition[/b]. And that's what you call a success, I guess. All the bad things about this release are minor, while all in all, it's pretty much as good as you'll want it to be. It's also nice to (finally) see a proper [b]Steam[/b] release. With [b]Steam[/b] achievements (which won't be disabled by cheats, but still), online leaderboards and all the original [b]Xbox[/b] features intact (yes, you'll still be able to get your [b]G-points[/b] if you'll buy this game in [b]Steam[/b], just make sure to connect your [b]Xbox[/b] profile in the main menu). There's one thing you should know about [b]Age of Empires[/b], though. See, this game is not for the new players. You never played such games before? Go for [b]Age of Mythology[/b] or [b]Rise of Nations[/b] first (both are presented in [b]Steam[/b]). You'll get a pretty good idea about how such games work and will be able build up some skill without suffering much. [b]Age of Empires[/b]? It was always a bit rough. And the [b]Definitive Edition[/b] kept that intact. Don't expect this game to go easy on you. Even on the lowest difficulty out there, new players have all chances to be brutally defeated. [b]AoE[/b] is just one of those series that may actually worth playing in a wrong order. Just because the first one was allways the most hardcore out there. You either know exactly how to achieve things, or die in agony.

It's a good thing, though. I mean, I just wanted to mention that. Just in case that kind of info will be useful for somebody. When it's about remakes, nobody likes it when the good old games become casual crap. When the original game was challenging? You want it to stay that way. [b]Crash[/b] got it. [b]Age of Empires[/b] got it too. And with easily accessible multiplayer? I'd say, this one is a must have for all [b]Age of Empires[/b] fans out there. It's almost as good as remake can be. You want it to be closer to the original? Dust off your original [b]CD[/b]s. Dixi.

I first discovered Age of Empires in the Xmas 1997 issue of PC Zone. It was on the demo disc (where I also discovered Grand Theft Auto) it wasn't a timed demo, just a restricted one, and it played the hell out of it all the way up to October 1998 when I finally caved and bought the full game. It was naturally usurped by AOE2, which I've sank many days into over the years. In doing so, the original was forgotten. I was hoping that this "Definitive Edition" would reignite my love. It didn't.

They've got some nerve calling this a definitive edition as there are numerous problems, not the least of which is the game suddenly cutting off and returning you to the desktop, and there's nothing you can do about it. Sometimes you'll get lucky and manage to finish a game, other times you won't! The interface is more detailed and user-friendly, but the controls feel clunkier and, compared to AOE2, you'll have no order over your armies, who just go off to do what they want instead of lining up in formations.

With less technology than the sequel, there's not much incentive to go back to the original Age of Empires outside of the nice visuals and orchestral soundtrack (assuming that you are not driven mad by the game just cutting you off as soon as you get going). Microsoft Games R-E-A-L-L-Y need to patch the hell out of this. But they won't.

If you are looking for a modern rendition of AoE 1 this is not it, this is more of a graphical update and the minimal QoL features for it to be considered a remaster. The shift queuing of tasks is broken so it leads to a very frustrating experience. The pathfinding for units is a mess and leads to inefficiencies.

If you are looking for a scrappy economy to play with and try to suss out an army, this is a good game. If you are looking to field hundreds of legionnaires and storm the enemy fort, this is not it, go play Rome Total War.

The naval game play is boring, artifacts are historically cool to look at to see how they evolved into relics, wild animals actually take down huntable animals.

The game feels a bit on the sluggish side, primarily because the GUI is a weird mix of modern and terribly dated elements. The nice graphical display of campaigns is replaced with lists that do not indicate progress. I really wouldn't want anyone to buy this game if you're looking at it for competitive play, there's too much dumb micromanaging for it to be a pleasurable experience.

If you are looking for historical campaigns and building what-if scenarios, this is a pretty good game to do that from. However long term support seems scant, in comparison to AoE2 DE this game seems like a ghost town. I'd advise against putting a lot of time and energy into this game.

It's really tough to know what to make of this game.  If nothing else, Definitive Edition is certainly true to the original, to the point of it being a fault.  The updated visuals are impressive, and certain quality-of-life features (like handy tool-tips that remind new and veteran players alike which buildings house which upgrades) are welcome additions.

However, I do feel quite strongly that the window dressing wasn't the only thing requiring an update.  One of the major reasons why AoE2 is hailed in the best in the series is due in large part to the wide variety of strategic unit options available for guiding and fielding armies.  That the same unit tactics were not put in play in this Definitive Edition of AoE1 strikes me as something bizarre as it is frustrating, even for a seasoned player of the original.  I can only imagine how many newer players likely resort to cheat codes to clear campaign missions because the all-too-faithful retention of the game's original AI will cause units to pathfind incorrectly around terrain features, or clump up and pause before attacking a target or retreating.  Losing units (and potentially entire missions) to one's inexperience or incompetence as an RTS player is one thing; doing likewise because of antiquated AI entirely another.

That's why it is so difficult to recommend this title as it stands.  On the one hand, I am very accustomed to the kind of jank this sort of game had back in the early- and mid-90's, but we are nearly thirty years removed from those kinds of software limitations being acceptable.  Had the AI, pathfinding, and versatility of unit tactics been brought up to the same spec as AoE2 I wouldn't have any issue heralding this iteration of AoE1 as a worthy update to the original.  But given that the game plays in so archaic a fashion despite the more modern appearance will surely drive away newer players, or players more accustomed to AoE2 (or even 3), I cannot in good faith recommend this as a purchase for anyone save the most die-hard AoE fans.

The first Age of Empires was a game that defined the RTS genre way back in the '90s. It's one of the classic Windows games everyone has played before. That being said, should you spend ‚Ç¨20,- to what is essentially a 20 year old game?

Yes. Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is everything the original was and more. It has all the classic campaigns with those from the expansion packs included, all with stunning visuals that mimic the old-school feel of the original while being a significant update at the same time. The game looks exactly what you remember the original looking like.

I haven't played a lot of other RTS games, so I might be biased, but Age of Empires is one of those games that is endlessly fun, replayable and, with the newly improved AI, challenging.

Microsoft made one of the best remasters in recent memory, and all for ‚Ç¨20,-. You'd be a fool to skip out on this, whether you're here to relive old memories or step into ancient warfare for the first time; you're guaranteed to have a good time.

Outside of that everything stays the same, AI know excactly where you are from the start, pathfinding is still worse than that of an ant on a computer screen. Army formations remain something that ancient people weren't able to fathom with their lizard brains according to this game.

Nations do not feel unique at all, just 4 old tired architecture sets, 4 wonders and widely shared unit types. Every single nation seems like the Greeks were roleplaying as Hittes, Babylonians, Egyptians - just name it. That basically counts as cultural appropriation so much hated among PC crowd these days LOL.

What about implementing saving & restoring of multiplayer progress? It's the current year not late 90's anymore...

19,99‚Ç¨ is a LOT of money especially today - better to spend it f.e. on food than on the game in such sorry state.

This version is just awful. If you enjoyed the original and Rise of Rome back in the day, chances are you are going to be massively disappointed. 

- The re-imagined music is forgetable, it does not really sound anything like the classic music in the original. Same with some of the voice lines, most of the iconic voices are gone. 
- The pathfinding is atrocious, somehow they made it even worse than the original, which just blows my mind. 
- The AI is incredibly cheap to play against, even on the eaiser difficulty settings. When attacking an AI base they just run all over the place and spam Town Centers and villagers making it very tedious to hunt them all down. There is also an option to increase the population to 250 (if I remember correct) but all that happens then is that the AI goes crazy and spams an never ending army of Legions. 
- This is really nitpicky but I actually hate how the game itself looks, it just looks bland and unappealing. Some of the newer models look pretty good, like the Hoplites and some of the buildings. But overall it does not actually look or feel like Age of Empires but rather some cheap knock off. 
- The achivements are a joke, too few and really uninspired. 

To call this version of the game the Definitive Edition is just insulting, stay away from this one and stick to the original. Or get the Definitive Edition of AoE2, because that is actually worthy of the name Definitive.

After having played and loved Age of Empires 2 for decades, I decided to give this classic another go. Man, am I sorely disappointed. The AI on this... Is overwhelming. I've restarted a map several times, and yet I can never seem to get a good handle. I'm by no means a rookie either to strategy games. Another match I tried, I literally had NO GOLD at all around my starting area. Explored an opponents area, and lo and behold, he had tons of gold over there. But by me? Nothing. There are no gates, the towers operate horribly. Units don't go into formation, and the AI pathing is just pathetic. Don't waste your twenty bucks on this game. It might be worth it for a few bucks, but I feel quite jilted on this purchase.

I just can't recommend this game. It's ok, I guess, but not great.
The pathfinding is really awful, your armies never group together and as for formations? Forget it, there are no formations. An army of Hoplites that can't use a phalanx? What a joke...

Also, the graphics aren't even that nice. It looks like the old backdrop from the original, only the character models look out of place, as if floating GIFs on the battlefield, it looks odd.

Even the largest skirmish maps are tiny, you normally have barely any space to build and your buildings take up tonnes of space - you almost never have enough room to build all the houses that you need.

All and all it's not terrible and doesn't exactly come at a steep price, but I think the original graphics were better, if a little more pixelated. Overall, I'm extremely disappointed with this product; especially considering how amazing Age of Empires 2: Definitive Edition looks. 

A real half assed job. No love put into at all. I just can't recommend it.

I usually tend to sugarcoat things (hence the recommendation), but this time, I've decided to be a tad bit more critical, since the original age of empires with the rise of rome expansion WAS my favourite game and probably STILL IS my favourite strategy game of all time, despite me not being able to play it since long due to technical reasons. The announcement of AoE: DE was a shock for me, I volunteered to test the beta, and got my hands on a relatively early build. I was stoked, but also a tad bit disappointed: the visual and musical overhaul was amazing, but didn't have the charm of the original, the mechanics were pretty much in shambles, and made some games really unenjoyable, to the point, where (although I'm not proud of it) I lost my commitment as a tester. Well, time passed, and I read about some interesting changes, positive and negative feedback from other testers, and even players, after the original release - one in particular, that piqued my interest: classic mode, with the original visuals and music was available now. At one point, I collected my spare shekels, waited for a sale, and got the game for 10‚Ç¨. It was worth it. Much better performance than the beta (speaking single player-wise, since I've never been so confident as to step into multiplayer blindly), and the classic mode just hits the right spots. Now on the downside, it's still a mess sometimes. Pathfinding is still terrible, the new graphics tend to make my hardware go "nope" in some cases (I run an office laptop, nowhere near a gamer setup, mind you) and since needs of players far progressed since 1997, the game might seem lacking, if played constantly (it has and always had way less replayability than the second implementation). Regarding the last part though, we can't blame the devs for trying to minimize changes to the authentic design - even though personally, I wouldn't mind some new civs added to the original roster, despite a major part of the community hexing people who even mention something "cashgrabby" "money-milky" as that. As a remake, this game holds its ground, with future updates even so, but I believe the limited potential overshadows the simple fun the game is offering. Not for me though, a simpleton like me could go centurion rush the AI hundreds of times without being a tad bit bored...

Absolute trash, breakdown to follow.

Graphics - they added a slight pixel increase, which blurs most of the time so it looks largely the same as AOE2.
Game play - they took about a third of play options from AOE2 and made those only partly work sometimes.
Multiplayer - Works for less than half the people who try to log in.
Login - XBL will lock up for most people trying to log in for the game which then just lags the game.
Steam - Won't even recognize player invites.
Controls - they took about a tenth of what AOE2 has and they only work about half the time.
AI - AI either stomps the players earning resources at more than 10x the player rate or it forgets to gather at all.

Overall - I'm honestly surprised any publisher would release this, or that any dev team would think this is worth charging players or paying workers for.

Multiplayer is absolutely broken. Invites via Steam just stay "connecting to lobby" permanently and require the game to be shut down via the task manager, and if you go through the trouble of creating a Microsof XBOX Live nonsense account, you will have wasted your time because when you try to invite your friends through that, surprise - they wont even show up in the list. The only way you can set up a multiplayer lobby for your friends is by making a public lobby, but get this - there's not even a way to set up a password for a lobby, so while waiting for your friends, you'll just have to kick everyone else that tries to join. And even when your lobby is public, it's not guaranteed your friends will see it. You just have to keep recreating the lobby until they do.

With all that in mind, Microsoft support for games you bought on steam is basically nonexistent. If you want to play with your friends, this game seems more trouble than it's worth.

EDIT: Oh, and if you want to enjoy the game single-player, tough luck. The campaign missions flip from dreadfully easy to almost impossible in an instant, and some of the campaign chapters seem out of order. In random maps, even on hardest difficulty, the AI doesn't really know what it's doing and barely poses a challenge, even a to player who doesn't care about perfect strategy.

The most fun part of the game for me was being able to revisit a childhood favorite with brand new graphics, but once the novelty wore off, there was just a lot of frustration.

Ah this bring back so many memories, i used to play this when I was a kid, finally got this game again, 20 years down the line.
I was very excited about this plus the graphics look amazing, but the first match i player ruined my experience, the did a 1v1 vs the AI on standard, i couldn't believe how overpowered the AI was, i mean there was no way i human could beat it, i mean even during battle AI was taking almost 10 desicions per second in different areas of the map, which a real person could never beat, after getting defeated in the first battle and the map completely running out of wood/gold/stone i somehow managed to raise another army with just food and the leftover of my gold stockpile, and attacked again, now mind you this was a map in which there was a big land mass in the middle surrounded by water, both the teams on the same land mass, the AI had like infinite amount of boats and i my ships were all destroyed in the first battle and now with the map completely out of wood, i was not able to make any more ships, i could have traded but my market was destroyed and i couldn't make it for the same reason.

Now after i raised my second army, i managed to destroy all the buildings and all the units of the AI, all there was left with boats, now i tried luring the boats towards the shore by making my troops go near the shore,

and i was successful i mean i destroyed around 10 ship like that, also i built some towers around the shore to increase my line of sight and that killed another 5 but even after that the game wouldn't finish, 

Now i looked up, and to win by conquest, you have to destroy each unit and building to win, now these ships, i could literally see them running into the fog of war and i tried to think of some other way to lure the ships near the shore to destroy them but i was not able to do anything, 

Now thinking maybe there is just one ship left over somewhere and there is nothing i can do because i don't have any ships, i finally decided to use the the cheat code to reveal the map and to clear the fog of war,

I couldn't believe what i saw, i could see at least 35 ships lined around the the edge of the map and the corner of the map, and they weren't even trying to attack they were just idle here, it's like the AI figured out it was going to loose and decided to hide troops to not loose the game, 

Then i decided to get this over with i used the cheat code to get wood and gold, i made ships and tried attacking these AI ships, now to surprise, these ships were not even attacking back they were just trying to run away

Finally i finished the game, and i was very disappointed, this was my first game of AOE 1 after a very long time and i couldn't believe how the AI was so overpowered and cheated

I seriously hope the the devs fix this, it's very disappointing to buy one of your favourite games as a child, and have this kind of an experience
