Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is a remaster of the game which partially was responsible for the the golden age of RTS games.

For an ancient game, so much was improved in the visual department that this can almost be reconsidered a remake. 
While AoE 1 isn't a masterpiece like AoE 2, it's still a great game with very solid mechanics.

Its age shows mainly in the lack of different units and overall cultural diversity of factions compared to its successor. But that's pretty much the worst thing I can say about it, which is saying a lot in itself, considering this game is 20 years old.

Both AoE Definitive Editions can be extremely enjoyable even without the faintest hint of nostalgia goggles on. Personally I prefer the second one a lot over the first, but it by no means diminishes the fact that this is still a very great RTS game, even without state of the art 3D environments.

I postponed this review many times "maybe it'll get better", "let's try this last little trick"...
But here it is: it WAS one of the greatest game from my early years experience. So how not to be curious and try to get back to those nice memories? Microsoft knew that the bait was strong in the community, so they just wrapped it up quickly with so much flaws.

- the game is almost exactly the same, alright, it was the deal (much more beautiful indeed... no autosave or decent pathfinding though?). I can enjoy that.
- "oops cannot run on Win8". Had to wait to buy a new computer to run it -_- (well played microsoft)
- new computer, more than enough to run it: umbeliavable lag at the start, to the point you can get black screens and windows itself prefers to consider it dead. Not sur what kind of coal technology they used to optimize their game experience, but the game DOES have to warm up 15 min of lag/freeze to finally be playable.
- Let's not talk about the glitchy and invasive online game system... 
- AoE DE is out for a while already. What a surprise to see that all the bugs people were reporting ages ago are still a pain in the ass. I tried dozens of fixes, reinstalled all my drivers and even windows 10, for zero improvement. It's 2020 and AoE I can't run smoothly or without the threat of crashing. What an achievement.

I will finish the campaign mode and burry it again were it belongs: cool memories. (Still not sure it worth the frustration and pain?)

I tried really hard to enjoy this game but I cannot recommend it at all, just get aoe2. aoe1 is just a downgrade in every single aspect imaginable. Firstly the ai is dogshit, the amount of times ur vills just afk and get stuck between a rock or a tile is astounding, secondly a lack of commands for units results in a heap of frustration, enemy boats or units seeping thru ur defences cos u cant patrol ur army to protect anything is quite annoying. Also i hate the enemy ai, its like it has some sort of tunnel vision maphacks with constant swarms of enemy units that seemingly are homing missles on ur villagers no matter where they are on the map.  really slows down progress when ur vills constantly getting massacred. The game is slow and lack of end game upgrades makes taking enemy bases a bit tedious, i play on max speed but campaign missions still mostly take over an hour to beat as u usually end up having to slowly advance against towers with enough soldiers to protect siege units and having to stop them going suicide against towers and protect them from cav charges that just reset the whole process if successful. I noticed going all in on navy seems best thing to do almost always as it only costs wood for boat armies and having water supremacy saves you from constant transport raids killing ur vills or boats anniliating all ur eco. But yeah icing on cake that forced my hand on negative review was frustrating campaign mission that was taking over an hour to complete (rise of rome lvl 3) where finally assaulting enemy base and then a random 'you have been defeated' shows up when enemy has no army or eco left. no clue what that was about but sure pissed me off enough to finally admit this game is not worth your time, just get aoe2 and let nostalgia memories of aoe1 keep you afloat instead of playing it and soiling your fond memories.  But hey its pretty now thats about it.

Such a fun game. I know everyone talks constantly about AOE II and that's great. however, let me tell you about the first game. It's pretty amazing too. What's great about it is that you get to experience the dawn of man through the Iron Age, You get to play with ancient Egypt, ancient Greece and ancient Rome. All amazing times in history. I love starting with club wielding cave men and then busting out chariots and elephants! 

The definitive edition is packed with content and although the game is old it looks great. It's definitely missing a few quality of life enhancements the genre is known for. However, it doesn't hamper your enjoyment one bit. 

Knights and castles are great. If you want to travel back to beginning though, then fire up the original and see how it all started. You just may find yourself putting down your knights for chariots for a little while. Don't forget to upgrade those bowmen and learn the secrets of alchemy. 

Take care and happy gaming!

Sadly, the Definitive Edition doesn't update everything to today's standards and is still outshined by its sequel, Age of Empires II.

Things began when I couldn't see a thing due to the tiny UI. And when I changed the scale of the UI the game reset it every time I started the game. I seriously had to manually change the file of the settings to read-only to keep the UI scale.

But the bigger issue are the campaigns. In the campaigns you have a population limit of only 50. Most of the time this is simply way too low. You can't build a strong army while keeping a good economy. You WILL have to cull villagers to make room for an army. Or you destroy your whole navy. And even then it is likely that your troops aren't enough and you have to get more troops to the front before the AI can. Hopefully your economy is still strong enough.

There are also missions where you start with an army, a navy and three villagers. In order to make more villagers you'd have to build a town center and ten houses. But you only have wood for the town center. So you destroy your whole navy to reduce the number of houses needed and start chopping wood with your three villagers...

I also want to mention the very first mission of Babylon. You start with a single priest and wander around trying to find someone to convert. When I found a villager I started to convert him at max. range. But then the game randomly decided that this villager would be enough to kill the priest. Mission failed. 

All these things cause the missions to be unnecessarily lenghty and boring. Truly a missed chance.

A relic from the coffers of the golden age of PC gaming gets a coat of polish and shines just as bright as the day it first released.  Age of Empires Definitive Edition is a remaster and rerelease of the classic real time strategy game that introduced a great many innovations to interface design and UX, and the ancient setting remains fresh and exciting as ever.  A rearrangement of the original soundtrack, a completely new 3D coat of paint, and a number of quality of life improvements and conveniences introduced in later games like Age of Empires II and III and Mythology further improve the experience.  It's as though the game never missed a beat in 23 years.  For those not too thrilled about the mechanical changes, new art direction, or soundtrack, a completely Windows 10 friendly 1:1 reconstruction of the original, quirks and old-school design sensibilities intact.  A great game in a really great package.

I wish there was a mixed option for this review, seeing as I cannot recommend this game nor can I not not recommend it. 

Pros:
-High resolution graphics
-Nice update from the original game (animations and visuals in general)
-Combines everything from AoE and AoE RoR into a single game
-For those looking for that old feeling of playing the original game, you will feel it

Cons:
-So many things could have been improved to make this a much much less irritating experience

1) No troop formation: Troops just wander and bump into each other continuously making it almost impossible to control and perform an effective attack or defence. It's hard to control more than 10 units, imagine a whole army. You have to select one by one in order to move them where you wish them to be.

2) Pathfinding sux: Troops and villagers get stuck all the time. If you don't pay attention, you might find out 15 minutes later that that villager you sent to build a watch tower was stuck in the forest all along. Combine this with the absence of troop formation, it becomes impossible and very painful to use strategy in a game that relies mostly on using strategy. 

3) Priests range is 10+ yet for some reason they won't start healing unless the unit is almost completely next to it. Sometimes I have 5 or more units all wounded very close to the priest yet he doesn't do anything. Same thing for some units like War galley that won't start shooting enemy units on sight. No matter what position you choose for them, they see enemy troops next to them such as a villager constructing a building and they just stand there without any reaction. 

Another issue with range is that your war galleys have 8 range and the enemy tower has 6 or 7 (less than you), yet for some reason, go figure, your boats need to get into the tower's range in order to shoot it and at the same time be shot by it? What's the purpose of having increased range if they put themselves withing enemy's towers range?

4) Population caps at 50 in campaign: How are you supposed to beat a very difficult AI that constantly spams attacks at you and rebuilds everything that you destroy, when you have 20 villagers on resources, 10 boats and 20 army units = 50 population. 

5) AI cheats or difficulty setting is bugged: I circled an enemy on an island, no resources left to gather, for 30 minutes continuously killing his villagers and troops with my boats without suffering any damage on my side, yet the AI never stops sending troops my way and never stops rebuilding every building I destroy (Easiest mode).

5)General bugs like a Gazelle running and stopping at mid-air jump  position. 


I know the original game lacked everything I mentioned here, but how hard would it be to make a better pathfinding and options for troop formations like in AoE2? I doubt anyone would complain about this for not being like the original game.

Everything has been updated, the game looks great, the game plays really well in 60 frames per second with new UI features (Zoom in and out and more), the sound track has been recreated with a orchestra and most of the sound effects have been updated. 
An extremely well polished and modern looking release of Age of Empires and a guaranteed nostalgia blast from the past.

However! Pains me to say, some of the changes they have made in my opinion have taken from the original feel of the game that I remembered and liked and have left me feeling a little disappointed.

Some of these changes, the new death sound effects and the new soundtrack (don't get me wrong, sound great) but do not work as well as the originals did.
They also tossed out the original intro video and replaced it with a puzzling new one that looks like it was nothing more than a place holder. 
The main menu and interfaces have been completely changed as well and don't give me the same wow factor the original did.

Regardless of these things, a still very good buy in my opinion!

If you've got plenty of cash to buy all the latest equipment, bells and whistles, you might enjoy this old Microsoft Game that's been tweaked to work like a modern one.  I played this back in the last century on my PC...it was really fun then.  I play all my games on PC - no Xbox, no tablet, no iPhone.  I was interested to see a version of it available here since I can't play my CD version on Windows 10.  I bought it from Steam and played it for several months...enjoyed it a lot.  Then came the Build 34483 "upgrade", which auto-installed and which I can't reverse, and it totally screwed up the game play.  Screen froze with no keyboard or mouse control, game crashed,  Task Manager was shut down, it even turned off power to the monitor.  Cold reboots, lots of frustration. Why can't Microsoft write code to avoid screwing up a working program?  

Long story short:  NOT RECOMMENDED unless you like having to re-tune your computer or other device the next time MS decides to "upgrade".

Originally released in 1997, [i] Age of Empires [/i] was the first game in the [i] Age of Empires [/i] series, followed by an expansion pack, [i] The Rise of Rome [/i], the following year. This game, the [i] Definitive Edition [/i], is a fully updated re-release of the original game and its expansion.

This game is a historical RTS covering a massive span of human history, roughly from the end of the last Ice Age to the fall of the Roman Empire. It contains multiple sprawling campaigns, each of which should take between 6-12 hours to complete, plus the option to play skirmish games against AI opponents. It also contains online multiplayer and a scenario editor, but I have little experience with either, and so will not discuss them in this review. 

On the positive side, the game looks gorgeous, and the remastered soundtrack is pleasant without becoming grating. The campaigns are fun, and are generally challenging without suffering from the unpredictable and infuriating difficulty spikes that plagued those in the original game. The AI can put up a substantial challenge to the player, and actual strategy is often required to win. Although all factions share the same overall set of technologies, units, and buildings, no faction has access to all of them. This, combined with various faction bonuses (ex. gold miners work 15% faster), ensures that no two factions feel exactly the same.

On the negative side, unit animations are somewhat stiff, and unit pathfinding can often be atrocious, requiring the player to effectively "babysit" their units. The AI, while capable, often relies on spamming one or two unit types, forcing the player to spend a large amount of time fighting off whack-a-mole raids.

Overall, [i] Age of Empires: Definitive Edition [/i] is an excellent remake of what I feel to be an unjustly forgotten classic RTS. If you love RTS games, ancient history, or both, pick this one up.

This is mainly an aesthetic update with some technical changes to the timeless classic age of empires and as such does not improve the pathfinding or any other issue the game had since 20 years and thats probably fine. 
However while most aesthetics of the original have been captured really well, some characteristic visuals have been reduced or cut completely for no apparent reason.
- Far less blood and no more blood on bodies.
- No rotting bodies or skeletons (if wc3 reforge can keep their skeletons and imporve upon them why can¬¥t AOE?)
- If you turn the detail level up you won¬¥t be able to zoom out as much.
- Bodies of water now all have a current, making lakes and rivers weirdly swell and contract.
Others issues:
- Game now allows population settings higher than 50 (up to 250 like aoe2) which the AI Players can¬¥t handle at all.
- The AI and difficulties for MP are borked and have never been fixed.

*I RECOMMEND YOU SHOULD NOT PAY MORE THAN 5 BUCKS FOR THIS* Happy 2020

So they made it happen. The legendary game in higher resolution with obvisous improvements applied...
Well in my humble opinion, anyone, who was amazed by the game 20 years ago and has a bit of good faith might enjoy playing this game. This remaster has many improvements while keeping the spirit of original Age of Empires. Let me summarize in points:

Definitive pros:
- graphics is MASSIVELY improved, the game is beautiful. Especially on 4K display, it's one hell of eye candy, almost want to say a piece of art.
- gameplay is improved to a level of AOE2 - you can walk over building foundations and over farms, you have queue on units and techs... so basically farming is not annoying, it's even better than in AOE2 (auto-rebuild button triumphs over reseed queue)
- pathfinding IS improved. Allthough units sometimes get stuck on each other, which happened in the original game also, they find way MUCH better. There has been some hate on this DE version pathfinding, but I must confirm, that it is significantly better than in the original game.

Questionable changes:
- the game has been a bit rebalanced, but main mechanics stay.
- campaings have been recreated, some of them or now a bit different, but they are playable and nice. But yeah, some legendary maps, such as Opening Moves, now works a bit different.
- sounds in the game are changed a lot. While some of the changes are easy to welcome, for example triremes aren't damn noisy and overall the game sound is not as disturbing as it used to be, other changes are a bit sad - some building sounds now are alienated, some of the legendary villager taunts (such as "homals" or "zugata") are lost. That is something, which takes down the legacy experience, but it is acceptable.

Cons:
- can't think of something, that is screwed.

If I were to rate this game, I would give it something like 8/10, but in moments of amazement over the visuals combined with feelings of the past the overall impression goes definitely higher.

Fun fact: When released some two years ago exclusive to windows store, MS said that the game won't be available on other platforms... What a miserable marketing claim :)

This game gives you most or all of what you're expecting; it's Age of Empires (including Rise of Rome) with proper widescreen support/functionality on new PCs with a few features which were introduced in Age of Empires 2 (and a few new ones). This means you can walk over farms, there's auto farm-queuing, idle military unit button, waypoints, etc. The units/buildings/art is also updated to look more modern/presentable. 
The campaign missions menu (and victory/defeat screens) also now have voiceover and not just text.

The cons are:
1) Some of the drawbacks of the original game are still there - pathfinding for instance.
2) The game plays the ROR music not the original vanilla music, unless you're playing classic mode.
3) There is a classic mode but it has the new icons/buttons not the original ones.
4) The game overall is still somewhat outdated by modern standards - it's mostly still the original Age of Empires.

I bought this game to play the campaigns, I had this game as a kid and thought it would be fun. Boy was I wrong. The campaigns for this game are impossibly difficult. It is so bad, I am not sure whether the game is bugged, or Microsoft thought it would be fun to increase the difficulty of the game for the Definitive Version but did literally no play-testing. 

The first level on the Babylonian and Hittite campaigns has you convert enemy villagers, then build up a base and destroy your enemies. I literally had an enemy army destroy me before my first building (town center) was even built. Other times I get 5 minutes into it before an enemy army wipes me out. This is before I even have the capability to create an army. Other times I had two different factions teaming up to attack me, who were also supposed to be enemies to each other! The campaigns are literally unplayable, Microsoft chucked this game together with little thought to anything other than a cash grab.

I'm going to go ahead and give this game a lukewarm review. If you played the original Age of Empires back in the day and simply want an HD remaster, go ahead and buy this when it's on sale like what I did. I spent ten bucks and have received many hours of entertainment from this game. However, if you've never played this game, I'd much rather recommend one of the later Age of Empires titles such as II or III. It's not that this game is terrible; the mechanics just haven't aged very well and it can be a very frustrating gaming experience. 

An example is the AI. The AI is terrrrrrible. Soldiers don't do what they're told or they go way out of the way to perform a simple task. There's no way to program your troops, ships or citizens to perform tasks according to importance; you basically have to micromanage everything or else your empire will collapse. I've had so many cheap deaths due to the crappy AI, and a loss of productivity due to the massively flawed AI. 

Other flaws include the population capacity of 50, along with the inability to destroy your own ships (this is especially true of fishing ships, which take up population and once they're done fishing, they're basically a waste of population.) You would think that they would have fixed many of these issues with this remaster; but it's simply a graphical upgrade, the game itself is still broken from over twenty years ago. 

Like I said, I have had fond memories of playing this game back in the late 90's and early 2000's and quite enjoyed this remake. If you're new to the series, though, I strongly recommend II as a starting point. It fixes many of the flaws of the original game, and a much more enjoyable gaming experience.

One of my fav RTS games of all times. I was so happy that it will be reworked. 
Then I found out that only W10 will be supported, so that was a no-go for the original price and that I'd rather find my way back to the original game. So I did.
Steam Winter sale got me to change my mind - ‚Ç¨5? Man, let's see the "product".

First of all, GRAPHICS is well done at first sight, I love(d) the zoom in/out option at first. Only until I fully zoomed in.
Now, I wouldn't have had a problem with this at all, but this game swallowed 16GB of my disk space - and frankly, my expectations where on a very different level. Better not to offer the zoom-in options when there isn't much to offer.
7/10

Moving on to MUSIC.
Here I am satisfied, mostly. Most of the tracks were remastered in a way that I like them, I can still get the feeling that it's the same music that I spent hours and hours listening to in last 20 years.
On the other hand, some of the tracks should've stayed the same, or with minimal changes.
8/10

Next stop is GAMEPLAY.
I've enjoyed the single player and toughest AI that this game could provide for years, taking into account that in the original game were so many bugs, but I got used to them over the years. Now, I expected, that most of these things got fixed in the remastered version after 20 years. And some have been. Pathfinding is somewhat better, but when your units glitch everytime they move, you get a feeling that something got wrong somewhere, when Microsoft decided to greenlight this re-work and asks me to pay ‚Ç¨20+ for the job.
Oh and the AI - so far, I like the improvements (but there was really a lot of stuff to improve)
7/10

Performance of the game on my rig is not what I'd expect either. Game stutters for a few seconds every now and then (but runs well otherwise). It's not a problem, unless you are trying to micromanage your units in an assault, then it really sucks.
6/10

BUGZ BUGZ & BUGZ
It's not that I haven't got used to these glitches and bugs over years, but man, campaign, Hittites, 1st map. Sea is divided by a narrow strip of land, so you have 2 seas that are not connected at all. My fishing ships from the northern sea want to ram through this strip of land to the south. Why? Because I built a secondary dock on that "bridge" - on the southern coast  and this one is CLOSER in a direct line that the dock they can get to. Hilarious. It was impossible to fix a problem like this?? Unbelievable.
Known bugs & problems fixed: 4/10

My conclusion is, that if I haven't bought it on a sale for ‚Ç¨5, I'd be really pissed about this remastered AOE game - which is why I can't recommend this game, at least for the full price.
But I still hope that most of these issues will be fixed (optimization, bugs) before this game gets old. Again.

game for ‚Ç¨5:  8/10
game for ‚Ç¨20: 4/10

Just bought it and played for like 5 hours, 4 games. AOE is really old game, but i remember it as nice experiance.. now.. im not sure. 
-Huge maps are not huge at all. 
-Music lacks the magic of ancient times, and sounds like happy utopia. It lacks war or drums feeling. I keep playing with original AOE soundtrack as its better.
-Graphic is pretty nice, comparing to the old one ofc, but ui looks like to be finished fast to catch deadline.
-Worst thing in this game for now i noticed is pathfinding. Units blocks with each other all the time, and its hard to do anything because if any 2 units get close they stand like braindead zombies not willing to move for few seconds, then they move again. Its 2019 and pathfinding for just damn 20-50 units should be something easy to apply to the game.
- Another design that its really annoying is when you make a group of soldiers and try to give them orders. They will keep roaming around stupidly, so you have to click click every second to fix their attempts to suicide. What is even worse is a fact, that when you have a group of units, and want them to move closer to each other you usually click same point on map waiting till they hug in the area to get formation. Here? No way man! Dont even try! When you click move order to a group they will keep being spread but move a little left or right. So if i want my 6 swordsmen to stand one next to each other, i have to manually move every single one. Because no matter how long i will click move order, they wont gather into that point.
Edit:
- After more time playing.. no big change here. I dont remember if that was like this in original AOE, but when like 4 upgraded arrow turrets cannot fast kill one slinger.. something is wrong here. It looks like that for sake of balance they made towers super weak, which can be ridicilus when few cavalery units just ride by your base and ignore turrets. Just check how much turret can deal damage. Unless u upgrade it to balista (which not all civilisation can do) its useless. 
- I never was AOE pro, but i remember that original game gave me fun. Here im constantly losing games on lowest difficulty setting. Its a bit annoying. Thats the reason of difficult settings to let weak players interesting game and same for pros. Even if i finally win something, it doesnt really give any fun.. its just spamming units until somehow u have more than them. 
-AI is hard some way, but its terrible stupid in another.. for example. You can do Zig Zag wall labirynth as only way to your base, many turrets beside like 10-20 and enemy units will follow this damn zig zag getting hits from turrets, wasting resouces instead doing a proper siege with catapults.

This game is just bad. Cheers.

I initially held off from buying this game due to the greed of Microsoft wanting to force me to use their sub-par console-ported store. I later filled out a survey regarding the future of the series and gave them my opinion on this subject with AOE DE and future AOE games and how they shouldn't be exclusive to their store. I was happy to find out that they had listened to myself and the community and put the game on Steam. However as much as I enjoyed the nostalgia of the taunts, sound effects, music and aesthetic of the game, I found it was wildly unpolished and its AI unplayable. There are several quality of life issues that needed addressed in the original game that should've been fixed when bringing it to 21st century. These include but aren't limited to idle villager buttons, better pathing for units, updated AI and LAN ffs. I highlight these because they were the most noticeable within my first two hours playing against Computers with a friend who also bought the game. As far as a competitive online experience, I could never see myself playing with its current pathing. Sending literally 5 ships down a 5 tile wide river feels like watching one of those old Rush Hour games (game where you have to move a red car to a gap by moving the vehicles around it (Look it up.)) The pathing can turn battles around and makes it near impossible to care about microing units unless its one by one. A lack of an idle villager button hurts because you cant see outlines of units through buildings and they can be idle the whole game if you forget about them. The AI are HORRENDOUSLY easy. I played AOE 2/3 in my childhood and was an 1850~ nonVoobly player recently. I could've been brand new to the game and beaten a Hardest AI 1v1. I played 2v2 with my friend thinking it would be a challenge seeing how the newer AI's in the AOE 2 games have come so far. After stomping the 2v2, we decided to 2v6 which was another waste of time. We decided that the only way to challenge ourselves was to go AFK for 10 minutes at the beginning and play on the most open map. We actually managed to lose that game. The AI all came and singled out one of us with higher tier units and completely walked around the other. If we tried again we would come up with a better strategy and most likely beat them. If the AI are so easy and poorly done that the only way of making it a challenge is to AFK for most of the game, they aren't fun to play with. Until they modernize the game or actually put some money into it, I probably won't play it again. I fully appreciate the effort of Microsoft of revitalizing the game and putting on Steam, but the development was the downfall of this game.

While the graphics have gotten a new makeover and there were some noticeable improvements, the AI are dumb as the rocks they manage to use as weapons. Unless you're looking to PvP, I'd look elsewhere. Seriously, we 2v6'd after giving the AI an 8-minute handicap on the hardest difficulty.

I love Age of Empires. It was the first PC game I really sank my teeth into back in the day, and the whole franchise is near and dear to me. Just so you understand my bias.

Definitive Edition makes for a nice graphical upgrade, running at modern resolutions and with nice textures, performing flawlessly for me.

But the game is still as clunky as it was in 1997, and the AI "upgrades" are just terrible in their execution. 

Regarding the clunk, unit collision and pathing is really bad. Your units will get stuck and require fiddling with - like a lot.

Regarding the AI, playing the campaigns - some of the missions the AI just sends a trickle of it's villagers straight into your base without gathering it's own resources, thereby crippling itself. On other missions the AI consistently sneaks cavalry around your flanks to kill all your gold miners. It seems totally random as to whether the AI is going to work well or completely shit the bed.

AI units are also inexplicably elite projectile dodgers which just feels really "off" when taken with the rest of the AI's issues and quirks.

Overall I still really enjoyed playing the definitive edition's campaign content and it was great to revisit an old classic, but the promised gameplay improvements are not here and if anything they've probably changed AI for the worse.

The classic! Age of Empires redefined the genre of Real Time Strategy. The core mechanics of AoE are simple, yet challenging to master. The gameplay revolves around collecting four different types of resources (food, wood, gold and stone) and using them to expand your civilization and armies. Each civilization comes with its own unique benefits and disadvantages. The players build their civilization through four ages that progressively give better upgrades for economy and military. There are broadly six kinds of units, the villagers that gather the resources, infantry, ranged units, cavalry, siege weapons, ships and priests. A match is won by meeting the victory condition, which can be total conquest, building a wonder and a few more. The player with better strategies, better time management and better multi-tasking always gets the upper hand and in that sense the game is a well balanced strategy game.

[h1] TL DR [/h1] 
Don't buy this until they fix the client, FPS issues and prevent the split community due to two different versions still available.

[h1] Long story [/h1] 

[b]Introduction[/b]
Played Closed Beta and actively contributed in bug hunting, testing and other required activities. Why? Because Definitive Edition looks really good. Love the graphics, love the remaster.

Post Closed Beta, things looked bad. Silence from the developers. No updates, except for critical ones. For a moment, after critical fixes, the game was playable. But then the Steam announcement and Crossplay came. We were happy. A lot of people were truly happy. Finally the stupid exclusive Windows Store only would go away and hopefully draw more players to the game by allowing Steam and Microsoft Store crossplay. It was very positive.

[b]Horror of two clients[/b]
But then the client was released on Steam and Windows. People couldn't update their existing version. Those who did update ran into terrible bugs. Not only that, but the client was completely changed. The UI of the menus was ugly, big. As if playing 640x480 resolution again. 

Worst of them all, there is a split community now. Majority still plays the old client version 27374 and the others play client version 28529. Why there are two clients, nobody knows. But we know that 27374 is more stable, has better UI and more clear browsing. But ELO is messed up and contains bugs, such as no coop mode. The new client, 28529 suffers from FPS issues when doing large wars.

[b]No active development[/b]
There is probably no budget any more for this game. Time is up. And that is how business goes in development. No money == no time. Because of AoE2DE and AoE3DE or any other project have focus now.

Also somewhere on Reddit there was a post from someone on the team, that said that some developers have messed up the project and that saving it was near possible. 

Basically, your typical case of cash grab from Microsoft or any other publisher. Yet I still bought it, because my love for the game has been since 1996. 

Do I hope for a fix/update? Yes, at least if minimum: The split community being united.

Will there be an update for this game? No, I don't think so. Knowing how this business works: No money == no time == no development. Simple as that.

[b]List of messed up[/b]
- No active development any more. Probably no budget allowance for dev
- ELO, they messed up the implementation. 
- Game lobby browsing they messed up. You cannot see Random Map or Death Match difference. It is all reported as 'Custom'. Only ranked games show the game mode. The old client had better overview
- Crashes randomly
- Player positions in team games are bad. Some players are isolated or surrounded
- Map generation is poor and resources spawn in terrible locations or inaccessible places.

20 years of anniversary has been flushed down the drain. Even AoE2DE has been rushed and buggy as hell. AoE2HD was a success, because it had active development. The DE versions get the short end of the stick.

Its AOE1, what more can I say?
Yes the AI sucks.
Yes some of the buildings with techs don't make sense.
Yes pathfinding is a nightmare.
Yes there is no unit management.'
Yes, the computer players still control EVERY UNIT AT EVERY GIVEN MOMENT.
However, its a 20 year old game, and it plays exactly how I remember it. Even the same cheats work! (Best cheat units of the series right here.)

So lets get on to what I think is good about this remaster.

Quality of Life Improvements: It adopts some of the nicer things found in AOE2, like AUTOMATIC FARM RESEEDING. You can also stack technologies in a single building to research, instead of micromanging them one at a time. It also shows progression squares on the upper left of the screen for each tech and unit. You can add 20 units to the queue at a time, instead of 15. A 250 unit population limit, however that is hard to reach because the game was designed with 50 in mind so making excessive armies just seems senseless. The UI is overhauled nicely, and is clean, intuitive, and helpful. Tooltips are where they should be, and not where you don't want them. And there is an idle villager/fishing boat button.

Graphics: At 18+gb, you'd hope that they improved on the graphics. And yes, they're certainly improved. If you don't think so, play the original or even look at screenshots. Animations are much smoother, and higher in detail. However they kept true to the unit and building design across all civilizations. There are small details you notice right away coming from the original game, such as piles of wood where a woodcutter is working, light sheen on the water, and more.

Music: The soundtrack is nicely overhauled, while keeping true to the OST. If you played the original as long as I have, you'll quickly pick up on the tunes representing the songs in the OST. Some could've been improved better, such as "Battle" however, while in the game, it doesn't sound repetitive like it does when you listen to the OST loop for a full 3+ hour game. I do think they randomize.

All in all, if you understand that this is a 20 year old game, and just enjoy it like I do, despite the AI quirks and whatnot, you'll have a fun experience with it. If you want something a bit more refined, grab AOE2 (2013) and add texture mods. I also recommend playing Empire Earth 2, with Mona Lisa's EE2 Overhaul patch (Currently called Unofficial Patch 1.5) for a nice nostalgic RTS kick.

This game was a part of my childhood and the fact that i'm playing it again in 2019 as an adult brings so much nostalgia. Even the pathfinding from the original game is kept the same, which may be annoying to a lot of people but to me, it was totally acceptable because it felt like i'm playing THAT game. So the reason i refunded was because I was hoping I could have fun with the online multiplayer, but it was a letdown because after trying to find an online game without any region filter, all I could find was 2 half-filled rooms in SE-Asia. It just seemed like no one was playing this game anymore even though it was newly released this month, or I might have done it wrong there idk.
To wrap up, it is definitely worth it (with the sales it's even more worth it) to buy this game if you want to feel a piece of your childhood again, in HD graphics. I came from the AoE2 DE remaster and thought to give this classic a shot because thats the one that got me started.
But compared to the AoE2 DE remaster, this remaster looks worse, plays worse, feels worse.
The looks is weird. Im used to rather pixelated figurines fighting and working, buildings nice pixelated buildings and harvesting pixelated resources.
In the AoE2 DE this style is still there while looking higher resoluted, in AoE1 DE it feels weird and too 3D.
I recommend looking at the screenshots on the store page and focus o nthe units and buildings in correlation with the environment, then moving to AoE2 DE and doing the same.
AoE1 just looks out of place. Its hard to describe, but when i started the game the first time and accidentially set the view distance closer, it looked like a different game than i remember, simply because units seem to be rather weird 3D models.

Dont get me wrong, the old version also looks attrocious, but this is not the style i expected to catch the spirit of the old game.
The remaster of AoE2 kind of set an expectation to find a game with a similar visual style AND the convenient features.
Some of these features are still in, yet the gameplay, the UI, the way some things are handled, felt off and not in line with the other remaster.
That might have a simple reason. Because i played AoE1 more when i grew up and ignored AoE2 mostly, i didnt realize how advanced AoE2 was. I never had an actual comparison between the two, never sat down and played both.
AoE1 cant stand up against AoE2 and in fact its so bad i had to refund it. I just would not play it.
Sadly.
So i cant give this DE, Remaster, however you call it a recommendation and rather point to the outstanding AoE2 DE. Which plays better, looks incredible and catches the spirit of these games much better.

Absolute classic of RTS genre with a new updated graphics and a lot of quality of life improvements. Age of Empires as 22 year old game succeeded where  most of the games today fall short at, like: game being played from elementary school kids to 40+ year adults, being easy to learn and hard to master, good enough for both casual and competitive players, being fun playing both single player and multiplayer matches, actual educational campaigns taking you through history of many ancient empires and great military leaders of that time and procedurally generated maps with 16 different civilizations  to chose from which every combination offers a unique match.
Having said that, this being both 22 year old game and first entry in the franchise, it falls behind it's successors in having old game mechanics that were expanded in other Age of Empires games later.
Nonetheless it's still fun and interesting game experience which I would recommend grabbing on a sale if you are not huge AoE fan.

Age of Empires : Not So Definitive Edition 
The hit of nostalgia , finally we can play the game that started off the series.The definitive edition makes some good changes but its still really only slightly better than the aoe gold edition jewel case cd that still is being sold on places all over the world , 
There are a lot of hits and misses but given that the original release had some glaring flaws that are fixed here it's rough game that's playable hopefully more patches bring up the game to clean state. Given the history of the game and its legacy its easily worth picking up in any sale.
Pros:
1) All content included just the same as the gold edition
2) Voices added to the campaigns descriptions
3) good quality improvements in game such as auto farm seeding, idle villager indicator ,  numbers that show how many villagers are allocated to what task, smart ai.
4) A bonus for achievement hunters most of the achievements are focused on single player so as to not force others to the horrible laggy multiplayer part.
PS: Ask nicely on the aoe de discussion forums if someone can help you out with the one mp achievement
Cons:
1) The game is slow feels sluggish poorly optimized.
2) Given the original game was such a small size it could have been included in the package as a standalone
3) The promised switch to retro graphics as a option is very limited
4) The UHD ui/visuals is not that appealing the the original retro ui was clean and still stands out better.
5) The new music feels weak compared to how strong the original was

I would recommend the game if it weren't for the game-breaking enemy AI.
In almost all skirmish games vs the AI, it will resign sooner than expected, not letting you "taste the victory" - sometimes not even letting you taste a fight. 
In 4 out of about 10 matches it happened to me that the AI resigned all of a sudden, when no attack was ongoing at its base. Some other times, it resigned after merely killing a few of its units.

My feeling is that the AI checks how much its score is surpassed by the enemy team, and resignes if it is many times larger.
I play vs AI 99% of my games, so I consider this problem pretty bad, and it severely decreases my ability to enjoy a game that would otherwise be a decent remaster.
I will edit my review in case improvements are made.

EDIT: A half workaround seems to be to play on Conquest victory mode, because then the AI is being forced to stay in-game until you raze it entirely. However, this sucks if you desperately want to play and win with Artifacts or Ruins, or Wonders.
EDIT 2: The game also has missing features compared to the 2nd game, this is not really something I should expect, but something that makes the game much less enjoyable than AoE II. Formations are non existent, military units move around with no order whatsoever (speed isn't even reduced to the slowest unit for mixed armies)... Units also have a large "box" and easily get stuck in passages.
Lack of gates is also something I don't like. I understand maintaining an original gameplay and all, but I just don't like it.

Overall my opinion on the game is 60% nope and 40% yes, so if I could I'd rate it so-so, rather than making a negative review, but I cannot.

EDIT as of 30.11.19
I made some more matches in the last months.
Conquest as the sole victory option is not a fix. The enemy surrenders incredibly fast, presumably as soon as his economy is almost bankrupt and cannot produce units (this is a speculation though). This means that you spend time preparing your production, tech all up, recruit good armies, launch an attack... only to see the AI surrender after a brief battle.
The game gets boring fast due to this. A pity.

The [b]first Age of Empires game[/b] always appealed to me the most, maybe it's due to [i]the memories I have with it[/i], [i]playing it more than the 2nd one[/i] or me [i]just preferring the time period[/i]. I used to play it a lot growing up, I could even say it was essentially the only game I played outside of flash games and I've wanted to re-experience the game for a decade now. So, hearing that the first game will be getting remastered alongside the second one got me [b]really hyped up.[/b]

So was it worth the hype? Depends. If you are only here to [b]re-experience the original game[/b] then [u]yes[/u], it's more than worth it. While it would've been great to have the option to play the game with it's original graphics, it's nothing that bothers me personally. However, if you're looking for anything new, you're not going to find it here and I'd much rather recommend you to check out the Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition instead.

Performance is manageable, pathfinding is a very big [i]ehh[/i] but outside from those two - it's the same Age of Empires I fell in love with in the first place.
Not simply a fresh coat of paint, but an overhaul bringing some much needed quality of life features that make playing this version far more satisfying than the original in every aspect.

It's basically re-mastered version of old "Age of Empires: Rise of Rome" really. Graphics looks better I guess. Few QOL features have been added. So for instance farming requires much less microing. Some of the campaign scenarios have been slightly altered.

pros
- looks nice
- QOL features (eg. autofarms)
- campaigns seem fairly nice so far (currently only Voices of Babylon 1 was bit annoying due enemy unit spamming)

cons
- enemy ai has good microing + often knows where you are despite no los
- ai might need bit rework for random map games (from what I've read)
- your own unit pathfinding is really bad ; dishonorable mention to catapults which are outright more dangerous to you than opponents
- not too sure about multiplayer scene really (though again based what I've read; I personally don't really care much)

Overall I guess I can recommend this game if you've played earlier version or get decent discount.

A remaster of Age of Empires(1997), and a really well done one at that. It's such a good remaster that it made people believe it was a complete remake, and not a lot of people give it credit for that.

[h1]The game functions more or less the same as the original, but with some updated stuff, such as:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Gather points
[*]Traversable farms
[*]Slightly more aggressive AI
[*]Slightly better pathfinding
[*]More intuitive UI
[*]Rebalnces to techs, civs and units.
[*]A few more quality of life things.
[/list]

I would suggest if you expect the game to be more or less the same as the 1997 release, then give the game a go. This game is by no means better than AoE 2, and won't be, even if they completely overhauled everything. 2 is more advanced, and is overall just a more complete RTS experience.

If you have any expectations that this game will be any better than the 1997 release, then this most likely won't be a game for you, since it can be pretty hard on unskilled RTS players, it's still the same game from 1997 with a lot of updated things. It still has some of the same bugs the original had and a few new ones even.

Overall, I like the game, despite that I grew up with AoE 2 when I was younger, I can still appreciate what the original did, and still enjoy it from time to time.

[h1]I'd say get this, if you:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Loved the original, despite its flaws.
[*]Don't have any high expectations for the game to be anything more than an average RTS game.
[/list]

[h1]However, do not get the game if you:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Expect this to hold a candle to modern RTS or even AoE 2.
[*]Have bad patience.
[*]Can't handle moderately hard games.
[*]Have any high expectations for the game.
[*]Expect this to have updates to mimick AoE 2.
[*]Can't handle lowered frames when zooming.
[*]Have only multiplayer in mind.
[/list]

I know it sounds like the game is bad when I say all this, but I do like the game, and the original 1997 release with the Upatch, I just think the reviews speak for themselves. It's not a game for people expecting it to be anything that is highly superior to the original, because it's really only a minor step up, outside of visuals.

If you played the original, then this game is well worth it if you pick it up on sale. The reason I say that is because since this is a newer version of AoE, there aren't very many mods for the game compared to the original. The online for the game operates off of the ELO ranking system which I do like. (ELO is the same system used by Halo 3 back in the day and I find it superior the the ranking systems used by Starcraft, Halo 5, and R6 Siege since it gives you a more accurate reading of where you stand in the rankings.) My biggest gripe with the game is the campaign narrator. The narrator is absolutely obnoxious. Talks like he is speaking to a bunch a 5 year olds. It's so bad I don't even pay attention to the campaign descriptors which gives you info on the mission, background history of the event, and hints on how to complete the mission. If they added a way to mute or disable the campaign narrator, then I'd be grateful. Another small nitpick I have is the building destruction animations are too smooth. It's like the building just kind of melts on itself. Nothing collides, it all just kind of slides on itself. It's hard to describe, but it is noticeable when you watch the animations. Otherwise this game gets a recommended from me since it is just an upscaled version of the original AoE and plays exactly like the original with 3d models and better graphics.
not a must, but the QOL and graphics upgrades are welcome, nice to have, get it on sale. or if you are a fan, do get it full price, as its not expensive

There are quite a lot negative reviews out there. But if you read them, most of them reveal wrong expectations not faults of the game itself. The Game is called: "Age of Empires - Definitive Edition". It is not called: "Entirely new game that includes completly new game mechanics but is losely based on Age of Emires".
Now, it's obvious: If you buy a game called Age of Empires, you'll get Age of Empires. Stupid to believe anything else. We know that Age of Empires had flaws like weak path finding, no formations and things like that and although pathfinding was improved, it's still weak and you won't get formations, gates for your walls or anything like that.
There are some new features like auto-replacing farms (without having to pay them in advance like in AoE2) which I think is a huge bonus. As a downer, at least for me, you can walk over them now like in AoE2. So no more farming fortresses...
Of course there are some points that can justify a negative review. Like I experienced some crashes or frozen screens. And the hardcore fans of AoE might realise very quick that some of the campaign maps have changed. Simple example: The tutorial map where you have to convert the siege weapon, where they changed the weapon from a Heliopolis to a catapult and it's position from the bottom right of the map to the bottom left. That might be a downer for Hardcore fans that I could fully understand as a reason to give a negative review.
On the other hand, the grafic look quite nice, the orchestral music is done very good, although I think they played the main theme a little too slow for my liking and they added voice acting to the campaign briefings. Overall, I'm quite willing to give a positive review but add that you might want to wait for a discount as the game mechanics itself are, well, 22 years old and you feel that.

P.S.: They made a trailer starting with "Wololo". How epic is that? I've got no clue why they didn't include that trailer on Steam's shop page.

Age of Empires II is a built up, vastly improved version of Age of Empire and everyone knows this. I would have seen Celtic and Germanic tribes added, alongside Aksum, Nubians, Inds, Dravidians, Aryans as well as a new expansion on the antique world. Don't mind the negative comments regarding unit pathfinding and AI, they remastered the game but decided to maintain the gameplay mechanics from the old game, this is great!

And don't expect this to mimick the very good, but overrated sucessor, AoE 2, this is the first game from the series.

I cannot believe that they put all the time and effort to make these new graphics, but still reused the same atrocious and prehistoric pathfinding of the original game, it actually feels even worse than that.

Your units will constantly fail to attack enemies centimeters away from them, bump and freeze on each other non-stop, take completely non-sensical long routes instead of following a straight line and so on, not to mention the insanely dumb AI.
The new pre-rendered graphics look great, and the new orchestral music is good too, but that's about it, this game is clearly a crude cash-grab on peoples nostalgia. Saying that it's just the exact same old game with revamped graphics and music is no exageration as it has little to no improvements at all.

It can have good nostalgic value, but after one or two matches you will inevitably start to see the abundance of problems that will make you cringe. Would reluctantly pay 5 bucks for this crap at max.

Anyone wanting to truly go back to their roots of 'Real-Time Strategy' _ This is your virtual pathway. 

Original cheats work too :)

Let me start by saying that the advertisements, the trailers, the gameplay videos and the never-ending Twitch Streamers do NOT do this game justice. You must play it on your own screen with your own resolution, and in doing so you will see just how beautiful Age of Empires is. I am truly in awe at the beauty given to the game without destroying what made AoE the first AoE in the first place. Not to mention the higher resolution and updated graphics enable you to see your troops' armour and weapons, so you really feel like you're commanding a force to be reckoned with. I really like the animations as well. Very WarCraft 3-esque,

However, graphical update or not, AoE 1 is still AoE 1. Troops travelling independently of other troops is all well and good when they all wield guns - Command and Conquer is a prime example - but when your soldiers have swords it can be very annoying not having formation options to keep them together to ensure they engage the enemy at the same time. Because of inevitable separation of troops, the soldier who reaches the enemy first is likely to die before he can be backed up, and the same can be said for the second, and the third, etc. It can be a headache working on keeping your army as closely knit as possible in order to maximise survivability, whereas AoE 2, we all know, introduced formations and always kept the troops who moved together close together. This is also quite a difficult game. My adult experiences in AoE 2 have seen me increase in performance from my childhood, but at this game I am just as terrible as always. It's a game requiring absolute focus and a swift mouse hand. Note, there are some, as they say, 'quality of life' inclusions; auto-seeding farms, villager chain-building, etc. This does improve upon the original release.

I do recommend it for those who played it as youngsters, and perhaps some of the modern generation would enjoy it. However, there is a reason AoE 2 is named the timeless, ageless, perfect RTS, and not AoE 1. If you're looking to get into an AoE game, it is perhaps best to buy AoE 2 in three days. I certainly will be getting it myself, as an AoE lover since a single digit age. If they've done for AoE 2 what they did here for AoE 1, I can firmly guarantee...

It's going to make history.

First of all the negative: The pathfinding is utterly broken hot garbage. Villagers will stack up at resources and military units will jam into balls for no reason. The amount of tedious micro required to optimize your units is insane.

Now the good: It looks pretty, it plays smoothly (for me) and it's one heck of a nostalgia trip for a price tag that's well below $60. You can spend a couple weekends digging through the campaigns (both the originals and the expac ones are included) and if you have some friends then you might be able to have few good multiplayer matches. I think it's good value for my money. Your mileage may vary but that's how it goes. Age of Empires has aged, but I can still have some fun with it.

It's a graphical overhaul of an RTS released in 1997.  Gameplay changes are minimal, which might explain a lot of the complaints about the slow pace and questionable pathfinding.  As someone who regularly enjoys experiencing or revisiting older (sometimes MUCH older) games, I should point out that this is what most first- or second-generation real-time strategy games used to be like - try playing the original WarCraft on DOSBox, for example.  Personally, I love it.  I have not experienced any of the FPS problems that people have been having (so far, anyways - I'm only 7 hrs in), and I like the steady pace of the game.  Playing through the tutorial campaign was a huge nostalgia high, too.  I would recommend this to anyone who played AoE back in the day.  If your only experience with the series as a whole has been Age of Empire II HD, though, be prepared to adapt to some charming-yet-outdated RTS mechanics.

Fantastic game filled with nostalgia and fun campaigns, but clearly some work needs to be done to make it more enjoyable. The biggest concern I have found is the horrendous path finding. Villagers and military units often get stuck or just stop what they're doing making it very challenging to navigate large groups of military/villagers. This is especially evident when there is a tight space or many enemies/terrain on either side. An example of this can be seen in the campaign Crossing the Alps. Additionally, the lack of military formations is a feature they should have included in this game. You'll find yourself having to micromanage your units far too often that what I would like. The calvary will always move in first, when you might want to send elephants or infantry before. Regardless, I recommend the game! I only pointed out some of the glaring concerns. I still have a great time playing.

I would have given this game a perfect score, But unfortunately they got some serious historical error in it. The civilizations of Assyria and Sumer structure buildings look like the one of Egypt instead of having unique looking buildings or at least buildings structures Similar Babylon building structures. Since all of (Assyria, Babylon and Sumer) represent Mesopotamia. Other than this historic error, The game looks amazing and plays very well.

Theres the genesis of a good game here, and that game is Age of Empires 2, which given its ready availability and much more active player base is the better place to go for some historic RTS action.

Age of Empires 1 is only worth the time for its nostalgia value, it was the first RTS I ever played and I have fond memories, but the balance and gameplay is just not up to the standards of its sequels. Each civ plays very similarly with only minor bonuses to distinguish them, no unique units or techs, no real differences in strategy, it mostly boils down to cosmetic variations. And what strategy is here is also lacking, theres a limit on strong counter units and trash units, defences are generally poor as the lack of gates   mean leaving your walls open so you can get your own units out, the saving grace here is that the pathfinding is terrible so units will often struggle to get at you anyway, that of course goes the other way too though and often you'll find your units getting killed as half of them have gotten lost trying to walk around a small rock, they also retain their relative positions so you have to manually group them up after they get separated by the bad pathfinding and thats not to mention that units with different move speeds will seperate out while walking, leaving the likes of priests and siege units vulnerable.  Its a shame that this couldn't be adressed or the various formation functions from AoE2 couldn't of been added to this new edition after all if you're remaking a game why not add in some useful functions that have since proved themselves in other games in the series.

Then of course there the multiplayer, there are games available but not many so it may be difficult to get a game in your region, what you do get will be of variable quality none of the matches I played were ranked so I could often get games where I crushed my opponent only to be crushed in the very next game. On top of that the lack of early game defences (like town center garrisoning in AoE2) means theres alot of early game rushes to deal with. In several team games one player would do a VILLAGER rush knock out another player and then the entire team would fold. The other issue due to the low numbers of other players is teams on discord, in several games I played 2v2v2 team matches only to find that one member of each team was in fact   from a group of friends on discord who all turned on their ally to secure an easy victory (Teams weren't locked), it can happen in other games but like I mention the low numbers in multiplayer make this much worse.

Honestly I'll end this by just repeating what I said at the start, go play Age of Empires 2 instead.

This game is a great remaster of the original for those looking for an authentic but much improved graphics experience of the ‚ÄòReal Thing‚Äô. The smoothness of the gameplay is fantastic and everything has been kept very much in the same layout and this brings back some real nostalgic feelings playing the game.

From time to time the controls do feel clunky - especially when you compare it to modern day RTS games - and there could have been more flexibility built into this revamp; for example more streamlined menus or a side bar for unit control on the battlefield/construction queues. As an optional change this would have protected the authenticity for those who prefer the original style of gameplay.

All in all, I‚Äôd recommend it - it‚Äôs delivered exactly what it says on the tin and if you are able to enjoy the new 4K graphics it is a winner all round; but I‚Äôm sure the current iteration of RTS game players would find it a bit too retro.

Age of Empires was a game that was a part of my childhood and I remember spending hours playing it with its horribly scaled graphics (people being bigger than the buildings they were spawned from), slow gameplay pace, and limited sounds. Two decades later the game has been remade with updated graphics, but not really updated gameplay.

I want developers who remake old games to stop thinking the original is infallible and unable to be improved. There's a reason people moved on from Age of Empires to Age of Empires II when it came out. The game was much better. There's a mode in the game to have it be played with the original style graphics and gameplay, but the new mode doesn't seem to fare much better.

While there is some gameplay improvements that help bring the game into more modern RTS's, it should have been improved significantly in terms of gameplay (more in line with AoE 2 or AoE 3) and you can play the "Classic" mode which emulates the original game. I think the current state the game is in would be a great "Classic" version of the game, with its slower pace and bad AI. The updated mode should fix all of these issues and make it a stronger RTS that works more in line with current RTS's.

The original campaigns could be updated so they're not capped at 50 population. It's just a shame that the devs, who remade the original AoE II so beautifully, couldn't improve the gameplay at all. It's just a reskinned port that is lagging behind the times.

Its sad that I have to not recommend this game but in its current state it is not worth the price tag. There is little new in terms of what the definitive edition brings, its mostly graphics which IMO look trashy and don't fit in well. The fact that they failed to even address many of the bugs from the initial game is not only irritating but is sad. Who ever they stuck to "work" on the DE most have been dropped on their head as an infant. Overall, not worth the price even for the nostalgia.

This is the original code base with some extra stuff.

The original was 150ish Mb on disk. This is roughly 1024 times larger.
I think most of that stuff is in the SLP folder which contains unit animations.

There are some small changes as well - i.e. farm maintenance is a hell of a lot easier and the UI is different and a little better.

Can't say it's because this is the soundtrack of my childhood or it actually sounds better, but I do prefer the original MIDI version. Wish there'd be an option to toggle between those two music options.

Apart from that, it's exactly the same game.

This AOE Definitive Edition is simple but is still a bit of a challenge at times at the "Hard" level, and it is fun!

[later review] OK, I have completed all the campaigns and have just over 170 hours of playing time.  I still say that this game is way fun.  I was a little naive about its "simplicity," however. Most of the campaign scenarios were completed at the "Hard" difficulty level, but I had to drop down to "Moderate" a couple of times 'cause I was getting my azz kicked by the AI that many of the negative reviewers have sneered at.

Many of the reviewers have commented that the campaigns in the AOE Definitive Edition are identical to the campaigns in the original; they are wrong.  Most of the campaign scenarios have been tweaked, and many have been totally redone.  One example:  In the original "Spartacus" scenario in the "Enemies of Rome" campaign, you are playing as Rome against Spartacus & the slave army -- but in the Definitive Edition you play as Spartacus.

After 170 hours of playing time -- no freezes, no crashes, no noticeable bugs.

A solid remake, but know what you are getting into. Gameplay changes are minimal, so at its root this is still an RTS from 1997. They added a bunch of QoL elements like better unit training queues (original didn't have any queuing, Rise of Rome allowed you to queue one type of unit per building), higher pop limit, better AI (though a very aggressive one), improved pathfinding (from atrocious to barely serviceable), walkable and auto-renewable farms, etc.

The graphics are wonderful and the remastered soundtrack is nice, though I prefer the original soundtrack because nostalgia. The campaigns have a narrator now which is pretty cool. Some people reported bugs and poor performance, but I can't say I encountered anything within the 12 hours that I have put in so far. There was one minor interface bug which they promptly fixed and they are still actively working to patch the game, so hopefully they eventually iron everything out.

The asking price is pretty fair considering the amount of work they put in, but I would only recommend this if you already like the original. If you never played it, the 2 hour refund window should be enough to make up your mind about this game.

I have a pretty high end PC and I'm getting really bad sudden FPS lag spikes for no reason. This game needs work and until it gets the work it needs to fix the lag spikes on a 2080 ti, I will not give it a good review.

-Update-

In the latest patch, the stutter/lag has been addressed. AoE DE is perfect in my opinion. A must have for any RTS fan or (like myself) old-school gamer.

Same game with a few gameplay improvements, very good graphics and HD music and new sounds for the priest :D.

Another thing that is great is the AI. Do not listen to those who complain about the AI, probably they lose on easy vs 1 CPU. Finally the enemy units wont get stuck on the first tower that they meet on the way as on AOE from 1997, they will try to assault your center of the city. Walls wont help too much because there are no gates and that means that towers are not as efficient anymore, enemy units will just pass by and you cant hide your villagers in the Town Center (as on AOE 2) and that means that you have to start building units before you get to Iron Age.That means that a cheesy tactics wont work as before and the overall tactics of the game has more depth. The AI is not perfect, though, if you find it's weak spot you can exploit it. I dont know if i should call that tactics or exploit? :D

Playing the campaign with this AI makes the game feel really fresh. Try playing the mission "Crossing the Alps" on hardest. It is what it was suppose to be since 1997. Enemies everywhere, from all sides, crushed by gigantic elephants. Very cool.

I have not tested multiplayer yet. I have joined the lobby just to check it out. I found 6 games about to start in Europe and 1 in USA. It seams that you can start a game in minutes.

What i dont like is the pathfinding, i dont know why but they have altered the "size" of the units in a strange way. For example, a villager occupy more space than on the origina. That will make it get stuck on trees and building. Another annoying thing is the performance, sometimes the frames drop so low that i can barely play. But the most annoying thing are the explosions. The boats and the ballistas shoot some big arrows but when they hit the target they transform into stones instead of a explosions. I think they have mixed some sprites by mistake? It is really annoying to see this glitch, especially when the graphics is so polished, almost perfect.

Overall, the remake is high quality, improves the original game from all the points of view. A lot better than the other "remakes", AOM: Extended Edition and AOE2 - HD. Has some bugs (i got a boat stuck in a building) but it is not as tragic as some other people say. Not at all. Overall i am very pleased with the remake.

Age of Empires: Rise of Rome was the first computer game I ever played, let alone the first strategy game. Playing the Definitive Edition brought back so many fond memories.
The game feels as I remember it, albeit with a few pathfinding issues on the AI's part.
Those whole two hours reminded me why I fell in love with the strategy genre in the first place.

Pros:

It's AoE 1 as you know it, with some _really_ nice QoL improvements, graphical enhancements, and a gorgeous re-recorded soundtrack.

Both the graphical updates and the soundtrack recording maintain the original feeling and character of AoE 1, but bring up the fidelity significantly. Animations are much smoother, textures are higher resolution, the live soundtrack sounds beautiful, but it still distinctly feels like AoE 1. For me, this is up there alongside Grim Fandango with best remastered soundtracks.

Quality of life improvements include idle villager selection, idle military selection, auto-farm reseeding, farms you can walk over, attack move, rally points, unit queuing (over multiple buildings too), jump to event with hotkey, and grid layout for hotkeys.

You can also increase the population cap over 50! Big battles are finally possible.

All of these seem like baseline staples of modern RTS', but they were completely missing from the original game! One of the biggest complements I can give is that most of these QoL improvements go unnoticed, because they feel natural and in line with modern RTS' while not  detracting from the original game. They're just what you'd expect if playing this game for the first time in 2019.

One exception: For veteran players, this means you can no longer use farms as defensive walls (which makes a lot of sense, but) might alter strategies a bit compared to the original game.

Cons:

It's AoE 1 as you know it, with many of the shortcomings that come with an old RTS. Pathing is still broken to the point where it's actually exploitable as a gameplay strategy. It's also still possible to spawn at the start of the game with an unfair food/resources advantage/disadvantage based on RNG map generation. The game is also generally a lot slower and more relaxed than modern RTS', however this isn't necessarily a bad thing.

Multiplayer is generally very stable over LAN, but will occasionally micro-stutter.

I've noticed many other reviews hating on the game for crashing lots. I haven't had a single crash yet, although I don't run AV outside Windows Defender. Perhaps they have patched the game, as of September 2019, the game feels very stable.

Overall:

If you liked AoE 1, you'll probably love this edition of the game. The best thing about Definitive Edition is it makes AoE 1 truly enjoyable again by modern standards. However in saying that, if you've never played AoE 1, you may *still* find this feels outdated. Trust me though... it's infinitely better than the original.

Plays exactly like the original-for better or worse. If you came expecting a more modern Age game in the original setting, you'll be disappointed. If you came for the nostalgia, you'll be happy with the result...mostly. The graphics are excellent, all the assets keep true to the original while looking sharp and more detailed. Small things, like roman Scutum leaning against the wall of the barracks, make all the models pop. Some certain oddities of the original still remain, however, such as the tiered hills. As well, cheat units didn't receive the same facelift as the others, so don't expect an HD version of the Zug 209. The music was also updated to use actual instruments instead of being digital, to mixed result. Some songs sound amazing, but some end up feeling wrong, or more in place in AoE3. Fortunately, when playing a custom game, you can choose to use the classic graphics, which also uses the classic sound effects. The music however, remains in the updated version. Finally, there are no cinematics,and the opening cinematic has been replaced by something incredibly uninspired that just serves as a reminder that Ensemble wasn't involved. Overall though, it was still an enjoyable experience for a veteran player to go back and revisit where it all began. If you're new and haven't experienced the Age series yet, I'd just wait for the Age 2 definitive edition in November

First, thank you Microsoft and Forgotten Empires for reviving this iconic (and my all-time favourite) franchise back to the gaming scene. 

Despite the fancy name, this is for the most part an aesthetic overhaul, albeit one of substantial girth. The Definitive Edition comprises all the original Age of Empires content plus the Rise of Rome expansion, and also features the short Hittite campaign that served as part of the original game's demo. The Definitive edition also includes support for local and online multiplayer, and comes with a new list of achievements for players to unlock.

Meanwhile, the graphical side of the update aims to bring the game up to a 4K standard while maintaining the timeless, picturesque style of the original Genie engine. All the models for buildings and units have been entirely redrawn, while the game takes advantage of modern effects for rendering water, reflections, and shadows.

For the most part, I think the remaster looks splendid. I especially like the new destruction animations for buildings, which now visibly collapse into a smoking heap of rubble, rather than simply replacing the building model with a brownfield sprite. I'm less convinced about the new zoom function. Although having more of the map onscreen and lets you better show off large armies, up close the new textures look smudgy and blurred.

The Definitive Edition isn't purely a visual makeover. New audio has been recorded for the game's music and sound effects. The former is superb, its rousing orchestral swells bringing a fitting depth and grandeur to the game, pairing up nicely with the bolder visuals.

Beyond the changes to visuals and audio, the game is pretty much identical to before. It's business as usual, which also means that some of the first game's shortcomings, such as the rather shoddy AI pathfinding and the heavy focus on what today is extremely rudimentary combat, remain intact. I understand that Forgotten Empires wished to stay as true to the original game as possible, but that also means it remains a flawed game, and those flaws haven't improved over time.

Such pondering assumes there will be new players interested in visiting a 20-year-old, highly orthodox RTS, and this, really, is the sticking point. You see, I love Age of Empires. I probably love it more than Alexander the Great loved his actual Empire. And for a few hours, playing the definitive edition provided me with some lovely, soothing waves of nostalgia. Exploring those early maps, watching my settlements slowly spread and advance, imagining names for my villagers like "Rogan Josh", all of it amounted to a pretty good time. 

I don't care if you buy the game or not, but I know I will, for rest of me life; every time there is a new Age of Empires game, I will buy it. I originally bought the game on MS Store (sure you can laugh), then I bought it here again to show game's developers that die-hard fans of this franchise still exist, and are not going anywhere anytime soon.
