This game is based on one of the best strategy games of all time. This, however, is not one of the best strategy games of all time. Microsoft had 20 years to update this game, and did very little. There are no formations for units, the pathfinding is still horrible, your army disperses all over, and it runs poorly. They gave you the option of a higher population limit than the original, and you can queue up techs and units. This is the only improvement. The graphics aren't as improved as you'd like, as the text is SO SMALL, you can't read anything on screen. The pathfinding has not improved. Your army and your villagers still have no idea on how to reach a destination and panic at the slightest problem. Your army could get strung out reaching a destination, and as soon as the first unit makes the trip, the rest of the selected units stop. 

You're paying $20 for a facelift and tech/unit queue. If you know what everything says already, the text size isn't a big deal. It is not worth the price in my opinion. I'll go back to spending the majority of my time on AoE II HD (2013). I have Xbox Game Pass Ultimate already, so luckily I won't be spending the extra money on AoE 2 DE when it comes out, because I imagine it will be much of the same - a facelift for a great game.
Not the same old age of empires. But I like it.

Good Remaster of a 20 year old classic. Just keep in mind this isn't Age 2. If you played Age 2 a lot, like myself, you will miss some features here, like gates, castles, buying ressources, trade or garrisoning units inside a tc/castle/tower. At least I would have want gates, formations and full market, but I understand that the devs didn't want to change the core game. 

What is good
-the core game is still great, though not as good as Age 2
-A lot of comfort features which weren't in the original
-great graphics
-great sound in general
-only one crash in about 60 hours
-campaigns are now voiced, at least the mission briefing and after you win or loose a scenario

What is neutral
-fps is limited to 60 and if you move around the map with your mouse you loose some fps. The reason I think this isn't that bad is this is a RTS. It's still well playable at lower fps.

What is bad
-no formations
-you can't buy/sell ressources like in Age 2 (Well, I guess you can sell ressources for gold, but in Age 1 this is like trade in Age 2 but really not effective and you need an enemy/friendly dock to do)
-pathfinding is bad
-units bump into each other and get blocked, especially vills
-sometimes a ship spawns from a dock and is stuck inside it. You either have to deleat the dock to free it or deleat the ship
-in normal games you can increase max population quite a lot, BUT in campagins the max is still 50. This sucks, because usually that's just not enough to have a good eco and a good military. Either you have a good eco but then only about 10-20 military or the other way. What I usually did to solve this problem is, first I get a good eco rolling with just a bit military to defend, and after some time if I have stocked up a lot of ressources I deleat vills to get pop space for miltiary. But really, this sucks.
-not beeing able to garrison units is a huge problem, also that your tc doesn't fire arrows. Because these two things mean, you are extremly vulnerable the first 2 ages. If you are beeing attacked by let's say axeman which are quite strong in the early game, you have almost no way to protect your vills, because you can't garrison them in your tc and tc can't fire. You basically have to rely on walls and towers. Another problem connected to this, if you play vs the AI and you are beeing attacked, the enemy units usually ignore your army and go straight into your eco and kill vills. This is so annoying, also in Age 1 there is no loom, so vills die extremly fast. And because there are no gates you have to completly wall of your base and if you want to get in your base with units or leave it you have to deleat some part of the wall, get your units through and then rebuild it. 
-german synchro is bad, at least some of the texts, the voiced lines are good
-the difficulty balance in the campaigns is rather bad. I played all the campaigns on medium difficulty. Some scenarios were pretty easy and some really hard, where I had to restart multiple times because the AI just overwhelmed me
-in my opinion the user interface is too small. Luckily you can increase the size of it in the options menu, but for some reason it gets saved for the current session, but if you restart the game it didn't save it.

So overall I am sounding really negative here and I can understand why some people are rating this game negative, but I still had a lof of fun with it, it's still Age of Empires. I love the series.

I like this game better than Age of Empires Two. Starting with cavemen picking wild berries and hunting game is the "kindling type way" every game should start. Nothing beats the campaigns that immerse you into civilizations that started it all.

I would tentatively recommend this game based on what your expectation for this game is. 

If you want to re-live the childhood memory where you sit besides your dad and watch the cavemen on screen slowly evolve into genocidal maniacs then by all means please grab it.  The game remains largely the same, but modernized slightly with some much needed QoL changes (such as idle vilies button, walkable farms and auto re-seeding), graphical improvement (not a complete overhaul, more like hi-res textures with high fidelity) and minor balance tweaks. The feeling of the game is preserved perfectly and you could instantly recognize almost everything in game if you have played the original. Also, some "authentic" annoyances got carried over (the most glaring problems being unit pathing and weird hit boxes). The soundtrack also got remastered with live orchestra, which is pretty neat.

However, if what you want is a total reboot of AoE 1 with modern game design philosophies then you might want to wait for sale or give it a pass. Peeling away the nostalgia, the game really does feel like it's more than 20 years old. It feels clumsy in terms of design yet sparse when comes to features. After all the underlying engine stays the same as it was 20 years ago. Playing this game makes me appreciate AoE2 (and 3 to some degree) more, seeing how much more enjoyable they actually are compared to AoE1.

So as I said, I tentatively recommend this game because fortunately (or maybe the opposite) I am of the first camp. Soooo...... rogan?

This is a great game, and with some work it is the perfect Age of Empires 1 reboot.

The voice acting is just marvelous, both campaign narrations and unit grunts. Normally I wouldn't mention that, but it is too smooth and professional to be overlooked.

The music is also really well done. I had heard that it was an excellent remake of the original, primitive midi soundtrack...and that turned out to be right. The soundtrack is very fitting and stays enjoyable throughout the game.

There is a few stutter issues though. When you first start a new game, the game stutters before it starts playing smooth again. There is random FPS drops across the game. The priest sprite is also stuttering in some positions (like moving straight upwards).

Now it does need some effort in terms of pathfinding as well, but I can't complain because pathfinding in the original 20 year old game was horrible and this one is much better and playable at least.

They also need to remake the original intro and other cutscenes in my opinion. The game doesn't feel same without their old charm.

The only major downer for me is the lack of an Indian civlization. Despite being the richest ever imperial civilization in human history until industrial era (and extremely powerful in AoE1 era, at one point the largest in the form of Mauryan Empire), the original MS devs left out India for some reason. So did the Definitive Edition sadly. I would love to see an India civ in the game, either a unified one like in AoE2 or broken into two distinctive cultures - Arya and Dravida.

[h1]The real wololo is back[/h1]

I‚Äôll start my review saying that this game doesn‚Äôt deserve all the negativity is getting. People love the [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-IgAVQdHJQ4]wololo meme,[/url] and also love to bash the first Age of Empires. The biggest characteristic of the Age of Empires series is that every game is unique in its own way. If you‚Äôre expecting a similar game as AoE 2 you‚Äôll be disappointed, but if you keep an open mind, you‚Äôll find a lot of enjoyment. Now to the actual review:

[h1]Remastering the game that started it all[/h1]

Despite the great reworked graphics, this game is more of a remaster than a remake. This means that it‚Äôs very faithful to the original game, including its oldschool clunkyness. But still, the Forgotten Empires developers have added some great quality of life features, like farm reseeding, tech queues, indicator of how many idle villagers you have, walkable farms, higher population cap and other minor additions. It‚Äôs also worth mentioning that the AI has greatly improved compared to the original and compared to the Microsoft Store launch last year. These AI improvements, made primarily to add more spice to skmirmish matches, have a side-effect of making some campaign levels unfairly hard. The game also features a reworked soundtrack, recorded with an orchestra. Personally, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1846861089]I don‚Äôt like it too much[/url], as the composer in charge have changed several melodies here and there, killing the nostalgic mood ‚Äì imagine if someone re-recorded the classic [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-bTpp8PQSog]Indiana Jones[/url] theme, starting fine and changing some notes in the way: that‚Äôs how it feels to me. 

[h1]What if I don‚Äôt want all this fanciness?[/h1]

Then you can enable the [url=https://youtu.be/I_1S5OqAo4w?t=214]Classic Mode[/url] in custom games, which uses the original graphics, soundtrack and gameplay. This mode is very poorly implemented, though, for several reasons: 1) You can‚Äôt use it on the campaigns; 2) You can‚Äôt use it on multiplayer; 3) It starts with the vanilla soundtrack rather than the Rise of Rome soundtrack like it used to in the original with the expansion; 4) The interface is the same as the Definitive Edition, so it‚Äôs not totally nostalgic; 5) You can‚Äôt choose between the MIDI and the recorded soundtrack from the Gold Edition. I‚Äôm hoping these issues can be solved in a near future. And it would be good if we could choose to use the original sound effects outside Classic Mode, as some re-recorded sounds are truly awful. Yeah, they have changed the classic ‚Äú[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JYdbcIQ-pQ4]Rogan?[/url]‚Äù sound to another ‚ÄúRogan?‚Äù that sounds like it came from a drunk and high pitched voice actor. Unbelievable.
 
[h1]What sets AoE 1 apart compared with AoE 2[/h1]

If you never have played the first Age of Empires, you should know that a lot of strategies from Age of Empires II don‚Äôt work here. For starters, there‚Äôs no gate ‚Äì I actually love this, because no one is ever safe, and you need to be creative with your walls placement, sometimes even creating some mazes that mashes with the environment. There‚Äôs also no land trading and no way to buy and sell resources on the market, so you need to plan a good strategy ahead as soon as you uncover the map. No army formations as well ‚Äì it‚Äôs all brute and raw. There‚Äôs no scout at the start, so if you want to explore the map without hurting your progress (avoiding using your villagers to explore) you should advance to the second age (Tool Age) and train a scout ‚Äì you could also use a Clubman, trained at the Barracks, but they‚Äôre too slow and don‚Äôt uncover a lot of the map. And the pathfinding is a lot simpler/poor (even if it‚Äôs slightly better in the Definitive Edition) compared to Age of Empires II, which to me it‚Äôs not a huge problem, as micromanaging units it‚Äôs one of the pillars of the RTS genre. Everything stated in this paragraph is what makes Age of Empires 1 my favorite in the series ‚Äì it‚Äôs much less automated and comfortable than its successors, providing a more strategic experience.
 
[h1]It‚Äôs worth the full price?[/h1]

As much as I love the first Age of Empires, I‚Äôm not sure if I could recommend it at full price to everyone, as it‚Äôs a whole different beast compared to Age of Empires II and other more modern RTS games. However, if you have enjoyed the original and/or you are used to older games, go ahead and pick it up right now; if not, wait for a sale. As for the Definitive Edition features: they‚Äôre a hit or miss sometimes. It‚Äôs certainly not definitive as it should be, but I‚Äôm glad that we at least have it, considering that the first Age of Empires is a very underrated game, shadowed by Age of Empires II, Age of Mythology and even by Age of Empires III. 

[b]Pros[/b]:

[b]*[/b] Faithful remaster of the original game
[b]*[/b] Great quality of life upgrades
[b]*[/b] The reworked graphics are awesome
[b]*[/b] The AI is greatly improved (and harder) compared to the original game
[b]*[/b] Cross-platform multiplayer between Steam and Microsoft Store
[b]*[/b] You can easily change/modify the game‚Äôs files
[b]*[/b] Accessibility options
[b]*[/b] Steam Cloud support

[b]Mixed[/b] (may or may not bother you):
 
[b]*[/b] The reworked soundtrack is a hit or miss
[b]*[/b] Very grindy achievements‚Ä¶
[b]*[/b] ‚Ä¶which can be obtained in custom scenarios and with ingame cheats. Yeah, I said it

[b]Cons[/b]
[b]*[/b] New sound effects makes no sense: some are re-recorded (and awful) and some are not
[b]*[/b] Stuttering on late game, and in some cases even before that. Unchecking some graphical improvements alleviates the problem a bit, but this shouldn‚Äôt happen
[b]*[/b] If you zoom out too much, the game locks your FPS to 30 for some reason
[b]*[/b] Classic Mode could be better implemented

System:
i7 7700K, GTX 1080

Memories.
9/10

This game is what it is, a rehashing of a classic albeit entirely outshined game from the inception of the RTS genre, with some quality of life improvements. And this is great, an opportunity for die-hard fans to play a classic game on modern hardware, in a modern way.

What's not so great is the execution. I have a GTX 1070,  i7 7500U setup. Although it's very CPU bottlenecked, you'd think it wouldn't have so much trouble running a game that is effectively from 1995. Although I can run most modern games I play at 144fps (save for EUIV), this one seems to get 39 at most, which is abysmally poor. The graphics settings don't help much with this either, as the only setting that makes any discernible difference is the 1x, 2x, 4x scaling drop down menu, 4x putting me down to 10fps, which seems to affect which sprites are used and how zoomed-in the game is, rather than anything that might affect the actual CPU usage.

Save for the main menu, every other screen looks straight out of 1995, or a D tier no-name you can only get by buying a random steam key on G2A, it's that bad. Multiplayer is a chore as well, trying to navigate the menus to find a lobby, having to deal with the fact that ranks have been broken since launch a year ago, and therefore ranked matching, and finding a game in general as I've only ever been able to find 2-3 other people online despite a much higher playerbase.

From a game standpoint, this title doesn't hold up either, especially against greater titles such as AoE II and AoE III (yes I know), both of which run very well, have proper looking menus for a game of this magnitude, a consistent online playerbase, and most importantly: civilizations. No doubt, the lifeblood of every RTS game are the minute advantages or disadvantages each civilization may have over another. An RTS game where every civilization is the same would grow old very fast, which is exactly what Age of Empires: DE is. The original, being an early RTS game, included a number of civilizations, none of which had their own advantages (e.g. speical units, special buildings, etc.) but instead found their de facto differences owning entirely to which units from the great pool they didn't have access to. Which is to say, the difference between the Chinese and the Greeks is that the Chinese don't have access to the Phalanx upgrade tree. In the original, there were also bonuses that exacerbated the differences between factions through gameplay changes, such as the Hittites having a 100% health bonus on their catapults, but even these were changed in DE (lowered to 50%), making the difference in gameplay that much less between civilizations. This explains why. unlike Age of Empires II: DE, AoE: DE didn't see the addition of any new civs, because there's no way to differentiate them from the already existing civs without adding new units for them not to have access to.

Although I enjoy this game for what it is, it's really only to tide me over to the release of Age of Empires II: DE, and I can't recommend it to anyone looking to get into an RTS that isn't explicitly Age of Empires I, because this is the best (and only) version of the first game you can run on modern operating systems.

Haven't experienced any bugs or performance issues on my end and the Windows 10 thing doesn't affect me right now but I agree on the points other reviews made about this.

However, the game itself is almost exactly what it should be for a remake of sorts.

As someone who have been playing this game since it's original release in 97, this version does a good job at keeping what was fun about it fresher and less clunky. 

Some thoughts, considering I played a few single player missions from different campaigns and some custom maps, but haven't touched multiplayer yet. 

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Graphics feel very nice in comparison to the original. Architecture is spot on and units remain distinct from one another in a glance. A striking contrast between what has been going on with Warcraft 3 remastered thing. Optional faction-unique unit differences would be great as well.
    [*]Unit queues with research from buildings, minimap options, rally points comprehensible Tech-tree, all QOL things that only make the game up to standards set by games released afterward, specially Age of Empires 2. I would love if they had added action queues (shift-clicking) as well, but nothing is perfect. 
    [*]New campaign based on the old Demo version of the original game, about the Hittites. It's not the same missions but made a lot more interesting.
    [*]Works with resolutions without needing a fix, runs well (turned off bloom) unless there are 200+units on screen at once.
    [*]New music is great at times, inferior at others. Some tracks had their melodies altered in ways that feel just wrong. You can make the vanilla OST play first instead of the Rome Expac one by swapping the filenames in the game's folder (music into xmusic / xmusic into music) so it changes the order in game.
    [*]They thankfully haven't added gates! This and the game's lack of a Castle equivalent makes it so you aren't absolutely required to build siege units. I really like this aspect of AoE1 and they respected it in DE.
[/list]

Cons

[list]
    [*]Voice actor narrates missions, but they didn't add different narrators for different campaigns like Age of Empires 2, which makes it feel cheap and adds 0 character to campaigns. I'd rather have no one at all.
    [*]While pathfinding is better than the original, Villagers still get stuck on one another in busy locations. This is specially annoying when there's stone, gold, wood and wild animals gathering on a single Storage Pit.
    [*]Stil no colorblind civ color mode so you can play as Red even in the campaigns.
[/list]

Overall 8.7/10, better than what I expected in some parts, but worse than what it could've been in others.

Nostalgia is a seductive liar.

I was tempted in by memories of childhood weekends spent on my old Windows 98 creating custom scenarios where I had a massively unfair advantage against the enemy or playing through the campaign and being fascinated by the greek and egyption civilisations.

But strategy games have come a long way since 1997. I expect to be able to move with the WASD keys or to be able to rebind to it easily without having to hunt through an unbind hundreds of other random context binds. I expect to be able to alter graphical settings without a crash every time. Add to this seeing the game actively cheating by spawning units in on the map on the second to low difficulty setting because the develop hasn't done a good job of programming the AI and thats a firm no from me.

Nostalgia brought me back but this game crushed those wide eyed dreams and memories fairly abruptly. Its a solid no from me.

CONS

Frame rate just suddenly goes down with not even a 100 units. 
Never happened with the original or any of its successors at their time with even the max units +2000. 
No real graphic options.  4K should be a free a DLC, most people don't even have a display or hardware for that or want a little bit more of space just as R6 does. 
There's also missing content, not even a single cutscene from  the original. There's also no glossary or encyclopedia that made the game so special as a history game, not even aside from the main build (the original had it apart). 
Units are overly sized (same as the original), they couldn't fix that, and the pathfinding is as bad as the initial release from 96 which improved with patches and the expansion. 
How does this game has the same minimum requirements as AOE II : DE?
Optional: No Mod support.
AOE: DE Theme at least should have a loop option at the main screen.

NEUTRAL

UI could get improve.

PROS

Music is just AMAZING.
Structures got really nice textures.
Slightly better gameplay for today standards.
Cool and original Cinematic Intro

Age of Empires: Definitive Edition is a faithful remake of the original that launched back in October of 1997. This is both a good thing and a bad thing. I‚Äôm a bit biased towards it as it was one of the first computer games I played in my youth, but will try to be as objective as possible. While I have an original disc of the Gold Edition, its ‚Äúease of installation‚Äù on modern OS‚Äôs and hardware was questionable, so I decided to buy this day-one, simply for the nostalgia factor.

In brief, it is a good game and definitely worth playing if you‚Äôre a long-time fan of the series or strategy games in general. However, if you‚Äôre picking this up for the first time, be advised: it plays ‚Äúold-school‚Äù and may feel clunky if you‚Äôre accustomed to newer titles such as Dawn of War or StarCraft 2.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
What this game gets right is the complete 3D graphics overhaul; that is fantastic! Overall, it is a beautiful and faithful recreation of the original maps. It also adds some small quality of life improvements such as unit queues, navigation way points and villagers per resource. There is also an integrated tech-tree button if you want to know a specific path to unlock a certain technology. Xbox Live has integration for multiplayer and then there‚Äôs LAN as well! Yes LAN! In this era of online-only forced on DRM based services, we get LAN!

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
It is a recreation of a 22 year-old game and stays largely faithful to that. There are no revolutionary new mechanics or special features to speak about. 

The most painfully obvious flaw becomes clear after the first few minutes in-game: pathfinding! Pathfinding is atrocious and I‚Äôm not really sure why it is this terrible as the developers would have to create it anew for this game. There are constant unit collisions where two units will just freeze in place and need manual redirection. Grouped units will often wander off in some split direction as well. I‚Äôm hoping this can be improved with patching, but considering it was already released a year prior on the MS Store, I‚Äôm a little doubtful.

There is also the clunky putting down buildings without the possibility of queuing your villager‚Äôs build or post-build tasks. Units still cannot move in formation (that‚Äôs apparently exclusive to AoE II and III ? I‚Äôm guessing). The unit stand-ground command exists, but is not toggle-able as far as I can tell and not really sure what it does behind the scenes, but units obey when clicked.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
This is a game that stays true to the original and if you don‚Äôt expect anything more, you will probably enjoy it. It is rough around the edges in a few areas, I‚Äôll fully admit that, and perhaps I‚Äôm looking upon it with nostalgia, but I still enjoy playing it every now and then to simulate clashes of ancient civilizations.

Not as good as AOE II, but AOE I with a facelift in graphics and a few quality of life features added (Farm AutoReseeding and some others), while there are complaints about the AI and pathfinding, these are more of legacy problems, because the AI is better than the 1997 version, and the pathfinding is the same (I guess I agree that this can be a pain in the ass with larger armies).

Unless you're super desperate for AOE II DE/loved AOE I back in the day, I would wait for a sale before getting this, because while the game is still fun, I didn't play it as much as AOE II back in the day to love it beyond an appetizer for AOE II DE.

First of all, thank you Microsoft for releasing this on Steam.

This game is very special to me as Age of Empires was my first RTS game (yes it's not StarCraft). It made me like the RTS genre and became very interested in history.

Now to non-biased review, here are my pros and cons of this game (I just finished the learning campaign):

[b]Pros:[/b]
~Graphics were improved compared to the old.
~Remastered soundtracks.
~Narrated campaigns (the old one was purely text)
~Multiplayer support (never tried this one yet because I'm more on campaign guy)
~Modern resolutions support.

[b]Cons:[/b]
~[i]Lost connection to multiplayer servers[/i] always pops up every now and then even if I'm only playing single player and wanted to play offline in the first place. (which is kinda annoying)
~[b]RANDOM CTDs[/b] Be sure to save everytime if you're playing Campaign.
~FPS drops when zoomed out and scrolling the map.
~Path finding sucks
~AI is unusually aggresive (in the first mission of Babylonian Campaign)

This game is quite awesome. I grew up playing it so when it was announced that it'd be coming to Steam updated for the newer OS and with refined graphics I was quite excited.

Having got my hands on it I have to say that it is indeed great fun to play the game again after all these years and all the nostalgia is coming back hard.

The little quality of life improvements are quite pleasant and overall I've had a wonderful experience retreading familiar ground and imagine I will continue to have such going forwards.

Now with that said I would not recommend this game for anyone who did not grow up playing it and is instead looking for something new and interesting. This is not such a game.

The pathfinding is awful and all the little quality of life improvements are not worth the fact that you're buying a game that is two decades old whose core mechanics have not been refined to match its sequel (Age of Empires II) which is ultimately a superior game and is about to get a new re-release of its own.

If you're buying this for nostalgia's sake like myself then go ahead and get this game. It is glorious fun to have it available again. If you're new to it then understand that this is a game of its era with all that entails. Don't expect complex gameplay or intelligent units.

Personally if I was going to buy a remade AOE game for the first time I would wait until the new version of Age of Empires II comes out and leave this game alone.

It has little value beyond nostalgia but the team behind it have done a great job in bringing it up to the newer standard.

Here's how my day went:
Morning i saw that AOE DE is coming to steam. SOOON it said. Put it on wishlist.
Afternoon i get an e-mail, saying AOE DE is available!
Naive me YEETS money into screen.
Starts game, launches first campaign.
"Something is interfering with the game, no do boos."
All afternoon goes by, i try to find the cause of the issue. No luck. I check reviews... many have same issue.
So here i am, hyped for this game since it was announced, didn't know 'till today it was coming to steam, and hell if i was to get it on microsoft store. And now... i have broken hopes and dreams.
It's a negative from me untill this issue is fixed.

I absolutely can not confirm things said by some people about AoE DE. Since the first ever start the game worked for me without a single crash. No weird error messages and no massive stutters as some people describe. 
The FPS for me (playing in 1080p, 144hz) are most of the time at steady 144fps, but can go down beneath 100 if there is a lot going on ingame (fights, buildings collapse, etc. at same time).

People arguing that they have beast graphics cards and a game like this should run way better, simply don't understand a thing about hardware and game engines. This game relies the most on the 2D acceleration of your graphics card, which only improved a tiny bit since the original AoE was released, because the manufacturers only improved 3D acceleration which doesn't help here. So in fact your CPU has to help out a lot.

The next point i would like to talk about is people complaining about the path finding. If you played Age of Empires the time it released (as I did for example) you totally recognize the behaviour of the units. This Definitive Edition feels like the original game while playing it, just with a much better look. Not only better but fitting for modern PC's in terms of resolution and datail. So if you expected the developer to change core game mechanics for this remastered/remade Version you fooled yourself. The devs were fully transparent with what you will get if you buy the game. 

It simply wouldn't be Age of Empires if they changed things like that. If you liked the original AoE then you will like this one too. If you don't like the style of it just don't buy it. You want a modern, probably better looking RTS game, with probably way better AI, pathfinding, etc.? Then simply wait a couple more months until Age of Empires IV gets introduced in detail.

Only thing i can confirm is the fact that buttons sometimes overlap with text, or text overlaps with frames onscreen.
This needs to be fixed asap and shouldn't be much of a thing as it is a simple matter of scaling improvement.

Why the hell do I have to KEEP DISABLING THAT GOD DAMNED NARRATOR every time I start this game!?

sure, everyone knows the feeling, when he can replay game from his childhood, that nostalgia of it. But in case of AoE you need to forget about it for the second, and try to keep your mind open to the facts. 

I must say some parts are better than they were in original, thats for sure. Graphic, sound and new models are really nice. But even though I really tried to get into it, I could not. Because main parts of the game are kind of problematic. I get it, they tried to keep core of the game untouched, but I dont think, that was good idea. They should at least make some changes in control, UI, AI, because it feels like nobody actually tried to play it, before they decided to send game out. 


Minor issue: 
Objectives, for example destroy all enemy farms... I destroyed AI¬¥s town center and all core buildings near it, but even than I had to look everywhere, wasting my time. Why? When AI is pretty much done, they could at least mark objects on the map. Or even better, let game end without finishing this non-sense objective.

Major issues:

AI:
AI felt silly, same as it was 15yrs ago. One would thought, they make it better, but I guess, I was wrong.
AI keeps sending small armies to your town center, even thought, its obvious it wont do any harm, because you have fortification in place...
During the game I actually remembered old days, to be more specific IWD, when you could lure enemies to the next room and kill them one by one. You can pretty much do the same here, kill whole AI¬¥s army by luring them one by one out side of range of AI¬¥s fortifications or even better under your towers. (perhpas the highest difficulty can fix this, but to be honest I didnt try it, because AI wasnt main issue for me)

Path-fiding:
The worst I have seen in years. One of the most annoying parts. Units can get stuck just by walking next to each other, no to mention, when you need them to move through the middle of your/AI¬¥s town, to keep it short, dont even try it, it ll be end of you. (I played only with 50 unit cap, and I already had hard time to control my units as I wanted them to)

Lack of formations:
maybe I missed it, but I had to manually create formations, I wanted to use, becuase AI has tendencies to keep original formations. Meaning, if you have units all over the place, it just keep it that way, is like you would copy&paste positions of selected units and redo it in new position, centered around your cursor. So before the combat, I created formations for every group, manually placing every unit where I wanted them to be, and then I send them to the attack. After "battle", I had to do it all over again, especially meeles.


Combat:
All those 3 things leads to the one thing, combat is one big mess. Even with 30 combat units it was annoying like hell, so I dont want to see game, when you control 200vs200 units...
Technical issues,awful performance.

[b]A criminally underrated game. Age of Empires II blew its predecessor out of the water so high, it still hasn't come down over 20 years later. With that said, this deserves its time in the sun, it's a fantastic remaster!

The Forgotten Empires Dev team have had a rocky time of it in the last few years, with some of their releases being hailed really well, and some not so much (Age of Mythology HD, common guys). This one seems to be one of the good ones, aside from some catastrophic bugs that are having peoples' games crash. 

Game wise, it's still the game you remember, or not if you're not over 25. Plays like Age of Empires 2 with 3D models. While they are much higher ress than its sequels 2D spites, there is a simplicity and beauty that AoE simply doesn't have. Campaign wise, the game explores the Ancient classical periods, with its campaign exploring ancient Greece and various other periods in history. A good bunch! in fact, I think i prefer them to AoE II, in setting at least

New civilizations, like the Celts, Mauryans, Israelites or Scythians, along with new terrain types and animals; would have been greatly appreciated, and I do hope that Microsoft and Forgotten Empires may take a look back at AoE:DE, and decide to add just a bit more content.

This game is heaven for nostalgists.
However, it lacks the long-time play motivation of its successor.
Although the graphics and sounds have been updated beatifully, it really needs a few additions to be really enjoyable in 2019:

1) The civilizations need to be more distinguishable. At least one unique unit like in AoE 2 would be neat.
2) 20 years later, it finally needs new civs. It would suffice if they introduced a DLC with "barbaric" factions: Germans, Gauls, and Sarmatians for example.
3) The pathfinding still needs to be fixed. How come every single unit hast to calculate its way itself and it's not possible to move a couple of units as one (like in AoE2)?
4) The game is too easy. The AI is no challenge for experienced AoE players.

With AoE2 DE dawning however, I doubt that AoE will get any support in the not-too-distant future. I appreciate the effort to get the game to Steam, though. Thanks for that!

I haven't played Age of Empires I since the Pocket PC Edition many, many years ago.  I did play Age of Empires III and The Warchiefs expansion.  So I approached this with memories of enjoying the classical civilizations, agriculture, fishing and ballistas.

Having read the reviews on here and on metacritic (although these were mainly from launch) I had some doubts but in the end this is a lot of content for not a lot of money and I missed that classical world.

The steam launch reviews talked of bugs.  At the time of writing I've played for just over 4 hours and these are my initial findings.  My steamapps folder is excluded from my antivirus programme (Bitdefender) and I also allowed access through Windows firewall (it asked twice and each time I took care to ensure that access was enabled on my private network).  I believe this has been responsible for me having no issues with the anti-cheating self monitoring mechanism in the game.

What bugs did I find?  Well one,  the poor text formatting at the summary after being "Victorious" on a quest .  Not a big deal and something that I expect a patch will fix soon enough.

Gameplay is pleasant, the music is relaxing and the game is stable.  Pathfinding seams better than the original but at this stage I haven't ran into any difficulties.  I suspect older players will be more relaxed with this having memories of the original game and it's quirky eccentricities.

The graphics are improved and although it's a personal preference I think the smoother animations are good and it's visually enjoyable.

The sound adds to the experience and is like returning to a familiar place.

I am enjoying being back and it's more than nostalgia.  So far this gentle start is just what I was looking for, a game I can relax and build a civilisation.

I bought it together with Age of Empires II DE and think one would struggle to find so much content for so little.  A little care with the firewall and antivirus at install went a long way for me and I think the game deserves a much warmer reception than it has had.  I am a very happy customer.

PS- edited as I was tired when I played last night and I think I may have mixed up the two storage types so the "second bug" was user error.

For me the Age of empires series are the best rts games ever made. The classic age1 is my favorite. After the day 2 update all of the launch problems seem to be gone. A little annoyed that I finally was forced to upgrade to windows 10 just for this but I probably needed to eventually anyway, and apparently its still possible to do for free so it was also a lot less painless than I was expecting. Anyway the game itself is basically the original but with modern graphics and quality of life improvements, so overall as someone who has a lot of nostalgia for the original I would say this is an instant buy. It even has a setting to play with the original game rules and graphics if you want the pure experience, in skirmish at least, haven't seen a way to activate it in campaign, but anyway there's that if you want an easy way to play it on modern systems, this really offers anything you could want from age of empires 1 and I am looking forward to the definitive edition of aoe2.
Being able to get AOE1 on Steam is a godsend. The game is in desperate need of bugfixes but the pieces are all there. The ability to switch to the original graphics is very much appreciated.

It plays pretty well, much of the same feel as in the original Age. Graphics, art style, sound fx, and music are vastly improved upon. No FPS drops, smooth animations, crisp detail, and plenty of options to tweak your gameplay experience. Very happy with this purchase.


Also just to add, that I'm on a Ryzen 1600 and a Radeon VII. So your results may vary.

If you have nostalgia goggles for Age of Empires, you'll get some enjoyment out of this regardless of its flaws. I debated getting a refund, but ultimately decided I'd enjoy revisiting the scenarios from my childhood again despite the flaws.

First off, game looks pretty. Animations are lovely, everything looks vibrant. I really like the UI too. The score has been redone and is nice enough.

Performance can be choppy. Frame rate stutters sometimes for reasons I've yet to make heads of. It's not too bad, but it's noticeable to the eye.

Pathfinding is TERRIBLE. I don't want to sound like I'm exaggerating, but every game has been bogged down by it at least once. Moving single units isn't too bad. Moving a group - sometimes they'll walk past where I tell them to go and keep going. In at least one occasion an axeman couldn't get to a tower to reach from one side of a forest so walked around the entire forest to reach the other side. When he got there.... he walked back round to where he originally was despite the fact that he had an opening. All the while being shot at. People walk into one another and stutter and struggle to sidestep (I actually remember this being a pain in the original, which makes it more baffling how it's there after 20+ years). Sometimes these are minor, but others can make the game a chore.

If you've only ever played AoE2 and are thinking of checking this out, I will say this feels slower gameplay wise, just like the original.

Some really nice additions (at least I think they are... been a while since I played the original). You can queue up different unit and tech orders in the same building. Some touches from AoE2:HD come over like auto-renewing farms, but not as many as I expected.

Some of the menus don't render correct for me. The victory screen after a match has buttons showing over the victory text.

I'll remain open to amending my review with further updates, I think with a few clean ups this could easily change to a recommended, but I'm a bit grumpy that these weren't ironed out sooner (hasn't it been on Windows Store for a year already? How weren't they caught then?). It does feel a little like I've paid for a beta. Your mileage may vary, but I'd still rather just keep playing AoE2:HD.
Well they didn't improve pathfinding much but graphics are gourgeous and UI is better.

Simple RTS game, love it. I used to play the previous version but it lacked graphics. Its not like dota or warcraft, where u can use magical powers whatsover, its simple like u need to mine gold stone from mines, chop trees for wood, farm for food etc. Build ur infantry and canons and crush the enemy with it. Over 5 hours into the Egypt campaign with zero technical issues, nothing like what I have read in other reviews. AI does seem a bit stupid, villagers will run into each other and get stuck. When moving units en masse some will randomly take the dumbest route possible, wandering right into danger, instead of the most direct path. 

Graphics are a great improvement, and you can even zoom a little bit. 

Wish they would have added a few features from AOE2 like being able to put units into formations, as they wont stand anywhere close together, which makes planning a battle a bit clunky, since you have to move each unit into place individually. 

Definitely worth the $20!

Start off from humble beginnings with three villagers, a town centre... Listen as a calm and beautiful soundtrack plays gently now and again between moments of silence with nothing but the chopping of wood, chipping of stones and cuttings of fresh gazelle as you watch clouds roll over the terrain your growing tribe is labouring upon. 

You lead them through the Stone Age into the Tool Age as your small economy grows and new technology paves the way to establish a small village. You explore the surrounding areas textured in HD graphics and detailed UI descriptions. Things only get more interesting as you manage your people through into new ages. A Bronze Age and finally an Iron Age.

You are not alone however as you expand you discover other ancient civilisations, opposing rivals or allies in your lands. Command your armies in conquest, or capture and hold artefacts and ancient relics, or build an economy of which you construct and defend a colossal wonder as a testament to your rule. Achieve victory as you see fit. The AI is much better organised then the original.

This game is a faithful remastering of the original Age of Empires from 1997. I remember the day my father pulled out this CD from the inside of a Kellog's Rice Bubbles cereal box in the early 2000s. I played this game almost everyday, the first thing I did getting home from school was booting up a game of AOE on my cream coloured box computer screen. A classic real time strategy game is now remastered... For a game which originally had sold over millions of hard copies. For Microsoft to come back and remaster this series... it's so unexpected. I am very grateful for this. I thought I'd never see the day.

I will be spending quite a bit of time on here. I'm glade you (microsoft) have finally brought it to Steam. It should have been here in the first place and I think you guys know that too. There are only have a few touches left of polish and this game will be a gem. As of this time there is flickering and overlapping UI in the Campaign mission aftermaths (love the voiced briefings tho). And the Computer AI has no diplomacy working during gameplay which would be amazing if you Microsoft can implement it or at least keep it as a random chance like it was in the original. Another gripe, however small, is upon zooming in on units and textures close up there is blurring. Path finding is much improved over the original as well, it can still happen but to me that has always been apart of the experience micro those men right and you will have no problem. Avoid tight spaces... fight in open ground unless you have missile superiority (cause then its a shooting gallery). Plan your city so you have easy routes for troops to move through.

To everyone out there this game is a must buy! To the old fans and to anyone young or new, this game will be great fun and well worth the price of around $20. This game has heaps of replayability and always has a active multiplayer community of truly hardcore fans. Join me as we build massive empires from humble beginnings.
it's year of 9012 and they still use 90s pathfinding.

Age of Empires was one of my first PC games and I loved it. However, I can't recommend this remaster in its current state.
The game looks beautiful and has some quality of life improvements over the original that make it less of a pain to play, but at the same time does some things even worse than the original:
The pathfinding is monstrously bad, villagers bump into each other and stay there for a solid 10 seconds before finally figuring out what to do, stand idle if there's too many of them in the same resource (even though there's clearly enough room for one more) and military units get stuck on the terrain more often than I'd like.
The AI is somehow worse than in the original, which is surprising for a 20+ year old game, not sure how they managed it. In Random Map, even in moderate difficulty it doesn't attack or make military units except for a few catapults. And in the campaign I've had it resign before I could complete the objectives, which is like the whole point of the campaign...

If they improve these things I feel it could be a solid game.

As much as I loved this game as a kid, this Definitive Edition just doesn't work for me. It will be a pretty fun experience, and with friends it's even better. Besides a few minor bugs here and there and some text overlapping after you complete a mission, It's not a bad remaster don't get me wrong, but It just went bad in a few places.
instantly crashes as soon as you start a campaign mission. AOE2 worked so well so how exactly did they mess up this badly?

I love Age of Empires. But straight up, this is not a "definitive edition" of AoE, and it isn't even close to being that. Be aware that the AI is worse than the original game, that there are bugs, that you can't play the campaigns using the original graphics and music, that the new graphics are gaudy, that you can't add AI teams to certain types of MP games including when using a random map, that the game menus are poorly done, and that there's no support for Windows 7 and 8 (though some people are trying to figure out how to get it working).

If you loved the original game and want to experience it again, get a copy of the original game and search for and install the "UPatch HD", which will give AoE modern resolution support, add the CD music, and give other fixes to make it comfortable on a modern OS.

If you want to read more details about some of the problems with AoE DE, read this forum post:

https://steamcommunity.com/app/1017900/discussions/0/2763442118820863113/

Introduction :

For having bought the game on the Windows 10 Store at the time I played it a lot and it's really a good game and I think that if the pathfinding was a little less farting because we already had this kind of problems on the 1998 version there are still problems and it's absurd for a game that supposedly has been redone.

However, why do I put "NO" to my recommendation in my first Review ? 

Simply because this game is a paranoid game indeed in order to prevent cheating the game cuts itself off if it detects processes that affect the game, problems : 
Every 5 minutes the game crashes because it conflicts with a lot of software: overlay Steam, antivirus, DirectX (I'm not kidding).
So the game is unplayable as it stands until they fix this "bug" because the game cuts your game and returns you to the menu with the options in grayed so apart from leaving the game you can't click on anything.

How to fix the "Conflict bug" :

Extremely disappointed to get f*cked up when they had a little over a year to fix these problems already and beyond if the developers had launched their game they would have noticed it after 5 minutes.
To fix the bug, Add the folder steamapps/common/AOEDE to your Antivirus exception, this problem show the "don't care" attitude of the development team.


Conclusion :

So in conclusion in the state it's playable but prepare to fix the "bug" yourself  (I do not exaggerate) so wait for the updates if you are interested if Age of Empire II: Definitive Edition meets the same problems it is scary for the future.
But Age of Empire will stay the game of my childhood and even it's a great game I just really hope that Microsoft really care more about the game than that they showing us now

I cannot in good conscience give this game a thumbs up 

Yes, it's a nostalgia trip; especially for me because I haven't played the first game, but i did play the second and third and Age Of Mythology. However, the amount of stonewalling I am getting because this game doesn't like the security protocols and programs, and whatever the heck is insane. Did Microsoft even beta test this on Steam!?! 

DO NOT. I repeat. DO NOT buy this game until the developers fix this glaring issue. And don't give me, the "um well I am playing it" fine your playing it but what about the rest of us who is still having this problem despite the "fix" suggestions the devs are offering through the support link. 

Now if you get pass that issue what about the rest of the game? Well it's a different AOE experience you can really feel it playing for the first time. And for the love of god turn up the game speed because you'll be doing these scenarios, matches, etc. For a long time. 

You can't just hope for the best in the beginning mind you like in AOE II and III, etc. Because here A.I. will mash out a ton and i mean a TON of units and settlers early on, which can be downright annoying at times. Obviously certain empires can't get certain things, and of course you have your standard multiplayer match types against either players or A.I. you can even once again customize and upload your own maps, etc. 

I would love to give this game a thumbs up. However the annoyance of having to troubleshoot a game FIRST rather than PLAYING it second turns me off a bit. But once you get pass that little annoyance be prepared for a different AOE experience.
Besides the game not being optimized, its pretty okay

$20 for a very updated Aoe game? YES please! 

PROS:   

1. Some QOL updates that AOE didn't have were implemented in. I could go into detail but I just got back to my PC and wanted to throw a positive review up before hopping back on!

2. Updated graphics, I was very excited seeing everything brought to life in so much more detail. Seriously the buildings crumbling down look so good and immersive, well done!

3. The music really captures the feels and my sweet sweet nostalgia

4. It feels like a brand new game to be honest. I can't wait to dive in more. A good buy for RTS lovers and AOE1/2/3 fans!

5. No crashing or any major problems for me so far, I will update this if any are found.

CONS: 

1. Minor UI problems, like overlapping UI here and there that's visually annoying but not at all game breaking

2. I would have liked to have seen the 3 separate zoom options put all in 1

3. I'd like to have a hotkey for selecting my town center ect, perhaps that's just a simple trip to the hotkey options but it be really odd not to have one already set up if it does exist. Maybe someone can drop a comment.

4. There doesn't seem to be a ton of Random Map options, would love to see more added on, but it's definitely enough for now.

5. The biggest gripe I have though is there doesn't seem to be any workshop implemented, that simply MUST change for this game to live up to the potential it deserves. Seriously Microsoft Studios, if you could only do one thing, it should be this 100%

6. Microsoft Studios didn't really announce the release, I would have liked to make plans around this so I could have been playing a lot more by now.

7. No formations would be my second biggest gripe, this was a huge QOL and immersive improvement that wasn't addressed. Hopefully we will see it implemented.

Overall Grade: 7/10 

A solid release! It just lacks the polish I felt the original games had, but very much captures the same excitement. REALLY needs a workshop implemented. That alone would put it up to 8.5/10 simply due to the love the community would put into fixing every little detail and implementing some great stuff.
My childhood is back. Good game :3

Aside from that, delivers what I expect (which to be fair isn't much, I just want to play the game, preferably with some opposition).

Quick update on AI later same evening after playing a couple of 50 pop games:

Low level AI shared with player (primarily pathfinding) always had issues in AoE. There seem to be slightly less traffic blockades now (farm fields passable!), but they are still there. Of course, I am experienced with the game's shortcomings so it's likely a beginner would have greater trouble with these. Some other problems I noted here probably always were there as well, such as my army often dissipating while I multitask something else because it decided to walk further and further to chase villager spam into defending towers. Yeah, there's stand ground command but a default behavior that remembered initial location would have been nice...

High level AI flips between challenging and completely unchallenging. Example: On a large island map I was invading the Korean faction counter-attacking me with one swordsman a time (predictably getting slaughtered), until I blew through half their base, at which they suddenly attacked with 10+ and wiped my siege force. Other enemies liked sending one ship at a time on repeat; not sure if this is any different from original. Sometimes the targeting is not too smart and units prefer to move a lot instead of shooting (at worst even spastically getting into indecision loops moving back and forth).

I did get the impression that when the high level AI works, it can put up a fight to pose a threat, but perhaps not enough to change the outcome, making most battles still feel like cleanup. A beginner might have more trouble, though I am far from the best AoE player. If I had to compare it to what I remember from the original game, the strategic AI may well be slightly better now, but it's difficult to tell without going back and play the original (which I won't for a Steam review).

This is the game we all have been waiting for quite a long time as this reflects the old nostalgia of our childhood, playing with our old PCs. But unfortunately, this game cannot offer me with quite a few things I have hoped for a long time.

Cons,
Firstly, there are no troops formations and as we move the troops, they become buggy on the map and they look disgustingly formed, more like random constant movements among troops like they are not programmed to be formed in a certain formation like those in old AOE games.

Secondly, massive FPS stuttering when you move around the map.

Overall,

Graphic: Stunningly Detailed and beautiful

Sound: No bugs at the moment

PC specs requirement: Medium or High end

Game play: Just like old time, good o' Age of Empires game play but as I mentioned above, there are some issues with the game plays.

Stories and Campaigns: Most of the campaigns are focused on Egypt, Greece, Rome and Japan.

If they fix the graphic and game plays issues, I'll recommend to buy this game. But right now, just wait for some updates.

EDIT: Make sure to add your game to your AV software in order to fix the error message that kick you out of your game. We shouldn't really have to do this, but that's the fix.

I purchased this once on the windows store but I wanted it on steam due to windows store's chronic uselessness. 

It seems to be working without major issues so far.

The UI is a bit dodgy with scaling (text overlap) and buttons flickering when hovering over them but nothing game breaking. Not had any crashes but I did have to make sure the game was allowed through windows defender or I got an error message that stopped me from playing until I allowed permissions.

I am not a hardcore AoE player by any means, I play it a lot more casually. This means I can't speak much for balance and high level gameplay but I can praise the detailed tooltips and the updated graphics and animations really capture the feel of the old game and are very smooth.

If you're like me and only played AoE 1 single player casually and wanted to recapture the game from your childhood then this is perfect for that. 

Will update if I encounter any game breaking issues.

EDIT: So after a few more games I ran in to the old problem - the unit pathfinding is pretty bad, it's not the end of the world and it's exactly how the old game played but it would have been nice to see that improved and may put off some players. Units get stuck on each other all the time and it requires a bit of micro managing to separate them out a bit which gets a bit grating during longer play sessions. 

I still think the game is worth getting if you're a fan wanting to treat your nostalgia but don't expect much more than a visual overhaul and some UI improvements, it's a fine remaster but not a remake.

Get it if you want to play single player.

First game i ever played, graphics are amazing and this title still highly enjoyable after so many years, if your game is crashing after 5 minutes it happened to me too, adding the game to exclusions on my anti-virus solved the issue for me.

Pros:

-Looks nice.
-Runs well.
-Lots of single player content.

Cons: 

-The worst pathfinding I've ever seen in an RTS.
-No advanced unit control, no formations, nothing. Just attack-move and watch as half your army attacks houses (because they don't prioritize military units) and the other half gets stuck on each other.
-Extremely low maximum unit supply, at least half of which is taken by your villagers, so enjoy rebuilding a handful of units 10 times before you can break an enemy base.

Listen devs, "looks nice" doesn't cut it anymore. If your RTS game controls worse than Warcraft 2, it's a sign that you need to put more work into it.
